ENTITLED “VEHICLE INSPECTIONS,” OF CHAPTER 10, ENTITLED

“BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS,” OF THE MUNICIPAL CODE
OF THE VILLAGE OF FOREST PARK, COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
BE IT ORDAINED by the Mayor and Village Council of the Village of Forest Park, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
Section 1. Subsection D, entitled “Age of Vehicle,” of Section 6-2, entitled “Vehicle Inspections,” of Chapter 10, entitled “Taxicabs, Taximeters and
Drivers,” of Title 3, entitled “Business and License Regulations,” of the Municipal Code of the Village of Forest Park is hereby deleted in its entirety and in
lieu thereof the following new provision is to be inserted (emphasis added for new language):
D. Age of Vehicle: No vehicle shall be licensed as a taxicab, whether upon application or renewal, unless it is less than ten (10) years old at the time of
application, commencing with fiscal year 2020, and for each subsequent year.
Section 2. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this Ordinance shall be and the same are hereby repealed.
Section 3. The corporate authorities of the Village intend that this Ordinance will be made part of the Village Code and that sections of this
Ordinance can be renumbered or relettered and the word “Ordinance” can be changed to “Section,” “Article,” Chapter” or some other appropriate word or
phrase to accomplish codification, and regardless of whether this Ordinance is ever codified, the Ordinance can be renumbered or relettered and
typographical errors can be corrected with the authorization of the Village Attorney, or his or her designee.
Section 4. All parts of the Village Code in conflict with the terms or provisions of this Ordinance shall be and the same are hereby amended or
repealed to the extent of such conflict, and said Village Code and all other existing ordinances shall otherwise remain in full force and effect.
Section 5. If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Ordinance or any part thereof is, for any reason, held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining
portions of this Ordinance, or any part thereof. The corporate authorities hereby declare that they would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs,
sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective.
Section 6. This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect on and after its passage and approval in the manner provided by law.

each inspection. Except as provided below, the yearly fee, totaling two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), shall be billed to the establishment on May 1, the
beginning of each upcoming fiscal year, and shall be due upon receipt of the invoice. Except as provided below, in the event a reinspection is necessary, a
fee of one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00) shall be charged for the first reinspection and two hundred twenty-five dollars ($225.00) for each
additional reinspection, which shall be billed to the establishment on a quarterly basis and shall be due upon receipt. Notwithstanding the foregoing to the
contrary, the American Legion/VFW Hall shall be exempt from the application and imposition of the provisions and costs under this Subsection D.

typographical errors can be corrected with the authorization of the Village Attorney, or his or her designee.
Section 4. All parts of the Village Code in conflict with the terms or provisions of this Ordinance shall be and the same are hereby amended or
repealed to the extent of such conflict, and said Village Code and all other existing ordinances shall otherwise remain in full force and effect.

ORDINANCE NO. O-12-19
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING TITLE 9, ENTITLED
“FOREST PARK ZONING ORDINANCE,” OF THE
VILLAGE CODE OF THE VILLAGE OF FOREST PARK
(Central Business District Incubator Kitchens,
Personal Grooming Services and Massage Establishments)
WHEREAS, the Village of Forest Park maintains a zoning ordinance which is found in Title 9 of the Forest Park Village Code, Forest Park Illinois (the “Zoning
Ordinance”); and
WHEREAS, the Village Council deems it reasonable to periodically review said Zoning Ordinance and make necessary changes; and
WHEREAS, the Village filed an application (“Application”) to amend the Zoning Ordinance to (i) provide “Incubator Kitchens” as a permitted use in the
Downtown Business District (DBD) of the Village; (ii) amend the definition for “Personal Grooming Services” to remove “massages”; and (iii) provide for Massage
Establishments as a permitted use in the DBD (collectively, the "Text Amendments"); and
WHEREAS, pursuant to proper legal notice, a public hearing to consider the Application was conducted by the Village of Forest Park Zoning Board of Appeals
(the “ZBA”) on March 18, 2019, at which time the ZBA reviewed the Application and took all testimony and public comment regarding the proposed Text Amendments;
and
WHEREAS, the ZBA recommended that the Village Council approve the proposed Text Amendments to the Zoning Ordinance, as set forth herein; and
WHEREAS, the Village Council has considered the recommendation of the ZBA and all of the facts and circumstances regarding the Application and finds that it
is in the best interest of the Village to amend the Zoning Ordinance.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE VILLAGE OF FOREST PARK, COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS, as follows:
Section 1: The facts and statements contained in the preambles to this Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby incorporated herein adopted
as part of this Ordinance.
Section 2: Section 9-1-5, entitled “Definitions,” of Chapter 1, entitled “General Zoning Provisions,” of Title 9, entitled “Zoning Regulations,” is hereby
amended to include the following definition alphabetically:
INCUBATOR KITCHEN: An establishment that rents or otherwise makes available commercial-grade kitchen space for the exclusive or
primary purpose of food preparation including temporary extra production capacity, menu planning, training, taste testing, product
development, food packaging, food storage or any other food-related purpose.
Section 3: Section 9-4-C1, entitled “Use Regulations,” of Article C, entitled “DBD Downtown Business District,” of Chapter 4, entitled “Business District,”
of Title 9, entitled “Zoning Regulations,” of the Village Code of the Village of Forest Park, Illinois, is hereby amended by adding the following permitted use in the
appropriate alphabetical location:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 5/416
Incubator Kitchen,” subject to the following conditions:
A. Single owner. The facility must be owned by a single person or entity and may not have multiple owners.
B. Owner license required. No facility may be established without all licenses as required by the Forest Park Code of Ordinances.
C. Multiple-use by rental only. If the facility will be used at any time by persons or entities other than the owner of the facility, then that use must be by a written
rental agreement.
D. User license required. No person or entity may rent or use a shared kitchen facility without all licenses as required by the Forest Park Code of Ordinances.
Section 4: The definition of “Personal Grooming Services” in Section 9-1-5, entitled “Definitions,” of Chapter 1, entitled “General Zoning Provisions,” of
Title 9, entitled “Zoning Regulations,” is hereby amended as follows:
PERSONAL GROOMING SERVICES: An establishment licensed by the state of Illinois that utilizes one or more individuals that are licensed by the state
of Illinois to provide services necessary for personal grooming, including beauticians that provide any cosmetic treatment, including, but not limited to,
services to the hair, hands, legs, feet and face; spas that administer any personal care treatment such as facials and barbershops.
Section 5: Section 9-4-C1, entitled “Use Regulations,” of Article C, entitled “DBD Downtown Business District,” of Chapter 4, entitled “Business Districts,”
of Title 9, entitled “Forest Park Zoning Ordinance,” of the Village Code of the Village of Forest Park, Illinois, is hereby amended by adding the following permitted use in
the appropriate location:
Massage establishment, as defined and subject to compliance with all regulations pertaining to massage establishments in Section 3-7-2 of the Village Code
of the Village of Forest Park.
Section 6: The corporate authorities of the Village intend that this Ordinance will be made part of the Village Code and that sections of this Ordinance can be
renumbered or relettered and the word “Ordinance” can be changed to “Section,” “Article,” Chapter” or some other appropriate word or phrase to accomplish
codification, and regardless of whether this Ordinance is ever codified, the Ordinance can be renumbered or relettered and typographical errors can be corrected with the
authorization of the Village Attorney, or his or her designee.
Section 7: All parts of the Village Code in conflict with the terms or provisions of this Ordinance shall be and the same are hereby amended or repealed to the
extent of such conflict, and said Village Code and all other existing ordinances shall otherwise remain in full force and effect.
Section 8: If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Ordinance or any part thereof is, for any reason, held to be unconstitutional
or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of this Ordinance, or
any part thereof. The corporate authorities hereby declare that they would have passed each section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof
irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or
ineffective.
Section 9: That this Ordinance shall be in full force and effect on and after its passage and approval in the manner provided by law.
Passed by the Council of the Village of Forest Park, Cook County, Illinois this 8th day of April, 2019.

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING PARKING IN LOADING ZONES
AND DESIGNATING TEMPORARY PICK-UP AND DROP-OFF
LOADING ZONES ALONG A PORTION OF MADISON STREET
WHEREAS, the corporate authorities desire to amend parking in loading zones and to designate certain portions along Madison Street as
temporary pick-up and drop-off loading zones.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Mayor and Council of the Village of Forest Park, Cook County, Illinois as follows:
Section 1. The corporate authorities of the Village of Forest Park hereby amend Section 6-4-2C, entitled “Parking in Loading Zones,” of Section
6-4-2, entitled “Parking Restrictions,” of Chapter 4, entitled “Stopping, Standing and Parking,” of Title 6, entitled “Motor Vehicles and Traffic,” of the
Municipal Code of the Village of Forest Park, as follows:
C. Parking In Loading Zones: It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle without vehicle emergency flashers enabled to stand (i) a
passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for loading or unloading of passengers, not to exceed three (3) minutes; (ii)
any freight carrying vehicles for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty (30)
minutes; and (iii) a motor vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for pick-up and drop-off of delivery goods, not to exceed
fifteen (15) minutes, in any place designated and marked by the Village Council as a loading zone pursuant to Section 6-5-12, or in any of
the following designated places:
1. In any place within seventy five feet (75') along the curb before the entrance to any hospital;
2. At any place within seventy five feet (75') along the curb before the entrance to a public building between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. except Sundays. (Ord. O-17-98, 5-11-1998)

locations as fifteen (15) minute temporary pick-up and drop-off loading zones, and further direct that such locations be marked by the appropriate sign:

PREFACE
This Village Code of the Village of Forest Park, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including ordinance O-22-18, passed August 13, 2018.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this Village Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent
therewith. Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the Code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
Sterling Codifiers
Coeur d'Alene, Idaho
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING
THE MUNICIPAL CODE OF THE
VILLAGE OF FOREST PARK, ILLINOIS
BE IT ORDAINED by the Council of the Village of Forest Park, Illinois as follows:
Section 1: Pursuant to the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3, and from and after the date of passage of this ordinance, the Municipal Code of the Village of
Forest Park, Illinois, ("Village Code"), prepared by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., containing the compilation of all ordinances of a general nature, up to and
including ordinance O-21-04, passed May 10, 2004, together with the changes made to said ordinances, under the direction of the governing body of the
Village, shall be accepted in all courts without question as the official code and law of the Village of Forest Park as enacted by the Council.
Section 2: There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification, the loose-leaf type of binding together with the continuous supplement
service, provided by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a general and permanent nature amending, altering, adding or
deleting provisions of the official Village Code is identified by the proper catchline and is inserted in the proper place in each of the official copies, one copy
of which shall be maintained in the office of the Village Clerk, certified as to correctness and available for inspection at any and all times that said office is
regularly open.
Section 3: All ordinances of a general nature included in this official Village Code shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provision and
the fact that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the governing body shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous
effectiveness of ordinances included in said official Village Code. All ordinances of a special nature, such as tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances,
franchises, vacating ordinances and annexation ordinances shall continue in full force and effect unless specifically repealed or amended by a provision of
the Village Code. Such ordinances are not intended to be included in the official Village Code.
Section 4: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Village
Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter ortamper with such Village Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the
Village to be misrepresented thereby.
Section 5: All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith, are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed.
Section 6: This ordinance and the Village Code adopted by the same shall be recorded and shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage,
approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
PASSED this 26th day of July 2004.
AYES 5
NAYS 0
ABSENT 0

Mayor
ATTEST:

Title 1
ADMINISTRATION
Chapter 1
FOREST PARK VILLAGE CODE
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 9/416
1-1-1: OFFICIAL CODE:
The ordinances embraced in these titles, chapters and sections shall constitute, and be designated as, the MUNICIPAL CODE OF THE VILLAGE OF
FOREST PARK, ILLINOIS, and may be so cited. (Village Code § 2-1)
1-1-2: SAVING CLAUSE:
All of the provisions of this code shall be in full force and effect from its passage and publication in book form, as provided by statute.
All general ordinances of the village, passed by the village council prior to the effective date of this code are hereby repealed, subject to the saving clauses
herein, and except those ordinances which are referred to herein as remaining in full force and effect or are, by necessary implication, herein reserved
from repeal. The following ordinances are excluded and are not repealed: tax levy ordinances, appropriation ordinances, ordinances relating to boundaries
or annexations; franchise and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or corporations, contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the
execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections; ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by, or from the
village; and all special ordinances, nor shall it affect any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending on said date; except that the proceeding thereof shall
conform as far as possible to the provisions of this code. (Village Code § 2-2; amd. 2004 Code)
1-1-3: ORDINANCES:
A. Passage And Publication: All ordinances passed by the mayor and village council shall be recorded by the village clerk in a proper book or books. The
original shall be filed in the office of the village clerk and due proof of publication of all ordinances requiring publication shall be procured by the village
clerk, and such proof or affidavit of publication shall be attached to and filed away with said ordinances. The villageclerk shall also note in his book of
ordinances, at the foot of the record of each ordinance, a memorandum of the date of passage and, if published or posted, the date of the publication
or posting of such ordinance. (Village Code § 2-5)
B. Effective Date: All ordinances passed by the village council requiring publication shall take effect from and after due publication thereof, unless therein
otherwise expressly provided. Ordinances not requiring publication shall take effect from their passage and upon being as signed and attested to,
unless otherwise expressly provided. (Village Code § 2-6)
C. Repealed Or Modified Ordinances: Wherever any ordinance, or part of any ordinance, shall be repealed or modified by a subsequent ordinance, a part
of an ordinance thus repealed or modified shall continue in force until the effective date of the ordinance repealing or modifying the same, but no suit
proceeding right, fine, forfeiture or penalty instituted, created, given, secured or accrued under any ordinance previous to its repeal shall in any way be
enjoyed and recovered as fully as if such ordinance had continued in force, unless therein otherwise expressly provided. (Village Code § 2-7)
D. Revival Of Previous Ordinance: When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be
construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless expressly provided therein. (Village Code § 2-8)
1-1-4: CONSTITUTIONALITY:
If any part or parts, section or subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is, for any reason, declared to be unconstitutional or invalid, such
decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of the code. (Village Code § 2-11)
Chapter 2
DEFINITIONS
1-2-1: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
In the construction of this code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed unless such construction would be inconsistent with the
manifest intent of this code:
A. Computation Of Time: The time within which an act is to be done, as herein provided, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the
last. If the last day be Sunday, it shall be excluded.
B. Gender: Words used in the masculine gender shall include feminine and neuter.
C. Joint Authority: All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such
persons or officers.
D. Official Time: Central Standard Time shall be the official time for the transaction of all village business; except during the period that daylight saving time
shall be in effect by the city of Chicago, the official time shall then be advanced by one hour.
E. Or, And: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or", if the sense requires it.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 10/416
F. Plural, Singular: Words importing the singular shall include the plural, and words importing the plural shall include the singular.
G. Preceding, Following: The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively.
H. Reasonable Time: In all cases where any provision shall require any act to be done in a "reasonable time" or "reasonable notice" to be given to any
person, such reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean such time only as may be necessary in the prompt execution of such duty or
compliance with such notice.
I. Signatures Or Subscription: Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
J. State Law References: Whenever reference is made to statute it shall mean the Illinois Compiled Statutes. Unless otherwisestated, the intent of the
village is to refer to the current Illinois Compiled Statutes.
K. Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present.
L. Written Or In Writing: Includes any representation of words, letters or figures whether by printing or otherwise. (Village Code §§ 2-3, 2-26; amd. 2004
Code)
1-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise provided, the following words and terms shall be defined as set out in this section:
COUNCIL: The village council of the village of Forest Park, Illinois.
COUNTY: The county of Cook, state of Illinois.
FISCAL YEAR: The municipal year of the village for all fiscal, financial and official purposes, except where otherwise specially provided by ordinance, shall
commence on May 1 and end on April 30 in the calendar year following.
MONTH: A calendar month.
OATH: Includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and
"sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed."
OWNER: Applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety
of the whole, or of a part, of such building or land.
PERSON: Includes a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization, trustee or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a natural person.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every species of property except real property, as herein defined.
PROPERTY: Includes real and personal property.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any street or highway, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school yard or open space adjacent thereto, and any lake or stream.
REAL PROPERTY: Includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
SIDEWALK: Any portion of a street, between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
STREET: Includes streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, viaducts and all other public highways in the village.
TENANT OR OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease, or who occupies the whole or a part, of such
building or land either alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The village of Forest Park, Cook County, Illinois.
YEAR: A calendar year. (Village Code §§ 2-3, 2-15; amd. 2004 Code)
1-2-3: CATCHLINES:
The headings of the several sections of this code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section; nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections,
including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (Village Code § 2-4)
Chapter 3
GENERAL PENALTY
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 11/416
1-3-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Wherever in this code or in any ordinance of the village, or rule or regulation promulgated by an officer or agency thereof, under authority invested by law
or ordinance, the doing of an act is prohibited, or the omission to do any act, is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense and where no specific
penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this code, ordinance, rule or regulation shall be punished by a fine not exceeding seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)1, provided, however, that a violation of section 6-1-1/13-111 of this code, operation of second division vehicle without a
certificate of valid safety test, shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). Every day that a violation of this code, or any such ordinance, rule or regulation shall continue, shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. O-54-
07, 11-13-2007)
1-3-2: OFFENSES UNDER SEPARATE PROVISIONS:
In all cases where the same offenses may be made punishable, or may be created by different clauses or sections of the ordinances of the village, the
prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense. (Village
Code § 2-10)
1-3-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
A. The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate
section.
B. In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed, but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a
license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
C. Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2004 Code)
ARTICLE A. ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATIONS
1-3A-1: PURPOSE:
The stated purpose of this article is to provide for fair and efficient enforcement and expeditious adjudication of municipal ordinance violations, excluding
standing, parking and condition of motor vehicle violations that are adjudicated pursuant to sections 6-9-1 through 6-9-13 of this code, as may be allowed
by law and directed by this or any other ordinance, through an administrative adjudication of violations of village ordinances and establishing a schedule of
fines and penalties and the authority and procedures for collection of unpaid fines and penalties.
The village hereby adopts, in its present form, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.2 et seq., and 5/11-31.1-2. (Ord. O-54-07, 11-13-2007)
1-3A-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, unless the context requires otherwise, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them:
BUILDING CODE: Any adopted code, municipal ordinance, law, housing or building codes or zoning ordinances that establish construction, plumbing,
heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable to structures and property in the village, or any village
ordinance that requires, after notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal of garbage and debris, the removal of inoperable motor vehicles or the abatement
of nuisances from private property.
BUILDING OWNER: The legal, equitable or beneficial owner of a structure.
CODE: The Forest Park village code of ordinances, except for anyoffense under the Illinois motor vehicle code1 or a similar offense that regulates the
movement of motor vehicles.
CODE VIOLATION: Any infraction or violation of any village ordinance or violation of this code including any building code, law or rule adopted by
reference.
DEFENDANT OR RESPONDENT: Any person, corporation, partnership, building or property owner, whether such ownership is legal or equitable, charged
with a violation of any ordinance of the village or of this code, building code or any of its adopted codes.
HEARING OFFICER: A village employee or officer, agent or appointee of the village other than a law enforcement officer or building inspector whose duty
it is to:
A. Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or not a building violation or other code violation exists;
B. Hear testimony and accept evidence from all interested parties relevant to the existence of a building code violation or other code violation;
C. Preserve and authenticate the transcript and record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 12/416
D. Issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a code violation exists and imposing fines;
E. Issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant testimony at the hearing; and
F. Find a respondent in default for failure to appear and proceed with the hearing.
INSPECTOR: Any state, county or village employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of structures in the village to determine if building
code violations, as herein defined, exist.
SYSTEM OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION: The adjudication of any code violation or any other village ordinance violation including, but not limited
to, those actions brought pursuant to this code, as well as the zoning ordinance and adopted codes such as the building code, fire code, plumbing code,
electrical code, property maintenance code and health and sanitation codes of the village, violations of section 6-1-1/13-111 of this code for operation of
second division vehicle without certificate of valid safety test, but shall not include violations regarding thestanding, parking or condition of motor vehicles
brought pursuant to authority granted the village by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3. Nor shall a system of administrative adjudication apply to
proceedings not within the statutory authority granted to the village pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., or 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3, nor shall it apply to offenses under the Illinois motor vehicle code2 or similar municipal offenses that are traffic
regulations governing the movement of vehicles or any reportable offense under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-204.
VILLAGE: The village of Forest Park, Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. O-41-03, 10-14-2003; amd. Ord. O-54-07, 11-13-2007)
1-3A-3: HEARING PROCEDURES NONEXCLUSIVE:
The provisions of this article shall not preclude the village from using other methods or proceedings to enforce the ordinances of the village, including the
institution of any action in the circuit court of Cook County, Illinois, or any other authorized administrative proceeding. (Ord. O-41-03, 10-14-2003)
1-3A-4: CODE HEARING PROCEEDINGS:
A. Instituting And Conducting:
1. At such time as any inspector, police officer or other individual authorized to issue a code violation citation notice finds the existence of a code
violation, he shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice and report form, indicating the name and address of the structure owner,
and/or party(s) in possession of the structure or other respondent, in cases other than building code violations, the type and nature of the violation,
the date and time the violation was observed, the name of the person witnessing the violation and the address of the structure or other location
where the violation is observed.
2. The violation notice form shall be forwarded by the inspector, police officer or other authorized individual, to the code hearing department where a
citation or docket number shall be stamped on all copies of the notice and a hearing date noted in the blank spaces provided for that purpose on the
violation notice form. Except for violations related to the standing, stopping or condition of motor vehicles adjudicated pursuant to title 6, chapter 9 of
this code, the hearing date shall not be less than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days after the violation is reported to the code hearing
department.
3. One copy of the violation notice form shall be maintained in the files of the code hearing department and shall be part of therecord of hearing, one
copy of the notice form shall be returned to the inspector or officer so that he may prepare evidence of the code violation for presentation at the
hearing on the date indicated, and one copy of the violation notice form shall be served, personally or by first class U.S. mail, postage prepaid, to the
respondent, along with a summons or notice to appear commanding the respondent to appear at the hearing. If, in the case of a building code
violation, the name of the owner of the structure or premises cannot be ascertained or if service on the owner cannot be made by mail, service may
be made on the owner of the structure or premises by posting or mailing a copy of the violation notice form and summons on the front door of the
structure where the violation is found, not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is scheduled.
B. Subpoenas; Defaults: At any time prior to the hearing date the hearing officer assigned to hear the case may, at the request of an inspector, other
authorized person on behalf of the village or the attorney for the village, or the respondent or his attorney, issue subpoenas directing witnesses to
appear and give testimony at the hearing. The party requesting a subpoena shall serve, via first class mail, copies of any and all subpoenas on all
parties to the action. If, on the date set for hearing, the respondent, his attorney or agent, fails to appear, the hearing officer may, after determining that
proper notice of hearing has been given, find the respondent in default and proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a
code violation.
C. Continuances; Representation:
1. No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer except in such cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of
the respondent. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for continuance. Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer under this section shall
not, except for good cause shown, exceed twenty five (25) days.
2. At the hearing, the case for the village may be presented by the inspector in the case of a building code violation, by another village employee or by
an attorney designated by the village; provided, however, that the case for the village may not be presented by a member of the code hearing
department. The case for the respondent may be presented by the respondent, or his attorney.
D. Hearing; Evidence: At the hearing, the hearing officer shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the existence or
nonexistence of a code violation. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply to these hearings. (Ord. O-41-03, 10-14-
2003)
1-3A-5: FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 13/416
A. General: At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a determination on the basis of the evidence presentedat the hearing as to
whether or not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be designated as findings, decision and order. The findings,
decision and order shall include the hearing officer's findings of fact, a decision as to whether or not a code violation exists based on the findings of
fact, and an order, ordering correction of the violation in the case of a building code violation, stating the fines or sanctions if applicable or dismissing
the case, in the event a violation is not proved. If a violation is proved, the order may impose any and all sanctions or fines that are provided by this
code for a violation proved, not to exceed the fines set out in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code per violation. A copy of the findings,
decision and order shall be served on the respondent or his attorney within five (5) days after it is issued; service shall be in the same manner as the
violation notice form and summons are served pursuant to section 1-3A-4 of this article. Payment of any penalty or fine imposed shall be to the village
and shall be paid within thirty (30) days of the date the order is issued. (Ord. O-41-03, 10-14-2003; amd. 2004 Code)
B. Judgment On Findings, Decision And Order:
1. Any fine, sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of or the failure to
exhaust, judicial review procedures under the administrative review law shall be a debt due and owing the village and, as such, may be collected in
accordance with applicable law.
2. After expiration of the period in which judicial review under the administrative review law may be sought for a final determination of the village, the
village may commence a proceeding in the circuit court of Cook County for purposes of obtaining a judgment on the findings, decision and order.
Nothing in this article shall prevent the village from consolidating multiple findings, decisions and orders against a person in such a proceeding. Upon
commencement of the action, the village shall file a certified copy of the findings, decision and order, which shall be accompanied by a certification
that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings, decision and order was issued in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-31.1-1 et seq., or 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., as the case may be and the applicable village ordinances. Service of the summons and a copy of the
petition may be by any method provided in section 2-203 of the Illinois code of civil procedure or by certified mail, return receipt requested, providing
that the total fines or other sanctions and costs imposed by the findings, decision and order do not exceed the sum of two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00). If the court is satisfied that the findings, decision and order was entered in accordance with the requirements of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., or 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., and the applicable village ordinances, and that the respondent had an opportunity for a
hearing and for judicial review as provided:
a. The court shall render judgment in favor of the village and against the respondent for the amount indicated in the findings, decision and order, plus
costs. Such judgment shall have the same effect and may be enforced in the same manner as other judgments for the recovery of the money; and
b. The court may also issue such other orders and injunctions as are requested by the village to enforce the order of the hearing officer to correct a
code violation. (Ord. O-41-03, 10-14-2003)
1-3A-6: REVIEW UNDER ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW ACT:
The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be subject to review in the circuit court of Cook County and the provisions of the administrative
review law, and all amendments and modifications thereto, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, are adopted and shall apply to and govern every action
for the judicial review of the final findings, decision and order of a hearing officer in hearings under this article. (Ord. O-41-03, 10-14-2003)
1-3A-7: SANCTIONS APPLICABLE TO OWNER:
Any order to correct a building code violation and any sanctions imposed as a result of a finding of the existence of a building code violation under this
article shall attach to the property as well as to the owner of the property, so that a finding of a violation against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying
or transferring the property to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of the property is subject to the findings, decision and order of the
hearing officer. (Ord. O-41-03, 10-14-2003)
1-3A-8: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING OFFICER QUALIFICATIONS:
Prior to conducting proceedings for administrative hearings, hearing officers shall successfully complete a formal training program that includes the
following:
A. Instruction on the rules of procedure of the hearings that they will conduct;
B. Orientation in each subject area of code violations that they will administer;
C. Observation of administrative hearings;
D. Participation in hypothetical cases, including rules on evidence and issuing final orders; and
E. All hearing officers must be attorneys licensed to practice in the state of Illinois for a minimum period of three (3) years. (Ord. O-41-03, 10-14-2003)
Footnote 1: 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.
Footnote 2: 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.
ARTICLE B. BOND FEE
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 14/416
1-3B-1: BAIL PROCESSING FEE:
An administrative bail processing fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) be and is hereby imposed against any person arrested and charged with a violation of any
bailable village of Forest Park ordinance, state or federal law. The bail processing fee shall be collected when such arrestee posts bail or bond.
All bail fees posted shall be paid to the general corporate fund of the village of Forest Park. (Ord. O-34-11, 11-28-2011)
Chapter 4
MAYOR AND VILLAGE COUNCIL
1-4-1: FORM OF GOVERNMENT:
The village council of Forest Park shall consist of the mayor and four (4) commissioners, as provided by the act known as the commission form of
municipal government act1. (Village code § 1-1)
1-4-2: ELECTION, TERM, OATH, BOND AND COMPENSATION:
A. Election, Term: The mayor and commissioners shall be elected, and hold office, for such term as is provided by law2. (Village code § 1-5)
B. Bond: Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, the mayor and each commissioner shall execute a bond in a penal sum not less than
three thousand dollars ($3,000.00), with good and sufficient security, to be approved by the judge of the county court of Cook County, and conditioned
for the faithful performance of the duties of the office and the payment of all monies received by such officer, according to law and the ordinances of the
village. (Village code § 1-4)
C. Oath And Compensation: The several commissioners and the mayor shall take the oath of office prescribed by law, and shall receive such
compensation as determined by ordinance passed in accordance with the laws of this state. (Village code § 1-6)
1-4-3: EXECUTIVE AND ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENTS:
The executive and administrative powers, authority and duties of the village shall be distributed into and among five (5) departments as follows:
Department of public affairs
Department of accounts and finances
Department of public health and safety
Department of streets and public improvements
Department of public property
The village council shall, by ordinance, designate the commissioner to be in charge and have supervision of one of the above departments. (Village code
§ 1-7)
1-4-3-1: COMMISSIONER OF PUBLIC AFFAIRS:
A. Mayor As Commissioner Of Public Affairs: The mayor shall have and exercise all the powers and perform all the duties provided and prescribed by the
laws of this state, or by the ordinances of the village not in conflict with the provisions thereof, and shall be the commissioner of public affairs and
superintendent of that department.
B. Powers And Duties:
1. He shall have general supervision over all departments and offices and employees of the village and shall report to the village council for its action
all matters requiring attention in any department.
2. He shall preside at all meetings of the village council.
3. He shall, on behalf of the village, sign all contracts the execution of which shall have been authorized by the village council.
4. The mayor shall have charge of, and cause to be prepared, all statements and reports required by law or ordinance or by resolution of the village
council.
5. The mayor shall grant all licenses and all permits not especially assigned to some other department.
6. In the absence or inability of any of the commissioners to act, he shall, unless the village council shall otherwise direct, exercise temporary
supervision over the department assigned to such commissioner. (Village Code § 1-23)
7. He shall have jurisdiction and supervision of the police department and the community center.
8. He shall have supervision over all public service utilities and all persons or corporations rendering service in the village under any franchise, contract
or grant made or granted by the village or state, and shall report to the village council or other proper officer any failure of such persons or
corporations to render service, or to observe the requirement or conditions of the franchise, contract or grant, under which such public service utility
is being operated.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 15/416
9. He shall have general supervision over all departments and offices of the village, and shall report to the council for its action, all matters requiring
attention in any department. (Ord. O-15-76, 9-27-1976)
C. Rules: The commissioner of public affairs shall make and enforce such rules and regulations not inconsistent with the law or ordinances as may be
necessary to secure efficient conduct of the service of his department and the business thereof. (Village Code § 1-47)
1-4-3-2: COMMISSIONER OF ACCOUNTS AND FINANCES:
A. Powers And Duties: The commission of accounts and finances shall have charge of and supervision over all accounts and records of the village and all
officers, departments and employees required to keep or make accounts, records or reports. He shall inspect or cause to be inspected all records and
accounts of the offices and departments of the village and shall cause proper accounts and records to be kept and proper reports to be made. He shall
have charge of the purchase, care and distribution of all stationery and printing and all other supplies and other articles not otherwise provided by law.
He shall examine, or cause to be examined, and report thereon to the council all bills, payrolls and claims before they are acted upon or allowed,
unless otherwise provided by law. He shall procure from all persons and corporations operating public service utilities in the village such reports, if any,
as such persons or corporations are required to make to the village or any of its officers and procure copies of such reports as are made to the state or
any public office or department. He shall place all such reports on file in the village clerk's office. He shall collect, or cause to be collected, all license
fees, special occupation or business taxes, franchise taxes, rentals or other monies which may be due, or become due, to the village. He shall report to
the village council any failure to make reports or to pay monies due to the village, with such recommendations in relation thereto as he may deem
proper. In cases where the village has authority so to do, he shall cause to be examined the accounts or records of any person or corporation having
an occupation or business subject to special tax, and shall report to the village council any refusal to permit such examination. The village treasurer,
village clerk and their respective offices, and all employees therein and all accountants and bookkeepers shall be under the supervision of the
department of accounts and finances. (Village Code § 1-48)
B. Fire Department And Fire Inspection Bureau3: The commissioner of accounts and finances shall have jurisdiction over and supervision of the fire
department and the fire inspection bureau and shall have charge of the purchases of all supplies, apparatus and equipment pertaining to and in said
department and bureau. (Ord. O-4-80, 3-10-1980)
C. Village Council Vice President: The commissioner of accounts and finances shall be vice president of the village council, and in case of vacancy in the
office of the mayor or in the absence of the mayor, or his inability to act, shall preside over the village council and perform all the usual duties of the
mayor and commissioner of public affairs. (Village Code § 1-50)
D. Rules: The commissioner of accounts and finances shall make and enforce such rules and regulations, not inconsistent with the law or ordinances, as
may be necessary to secure efficient conduct of the service of his department and the business thereof. (Village code § 1-51)
E. Collective Bargaining: Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-5-2, it is hereby determined that the department of accounts and finances shall have
the power and duty of overseeing collective bargaining conducted with any labor organization that has been designated by the Illinois labor relations
board as the exclusive representative of any village employees in a bargaining unit which has been recognized by the Illinois labor relations board, and
such powers and duties hereby assigned to the department of accounts and finances. (Ord. O-13-03, 4-28-2003)
1-4-3-3: COMMISSIONER OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY:
A. Powers And Duties: The commissioner of public health and safety shall have jurisdiction over and supervision of the building department, the code
hearing department and all other inspectors not otherwise assigned. He shall be in charge of and have supervision and direction over all officers and
employees of said departments and of all officers and employees charged with any duties concerning the matters and things assigned to his
department. He shall be consulted on all purchases for, and have charge of, motor vehicles, apparatus, officers, employees and all supplies of said
departments except such as are otherwise specially assigned. (Ord. O-19-99, 6-28-1999; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
B. Rules: The commissioner of health and safety shall make and enforce such rules and regulations not inconsistent with the law or ordinances as may be
necessary to secure efficient conduct of the service of his department and the business thereof. (Village code § 1-54; amd. Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004)
1-4-3-4: COMMISSIONER OF STREETS AND PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
A. Powers And Duties:
1. The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall have authority over and charge of all public works, streets and alleys, except as
otherwise provided by law; the entire erection, making and reconstruction of all street improvements, paving, curbing, sewers and all public
improvements and of the repair thereof; the erection and maintenance of nonelectrical traffic signs on all streets and public ways and all underground
utilities of the village. The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall keep all roadways, gutters, curbs, manholes, catch basins and
alleys of the village clean and in good repair and condition. The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall also have charge of
enforcing the provisions of any ordinances which relate to obstructions, encroachments or any other trespasses upon the streets and alleys, and any
ordinances which relate to garbage, drainage and billposting.
2. In all cases where excavations in, or obstructions of, streets, alleys and public ways are permitted as provided by ordinance and a permit therefor is
required, such permit shall be issued by said commissioner of streets and public improvements.
3. The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall keep all village maps and charts to date, and shall keep account of all matters and
doings of the department in books to be provided for that purpose.
4. The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall also provide for the collection and disposal of all garbage and rubbish.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 16/416
5. The engineer in charge and all persons employed in the department of streets and public improvements shall be under the supervision and direction
of the commissioner thereof.
6. The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall also be ex officio the commissioner of public works, with regard to all of the duties
assigned to the commissioner of streets and public improvements.
B. Rules: The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall make and enforce such rules and regulations not inconsistent with the law or
ordinances, as may be necessary to secure efficient conduct of the service of his department and the business thereof. (Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004)
1-4-3-5: COMMISSIONER OF PUBLIC PROPERTY:
A. Powers And Duties:
1. The commissioner of public property shall have charge of and supervision over the care, custody and recovery of all village property not otherwise
specially assigned. The commissioner of public property shall have charge of the repair and maintenance of the village hall and all village buildings
and of the grounds connected therewith, all aboveground utilities and the direction of the lighting of streets, alleys, public grounds, public places,
municipal buildings, and all other public lighting provided for by ordinance. The commissioner of public property shall also have authority over and be
in charge of the construction, repair and maintenance of all playgrounds. All persons employed by and assigned to the department of public property
shall be under the supervision and direction of the commissioner thereof.
B. Rules: Said commissioner shall make and enforce such rules and regulations, not inconsistent with the law or ordinances, as may be necessary to
secure efficient conduct in service of his department and the business thereof. (Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004)
1-4-4: VILLAGE COUNCIL MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the village council shall be held on the second and fourth Monday of each month of the year at seven
o'clock (7:00) P.M. unless otherwise ordered at a regular meeting. (Ord. O-19-98, 6-22-1998)
B. Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called at any time, by the mayor or two (2) commissioners, upon giving not less than twenty four (24) hours'
notice to all members of the village council. Provided however, that if all members of the village council are present at a special meeting, no notice of
such meeting shall be necessary.
C. Open Meetings: All meetings of the village council, whether regular or special, shall be open to the public. (Village code § 1-9)
D. Presiding Officer: The mayor shall preside at all meetings. In the absence of the mayor, the commissioner of the department of accounts and finances
shall act as chair for the meeting.
E. Quorum: Three (3) members of the village council shall constitute a quorum, and the affirmative vote of three (3) members shall be necessary to adopt
any motion, resolution or ordinance, or pass any measure, except where otherwise provided by law. (Village code § 1-10)
F. Voting; Records: Upon every vote of the yeas and nays shall be called and recorded; and every motion, resolution or ordinance shall be reduced to
writing and read before a vote is taken thereon. All the commissioners, including the mayor, present at any meeting shall vote thereon. (Village code
§ 1-11)
G. Disorderly Conduct: In case of any disturbance or disorderly conduct, the presiding officer shall have the power to require the chambers to be cleared,
as necessary. (Village code § 1-12)
H. Electronic Attendance At Meetings:
1. Rules Statement: It is the decision of the village of Forest Park that any member of the council may attend any open or closed meeting of the council
via electronic means (such as by telephone, video or internet connection) provided that such attendance is in compliance with these rules and any
applicable laws.
2. Prerequisites: A member of the council may attend a meeting electronically if the member meets the following conditions:
a. The member shall notify the village clerk at least forty eight (48) hours before the meeting, unless impractical, so that necessary communications
equipment can be arranged. Inability to make the necessary technical arrangements will result in denial of a request for remote attendance.
b. The member must assert one of the following three (3) reasons why he or she is unable to physically attend the meeting:
(1) The member cannot attend because of personal illness or disability; or
(2) The member cannot attend because of employment purposes or the business of the village of Forest Park; or
(3) The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency.
3. Authorization To Participate:
a. The village clerk, after receiving the electronic attendance request, shall inform the council of the request for electronic attendance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 17/416
b. After establishing that a quorum is physically present at a meeting where a member of the village of Forest Park desires to attend electronically,
the presiding officer shall state that: 1) a notice was received by the member of the council in accordance with these rules, and 2) the member will
be deemed authorized to attend the meeting electronically unless a motion objecting to the member's electronic attendance is made, seconded,
and approved by a majority of the members of the council physically present at the meeting. If no such motion is made and seconded or if any
such motion fails to achieve the required vote by the members of the council physically present at the meeting, then the request by the member to
attend the meeting electronically shall be deemed approved by the council and the presiding officer shall declare the requesting member present.
After such declaration by the presiding officer, the question of a member's electronic attendance may not be reconsidered.
4. Adequate Equipment Required: The member participating electronically and other members of the council must be able to communicate effectively,
and members of the audience must be able to hear all communications at the meeting site. Before allowing electronic attendance at any meeting, the
council shall provide equipment adequate to accomplish this objective at the meeting site.
5. Minutes: Any member attending electronically shall be considered an off site attendee and counted as present electronically for that meeting if the
member is allowed to attend. The meeting minutes shall also reflect and state specifically whenever a member is present by electronic means.
6. Rights Of Remote Member: A member permitted to attend electronically will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting and
participate in the same capacity as those members physically present, subject to all general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted
and adhered to. The member attending electronically shall be heard, considered, and counted as to any vote taken. Accordingly, the name of any
member attending electronically shall be called during any vote taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded by the village clerk and placed in the
minutes for the corresponding meeting. A member attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any member, provided
the member attending electronically shall announce his or her leaving and returning.
7. Committees, Boards And Commissions: These rules shall apply to all committees, boards and commissions established by authority of the council of
the village of Forest Park. (Ord. O-05-09, 1-26-2009)
1-4-5: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
After the meeting has been called to order and it is found that a quorum is present, the village council shall proceed to the business before it, which shall
be conducted in the following order:
Roll call.
Reading of minutes of the proceedings of the last meeting or meetings, and correction and approval of the same, unless dispensed with by the village
council.
Reading of petitions and communications.
Bills for approval.
Reports of officers.
Unfinished business.
New business.
Adjournment. (Village code § 1-19)
1-4-6: CONDUCT OF PROCEEDINGS:
A. Presentation Of Materials: When a member wishes to present a communication, petition, order, resolution or other original matter, he shall send it to the
desk of the village clerk, who shall read such matter in its proper order. (Village code § 1-13; amd. 2004 Code)
B. Oratory Or Debate; Time Limitations: No member, without leave of the village council, shall speak more than once upon the same subject until every
member desirous of speaking shall have spoken; and no member shall speak longer than five (5) minutes at any one time, except by consent of the
village council. (Village code § 1-14)
C. Members Required To Vote; Exceptions: Every member who shall be present when a question is stated from the chair, shall vote thereon, unless
excused by the village council or unless he is directly interested in the question, in which case, he shall not vote. In case that any member refuses to
vote upon any question, he shall be recorded as voting "no". (Village code § 1-16; amd. Ord. O-48-10, 10-25-2010)
D. Presiding Officer To Decide Questions: The presiding officer shall decide all questions of order; and in all cases not provided for by law or ordinance, all
meetings will be governed by "Robert's Rules Of Order". (Village code § 1-17; amd. Ord. O-48-10, 10-25-2010)
E. Signatures On Documents: Every resolution, ordinance and measure, passed by the village council, must be signed by the mayor, or by two (2)
commissioners, and be recorded in the books of the village before the same shall be in force. (Village code § 1-18; amd. Ord. O-48-10, 10-25-2010)
F. Bills: No bills or claims for labor or material furnished to the village shall be paid until the same has been approved by the commissioner of the
respective department to which such labor or material has been furnished, and it shall be the duty of the commissioner of accounts and finances to see
that no bill is paid until it has been so approved. (Village code § 1-20; amd. Ord. O-48-10, 10-25-2010)
G. Sergeant At Arms: The chief of police of the village shall act as sergeant at arms at the village council meetings, and shall be in uniform. He shall
preserve order and obey the directions of the village council, and perform all duties usually appertaining to the office of sergeant at arms of deliberative
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 18/416
assemblies; provided however, in his absence or inability to act, the fire chief shall act as such sergeant at arms. He shall have power to appoint such
number of assistants as he may deem necessary. (Village code § 1-21; amd. Ord. O-48-10, 10-25-2010)
H. Censure: Any member acting in a disgraceful manner or who uses opprobrious, obscene or insulting language to, or about, any member of the village
council, or who does not obey the order of the chair, or who wilfully and persistently violates any of the standing rules of the village council shall be, on
motion, censured by a majority vote of the members present, or expelled by a four-fifths (4/5) vote of all members elected. In case of censure, the
sergeant at arms, or any person acting under the direction of the chair, shall cause the member censured to vacate his seat and come before the bar of
the village council and receive censure from the chair. (Village code § 1-22; amd. Ord. O-48-10, 10-25-2010)
1-4-7: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. General: The village council has and shall exercise all legislative powers, functions and duties conferred upon it by statute. It shall make all orders for
the doing of work or the making or construction of any improvements, bridges or buildings. It shall levy all taxes and appropriate all funds; and audit all
bills, accounts, payrolls and claims and order payment thereof. It shall make, or authorize the making of, all contracts, and no contract shall bind or be
obligatory upon the village unless reduced to writing and approved by the village council. All officers and superintendents are only agents of the village
council, and all of their acts shall be subject to review and to approval or rejection by the village council. Every officer, superintendent or employee
having discretionary or supervisory powers shall from time to time, as required by law and ordinance, or whenever requested by the village council or
by the commissioner in charge of the department to which such report relates, or whenever he shall deem necessary for the good of the public service,
report to the village council in writing, respecting the business of his department or office, or the matters connected therewith. The village council shall,
by ordinance, determine the powers and duties of, and to be performed by, each department and assign them to the appropriate department. Said
village council shall also prescribe the duties and powers of officers and employees, and may require an officer or employee to perform duties in two
(2) or more departments; and may make such other rules and regulations as may be necessary or proper for the efficient and economical conduct of
the business of the village. (Village code § 1-2)
B. Licenses: The village council shall grant all licenses and shall have the power to revoke the same. (Village code § 1-3)
1-4-8: RULES FOR PUBLIC PARTICIPATION:
In order to secure the rights of the citizens of the village of Forest Park to fair and just representation before their elected officials, and to guarantee order
at public meetings of the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park, the following rules are established:
A. Any person who seeks to address the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park, at the time allotted during the public meeting for public
comments and questions, shall be permitted to speak, only upon recognition by the presiding officer, and such person shall adhere to the following
provisions:
1. Prior to addressing the corporate authorities, each person addressing the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park must complete the public
questions and comments sign-in sheet provided by the village clerk.
2. Each person addressing the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park shall state his/her name and address for the record, at the beginning
of such address.
3. Each person shall be granted no more than three (3) minutes per meeting in order to address the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park,
unless such time is extended by the presiding officer, giving consideration to the probable number of speakers and lateness of the hour.
4. Questions and/or comments shall be limited to village business. Comments supporting or opposing a nominated person's candidacy for elective
office shall not be permitted.
5. Comments shall be directed to the presiding officer, unless the presiding officer permits the individual to address the members of the village council
or other village officials, employees or consultants present.
6. The following behavior is prohibited during a public meeting of the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park:
a. Conduct in violation of any village ordinance, state or federal law, or any rule or regulation implementing state or federal law;
b. Interruption of speakers; name calling; boisterous remarks;
c. Offensive use of abusive, obscene, profane, slanderous or threatening language or gestures;
d. Acting or behaving in such an unreasonable manner so as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; and
e. Any other act designed to intimidate, threaten or harm persons, or damage or destroy property.
B. Members of the public shall not engage in audible conversation which prohibits individuals from hearing and/or participating in a public meeting, or
disrupts the conduct of business by the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park.
C. Members of the public may enter and leave the meeting room at any time, provided such entrance or exit is made quietly and in an orderly fashion.
D. Battery operated recording equipment is permitted at public meetings, provided the operation thereof is silent.
E. The presiding officer at each public meeting of the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park shall be responsible for the enforcement of the
provisions of this section, and shall be empowered to reprimand and/or cause the removal of any and all persons violating the provisions of this
section. The removal of an offender from a public meeting shall proceed as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 19/416
1. The presiding officer shall twice give the offender notice that he/she is violating certain terms of this section and might be removed from the public
meeting.
2. If the offender continues to violate any of the provisions of this section after receiving the above notice, the presiding officer shall order a police
officer to remove the offender from the meeting room. If the offender continues the disturbance outside the meeting room, such that the orderly
conduct of business by the corporate authorities of the village of Forest Park is disrupted, the offender shall be removed from the village hall.
3. The offender has no right to appeal from an order of the presiding officer requiring the removal of the offender from the meeting room or village hall;
however, such an order may be appealed by a member of the village council present at the meeting. Any ruling by the presiding officer may be
overruled by a majority of the members of the village council present at such public meeting.
4. The offender removed from the meeting room or village hall shall be criminally charged for any violations of applicable law. (Ord. O-48-10, 10-25-
2010)
Chapter 5
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
1-5-1: APPLICABILITY OF CHAPTER:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all officials and employees of the village, regardless of the time of the creation of the office or position, or the
time of appointment. (Village code § 2-18)
1-5-2: ELECTIONS:
Elections for village officials shall be held at the time, and in the manner, provided for by statute. Voting precincts for conducting elections in the village,
shall be as established by ordinance or resolution. (Village code § 2-27)
1-5-3: APPOINTMENTS:
A. General: All officers, other than elective officers, shall be appointed by the village council as is provided by statute. Other employees shall be employed
in the manner provided by statute or ordinance.
B. Oath: Before assuming his duties, every officer shall take the oath provided by statute1. (Village code § 2-19)
C. Term Of Office: Every appointive officer shall hold office until May 1 following his appointment, or until his appointment, or until his successor is
appointed and qualified, unless otherwise provided by ordinance. Vacancies in an office shall be filled in the same manner as appointments are made.
(Village code § 2-20)
1-5-4: RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS:
A. Elective Office: A person is not eligible for any elective municipal office unless that person is a qualified elector of the municipality and has resided in the
village for at least one year preceding election. (Ord. O-6-99, 5-24-1999)
B. Appointive Office: No person shall be eligible for any appointive office except the village administrator and all department heads, including police chief,
administrative assistant to the police chief, fire chief, captain of the fire department, director of public health and safety, community center director, and
public works director, and those offices for which the law provides other residency requirements, unless that person is a qualified elector of the
municipality or otherwise provided by law. (Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
C. Applicable Residency Requirements:
1. All employees of the village shall be residents of the state of Illinois. (Ord. O-25-05, 6-13-2005)
2. The residency requirements provided herein shall not apply to the village engineer, attorney or any other officer who, in the opinion of the village
council, requires technical training, knowledge or experience.
3. The provisions of this section shall apply to all present officers of the village and to any persons elected or appointed by the village from and after the
effective date hereof. (Ord. O-6-99, 5-24-1999; amd. Ord. O-25-05, 6-13-2005)
1-5-5: COMPENSATION:
Officers and employees shall receive such salary as may be, from time to time, provided by ordinance or resolution. (Village code § 2-22)
1-5-6: INDEMNIFICATION OF CERTAIN OFFICIALS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 20/416
A. Officials Designated: The following officials and employees of the village shall be indemnified, defended and held harmless by the village from and
against all liabilities, expenses or investigation, judgments and amounts paid in settlement which may be imposed upon or reasonably incurred or paid
by such official or employee in connection with or resulting from any claim made against him, or any action, suit, proceeding or investigation in which
he may be involved, by reason of his being or having been such official or such employee of the village, whether or not he continues to be such official
or employee at the time of such claim, action, suit, proceeding or investigation:
Mayor
Each member of the village council (i.e., each commissioner)
Village clerk and collector and each deputy or acting village clerk or collector
Village treasurer and each deputy or acting village treasurer
Village attorney
Superintendents of village departments
Chief of police
Chief of the village fire department
Each member of any board or commission of the village established pursuant to applicable law or by ordinance of the village
B. Acts Not Indemnified: The foregoing indemnity shall not extend to any of the following:
1. Any liability or cost with respect to any matter as to which such official or employee is finally adjudged to be guilty of bad faith, actual malice or wilful
and wanton misconduct in the performance of his duties as such official or employee;
2. Any payment, expense or cost arising out of a settlement of a claim, action, suit or proceeding, unless: a) such settlement shall be approved by the
court having jurisdiction over such claim, action, suit or proceedings, with express knowledge of the existence of the indemnification provided hereby;
or b) such settlement shall have been made upon the written opinion, of independent legal counsel selected by the village council, to the effect that
there is no reasonable grounds for any finding of bad faith, actual malice or wilful and wanton misconduct on the part of such official or employee and
that the anticipated cost of such settlement will not substantially exceed the estimated cost and expense of defending such claim, action, suit or
proceeding to a final conclusion;
3. Any liability or judgment payable to the village itself;
4. The cost of independent legal representation in any such action, suit or proceeding if the village offers or otherwise indicates its willingness to
provide a legal defense with respect to such claim, action, suit, proceeding or investigation.
The foregoing rights of indemnification shall be in addition to any other rights to which such official or employee may otherwise be entitled as a
matter of law. (Ord. O-26-77, 11-14-1977)
1-5-7: TURN OVER MONIES:
All monies received by an officer in his official capacity shall be turned over to the village treasurer at least once a month, with a report showing the source
thereof. (Village Code § 2-21)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
1-5A-1: POSITION CREATED:
There is hereby created the position of village administrator. (Ord. O-37-03, 10-14-2003)
1-5A-2: APPOINTIVE PROVISIONS:
A. Bond: Prior to entering upon the duties of the position, the village administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) to be approved by the village council and conditioned on the faithful performance of the duties of the village administrator.
B. Compensation: The village administrator shall receive such compensation as established by contract, ordinance or resolution. (Ord. O-53-00, 12-18-
2000; amd. Ord. O-37-03, 10-14-2003)
1-5A-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Fiscal Matters: The village administrator shall have custody and control of all documents, including debts, mortgages, leases, contracts, judgment
orders, notes, bonds and evidences of indebtedness belonging to the village except such as are directed by law or ordinance to be deposited
elsewhere. The village administrator shall have supervision of the issuance and sale of all bonds, warrants and obligations, and shall have supervision
over the accounting work of the village.
Specifically, but not in limitation of the above, the village administrator shall have the following powers and duties:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 21/416
1. On or before May 31 of each year the village administrator or his designee shall submit to the corporate authorities a report of the amounts of money
necessary to defray the expenses of the village during the next fiscal year, and in said report classify and detail the purpose of the expenditures, the
aggregate income of the preceding fiscal year and the village liabilities and anticipated revenues.
For the purpose of preparing the aforesaid estimate, the village administrator or his designee is authorized to require all officers to submit statements
of the condition and expenses of their respective offices or departments, a description of proposed village improvements, and the probable expense
thereof, a description of all unperformed contracts and a statement of the amount of all unexpired appropriations of the preceding year.
2. The village administrator shall, after evaluating all necessary data, conferring with the finance director and consulting with the mayor and village
council, prepare and submit the annual appropriation and tax levy ordinances for passage by the village council. In conjunction with these
obligations, the village administrator shall utilize current available revenues and search out and recommend additional sources of revenue necessary
to operate the village.
