3. The village administrator shall recommend to the village council the salaries to be paid officers and employees of the village when requested by the
village council.
4. The village administrator shall, each month, cause to be prepared and shall present to the village council a statement showing the exact financial
position of the village and give such additional reports and information concerning the fiscal matters of the village as may from time to time be
required by the village council. (Ord. O-53-00, 12-18-2000)
5. Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-5-2, the village council hereby prescribes that the village administrator shall have the power and duty to
conduct collective bargaining on behalf of the village with village employees or their exclusive representatives; to designate the other members of the
village's collective bargaining negotiating teams; to enter into tentative agreements with the exclusive representatives of village employees regarding
the wages, hours and other terms and conditions of employment, subject to ratification by the village council; to report periodically to the village
council regarding the status of such collective bargaining; and to perform any other functions necessary to carry out such duties. (Ord. O-13-03, 4-
28-2003)
B. Village Administration: In addition to the above duties, the village administrator shall perform such other duties as are herein provided:
The village administrator shall be the chief administrative officer of the village and shall be responsible to the mayor and to the combined village council
for the administration and operation of all of the affairs and the departments of the village. As such administrative officer, and unless otherwise directed
by the village council, the village administrator shall have the administration and control of all matters and things pertaining to the operation and
maintenance of the properties of the village and of all departments of the village. He shall also have supervision of such other administrative agencies
and departments and officers as may be hereafter created by the village council, unless the administration and control of such departments and officers
is expressly delegated elsewhere. He shall perform his duties in conformity with the rules in the village. Specifically, but not in limitation of the above,
he shall have the following additional powers and duties:
1. Recommend to the mayor and village council the appointment of all officers of the village who are required by law to be appointed by the village
council and further recommend the removal or suspension of any such officer or employee when such removal or suspension shall be consistent
with the best interests of the village.
2. The village administrator shall make or cause to be made all necessary purchases of supplies and equipment for all departments of the village and,
for that purpose, the village administrator is authorized to make expenditures without approval from the village council that are consistent with the
purchasing ordinance of the village1; provided, however, that all expenditures and payments, regardless of the amount, shall be subject to the
confirmation or approval of the village council and to the limitations imposed by law, ordinance and/or budget or special appropriation, and pursuant
to chapter 8, article A of this title.
3. The village administrator shall attend all meetings of the village council unless excused therefrom by the village council, except when his removal is
under consideration by the village council. The village administrator shall have the privilege of taking part in the discussion of all matters coming
before the village council and shall be entitled to notice of all meetings, regular and special, of the village council when required.
4. The village administrator shall investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning village services and village administration.
5. The village administrator may, when requested by the commissioner in charge of a department, recommend the appointment and/or discharge of an
employee in such department with supporting information regarding the reason for such appointment and/or discharge, exclusive of employees and
officers of the police department and regular firefighters under the jurisdiction of the board of fire and police commissioners2.
6. The village administrator shall devote his entire time to the discharge of official duties.
7. The village administrator shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by the village council consistent with the statutes of the state of
Illinois and village ordinances.
8. Subject to final approval of the village council, the village administrator may consolidate, combine or reorganize any departments under his
jurisdiction. (Ord. O-53-00, 12-18-2000)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE CLERK
1-5B-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of village clerk, who shall be appointed by the village council1. (Ord. O-55-00, 12-18-2000)
1-5B-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
A. Bond And Oath: The village clerk shall, before entering upon his duties, take oath and execute a bond with surety in an amount as shall be determined
by the village council. (Village Code § 1-25)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 22/416
B. Compensation: The village clerk shall receive such compensation for his service as the village council shall, from time to time, determine. (Village Code
§ 1-27)
1-5B-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village clerk shall perform the following duties:
A. Issue notices to the members of the village council when directed to do so by that body; also to the members of the various committees and those
whose presence is required before any committee when directed or requested to do so by the chair of said committee; and have duly delivered to the
officers of the village resolutions and communications referred to such officers.
B. Keep the corporate seal of the village2 and all papers belonging to the village; and receive all petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or other
communications addressed to the village council or to the mayor and village council and shall read them at the meeting of the village council next
succeeding their receipt by him, unless otherwise ordered by the village council. All books, records and other documents of the village, under the
control or jurisdiction of the village clerk, collector and comptroller, shall be kept by him in the municipal offices of the village.
C. Attend all meetings of the village council and keep a full record of all its proceedings in the journal.
D. Record, in a book to be kept for that purpose, all ordinances passed by the village council and, at the foot of the record of each ordinance so recorded,
shall make a memorandum of the date of its passage and of the publication and posting of such ordinance.
E. Make all required preparations for the holding of village elections; and within five (5) days after any election is declared or appointment made, notify all
persons elected or appointed to any village office of their election or appointment and shall execute with the mayor and deliver commissions to each
person elected to a village office as prescribed by law.
F. File with the county clerk of Cook County each year immediately after its passage, the annual tax levy ordinance.
G. Perform such other additional duties as now or hereafter may be prescribed by the ordinances of the village and by the statutes of the state. (Ord. O-
55-00, 12-18-2000)
1-5B-4: DEPUTY VILLAGE CLERK:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created the office of deputy village clerk, who shall discharge the functions and duties of the office of municipal clerk, as
directed by the village clerk. (Ord. O-45-05, 9-26-2005)
B. Appointment: The deputy village clerk shall be appointed by the village clerk, and before entering upon the duties of his office, shall give a surety bond
in such amount as the village council shall require. He shall hold office at the pleasure of the village clerk. (Village Code § 1-29)
C. Compensation: The deputy village clerk shall receive such compensation as the village council shall determine. (Village Code § 1-30)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE TREASURER
1-5C-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of village treasurer who shall be appointed by the village council1. (Village Code § 1-31)
1-5C-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
A. Bond And Oath: The village treasurer shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take oath and execute a bond to the village in such amount as
may be determined by the village council in accordance with state law2. (Village Code § 1-32)
B. Compensation: The village treasurer shall receive as compensation such sum as shall be determined by the village council. (Village Code § 1-40)
1-5C-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Receive Monies: It shall be the duty of the village treasurer to receive all monies and to exercise all powers and duties as prescribed by state law.
(Village Code § 1-33)
B. Accounts: The village treasurer shall keep a true and accurate account of monies paid into the treasury, and from and on what account received. He
shall keep a separate account of each fund or appropriation, and shall keep a distinct account of all special assessments, and in making report to the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 23/416
mayor and village council shall make separate and specific report of the same. He shall keep a register of all warrants redeemed and paid, which shall
describe such warrants and show the date, amount, number, the fund from which paid, the name of the person to whom and when paid; and his books
and accounts shall, at all times, be subject to the inspection of any member of the village council or other officer of the village. (Village Code § 1-34)
C. Pay Warrants: The village treasurer shall pay all warrants or orders presented to him properly drawn and signed by the mayor and countersigned by the
village clerk and commissioner of accounts and finances when he shall have the necessary funds to pay the same, and he shall make no distinction,
nor give any preference to any person in paying such warrants. He shall keep all monies belonging to the village in his hands, separate and distinct
from his own monies, and he is hereby expressly prohibited from using either directly or indirectly, the village money or warrants in his custody or
keeping for his own benefit, or that of any other person or persons whomsoever; and any violation of this provision shall subject him to immediate
removal from office by the village council and such removal shall be entered upon its records, and his successor shall immediately be appointed by the
village council by a vote of a majority of all its members authorized by law to be elected, to be taken by yeas and nays, and entered upon its records,
and such successor shall hold his office for the remainder of the term unexpired of such officer so removed. (Village Code § 1-35)
D. Special Assessments: All monies received on any special assessment shall be held by the treasurer as a special fund to be applied to the payment of
the improvement for which the assessment was made, and said money shall be used for no other purpose whatever, unless to reimburse said village
for money expended for such improvement. (Village Code § 1-36)
1-5C-4: REPORTS AND RECORDS:
A. Monthly Account: The village treasurer shall, at the end of each and every month, render an account to the village council showing the state of the
treasury at that date of each account and the balance of money in the treasury. He shall also accompany such accounts with a statement of all monies
received into the treasury, and on what account, together with all warrants redeemed and paid by him, which said warrants, with any and all vouchers
held by him, shall be delivered to the village clerk and filed with his accounts in the village clerk's office upon every such day of settlement, with any
and all vouchers paid by him stamped or marked "paid". He shall also report to the village council, at such other times as he may be required, a full and
detailed account of all receipts and expenditures of the village as shown by his books at the time of said report. (Village Code § 1-37)
B. Annual Report: He shall annually, within thirty (30) days after the close of each fiscal year, make out and file with the village clerk a full and detailed
statement of all receipts and expenditures, and of all his transactions as such village treasurer during the preceding fiscal year and shall disclose in
such account the state of the treasury at the fiscal year, which account the village clerk shall immediately cause to be published in a newspaper of
general circulation in the village, if there be one, and if not, by posting in a public place in the village clerk's office. (Village Code § 1-38; amd. 2004
Code)
C. Records: He shall keep and record all files of his office at such places as may be designated by the village council, which shall at all times be open to
the inspection of the mayor, village clerk and be subject to such other rules and regulations, as the village council may from time to time direct. (Village
Code § 1-39)
ARTICLE D. LEGAL OFFICERS
1-5D-1: VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
A. Bond: The village attorney shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, execute a bond to the village in the sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) with sureties, to be approved by the village council, conditioned as required by law. (Village Code § 1-41)
B. Compensation: The village attorney shall receive, as compensation for his services, a salary as set by the village council from time to time. In addition to
the foregoing, the village attorney shall also receive, as additional compensation, such reasonable amounts as shall be determined and approved by
the council from time to time for the handling of other extraordinary legal matters, including court litigation. (Village Code § 1-44; amd. 2004 Code)
C. Powers And Duties: The village attorney shall superintend and conduct all the law business of the village. He shall draft such ordinances, leases,
deeds, papers, contracts and other such instruments as may be required in the business of the village. He shall furnish written opinions on subjects
submitted to him by the village council or the mayor when requested, on all legal questions arising in the conduct of the business of the village. (Village
Code § 1-42)
1-5D-2: VILLAGE PROSECUTOR:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor for the village. The village council, by a majority vote, is hereby authorized to
appoint the village prosecutor for the village.
B. Duties: The village prosecutor shall have charge of prosecuting all violations of village ordinances, and violations of the Illinois vehicle code, unless
otherwise prohibited by law, and the village prosecutor shall cooperate with the various village departments and officers, as required, in carrying out the
functions specified in this subsection. (Ord. O-26-03, 7-14-2003)
ARTICLE E. OTHER VILLAGE OFFICIALS
1-5E-1: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 24/416
A. Position Created: There is hereby created the position of director of public health and safety.
B. Duties: The director of public health and safety is responsible for the operations of the code hearing department. The director of public health and
safety's responsibilities shall include conducting plan reviews, performing inspections, enforcing the village's building codes, ensuring compliance with
all construction activity including, but not limited to, new construction, alterations, additions, demolition and various other improvements. Additional
responsibilities include supervising department staff, assistance with the enforcement of village zoning, property maintenance, health inspections, and
village ordinances as they relate to residential, commercial, industrial and public property. The director of public health and safety will be the conduit for
community development.
C. Accountability: The director of public health and safety shall be responsible to the commissioner of public health and safety. (Ord. O-24-05, 6-13-2005;
amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
1-5E-2: VILLAGE ENGINEER:
A. Office Created: There is hereby established the office of village engineer who shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the commissioner of streets
and public improvements and who shall be appointed by the village council.
B. Compensation: The village engineer shall receive such compensation as the village council shall from time to time determine.
C. Duties: The village engineer shall have charge of all engineering matters and prepare maps, plans and specifications for all construction work or
improvements including the laying of mains and water supply pipes and when authorized, shall have charge of the construction and repair of all
improvement projects. In addition to the foregoing he shall perform such duties as may be required of him by the village council and the ordinances of
the village. (Ord. O-5-63, 5-13-1963; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
1-5E-3: FINANCE DIRECTOR-COMPTROLLER:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created the office of finance director who shall also serve as comptroller. Any future references to finance director shall
include comptroller.
B. Compensation: The finance director shall receive such salary as shall be determined by the village council.
C. Duties:
1. The finance director shall keep in his office, in books used solely for that purpose, a correct list of all the outstanding bonds of the village, showing
the number and amount of each and for and to whom the bonds were issued. When bonds are purchased, paid or canceled, these books shall show
these additional facts. In the finance director's annual report, he shall particularly describe the bonds sold during the year and the terms of sale, with
every item of expense incurred in connection with the bonds.
2. The finance director shall exercise a general supervision over all the officers of the village, with the exception of the village administrator, charged in
any manner with the receipt, collection or disbursement of the municipal revenue, or with the collection and return of the municipal revenue, or
collection and return of the municipal revenue into the village treasury.
3. The finance director shall have custody and control of all municipal documents, books and papers designated by the corporate authorities.
4. On or before May 15 of each year, and before the annual appropriation ordinance is prepared by the corporate authorities, the finance director shall
submit to the village administrator and corporate authorities a report of the director's estimate, as nearly as may be, of the money necessary to
defray the expenses of the village during the current fiscal year. For the purpose of making this report, the director is authorized to require all officers
to submit statements of the condition and expenses of their respective offices or departments, with any proposed municipal improvements and the
probable expense of those improvements, all unperformed contracts and the amount of all unexpended appropriations of the preceding year.
In this report, the comptroller shall:
a. Classify the different objects and purposes of expenditure, giving, as nearly as may be, the amount required for each;
b. Show the aggregate income for each from the previous fiscal year;
c. Show the amount of liabilities upon which interest is to be paid;
d. Show the bonds and debts payable during the year, when due and payable; and
e. Give all other information to the corporate authorities, and the village administrator that the director deems necessary, so that the corporate
authorities and village administrator may fully understand the demands upon the village for the current fiscal year.
5. Prepare a statement of investments showing all investment activity of the previous year and interest earned.
6. When required by the village administrator or corporate authorities, assist with future investments and investment activity.
7. In addition to the foregoing, the finance director shall, when requested, exercise such duties relating to the financial affairs and conditions of the
village as may be necessary. (Ord. O-54-00, 12-18-2000; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
D. Budget Director: There is hereby created the position of budget director, who shall also serve as the director of finance, and shall receive such salary as
shall be determined by the village council.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 25/416
E. Assistant Budget Director:
1. Office Created: There is hereby created the position of assistant budget director who shall be appointed by the village council. (Ord. O-37-03, 10-14-
2003; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
2. Compensation: The assistant budget director shall receive such compensation as shall be determined from time to time by the village council.
3. Duties: The assistant budget director shall perform the duties delegated to the budget director and assist the budget director whenever necessary.
The assistant budget director shall also perform such duties as may be delegated by the village clerk and comptroller and the budget director. (Ord.
O-9-80, 6-9-1980; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
1-5E-4: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
A. Position Created: There is hereby created the position of director of public works.
B. Duties:
1. The director of public works shall supervise all employees of the department of public property and in that capacity shall be responsible for the
operation and maintenance of all public property, including, but not limited to, utilities, sidewalks, playgrounds, municipal buildings, forestry and all
public property, and shall be responsible for the supervision of employees under the control of the commissioner of public property, when those
employees are performing such duties.
2. The director of public works shall also supervise all employees of the department of streets and public improvements and in that capacity shall be
responsible for the operation and maintenance of all public improvements, including, but not limited to, curbs, gutters, garbage and rubbish removal,
streets, alleys, manholes and catch basins and shall be responsible for the supervision of the employees under the control of the commissioner of
streets and public improvements, when those employees are performing such duties.
C. Accountability: The director of public works shall be responsible to the commissioner of public property, in relation to those duties described in
subsection B1 of this section. The director of public works shall be responsible to the commissioner of streets and public improvements, in relation to
those duties described in subsection B2 of this section. (Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
1-5E-5: YOUTH AND SENIOR CITIZENS COORDINATOR:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created the position of coordinator of youth and senior citizens activities for the village, who shall be appointed by the
village council.
B. Compensation: The coordinator of youth and senior citizens activities shall receive such compensation as the village council shall designate.
C. Duties: The coordinator of youth and senior citizens activities shall be in charge of all senior citizens and youth activities in the village and be
responsible for the establishment of programs designed to enhance and improve the lives of the senior citizens and youth in the village. In this regard,
the coordinator shall be directly responsible and account to the mayor, department of public affairs. (Ord. O-8-74, 8-10-1974; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-
2010)
1-5E-6: RISK MANAGEMENT COORDINATOR:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created the position of risk management coordinator for the village, who shall be appointed by the village council who
shall prescribe the amount of time to be devoted to the duties of the coordinator and the compensation attached to the position.
B. Duties: The risk management coordinator shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
1. Responsibility for the coordination and/or administration of programs in the following areas: accident prevention, fire protection, security, emergency
control, industrial hygiene and first aid functions.
2. Implement Illinois municipal league risk management association (IMLRMA) procedures to ensure that supervisors observe for unsafe acts and
conditions and initiate corrective action before accidents happen.
3. Participate in accident investigation. This is to be done when unusual and disabling injury accidents occur or at any time any supervisor requests an
investigation in conjunction with his own investigation. Follow up is to be made on all investigations to see if corrective action eliminates the unsafe
act or condition.
4. Periodically develop internal analysis of accidents as to types, causes, severity and all other factors from experience, which can serve as a guide for
supervision in accident prevention; the risk management association (RMA) and analysis profile can be used as a basis.
5. Occasional inspection of job procedures and equipment to determine need for safeguards and the study of requirements for personal protective
equipment and make appropriate recommendations when applicable.
6. Periodic inspection of safety equipment or coordination of municipal supervisor's inspection program.
7. Participate in safety and health education and training with IMLRMA loss control personnel.
8. Keep abreast of current developments in the field and provide information and advise periodically and as requested by supervision.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 26/416
9. Participate in the inspection of plant premises and equipment for safety and health when applicable.
10. Maintain regular contact with IMLRMA loss control personnel, and act as the municipality's primary liaison within the municipal league's overall loss
control and risk management program.
11. Make job studies of new processes to develop data regarding hazards and keep the various supervisors informed.
12. Coordinate activities of the first aid personnel and services.
13. Participate in the administration of workers' compensation claims activities and act as primary liaison with claims service company personnel.
14. Attend periodic regional loss control training sessions provided by the RMA loss control specialist and apply knowledge gained.
15. Such other duties and responsibilities in the field of safety as the village council shall from time to time determine.
16. Submit periodic reports of his activities, results and recommendations in the area of the coordinator's responsibility to the village council. (Ord. O-
14-83, 12-19-1983; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
Chapter 6
VILLAGE DEPARTMENTS
ARTICLE A. FIRE DEPARTMENT
1-6A-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED; MEMBERS:
A. General: There is hereby created a fire department, an executive department of the village, which shall consist of one fire chief, one captain, three (3)
lieutenants and such other firefighters as provided by the village council, who shall receive such compensation as the village council shall determine by
ordinance or resolution.
B. Firefighter/Paramedic Positions: The position of firefighter/paramedic is hereby created in the fire department. Effective July 1, 2000, and as a condition
of employment, all new firefighters employed by the Forest Park fire department shall be licensed paramedics by the Illinois department of public health
and certified to function in the emergency medical system under which the Forest Park fire department operates. All firefighters hired after July 1, 2000,
shall maintain their paramedic license and certification as a condition of continued employment. (Ord. O-21-04, 5-10-2004)
1-6A-2: FIRE CHIEF:
A. Appointment; Bond: The fire chief shall be appointed by the village council and shall be in charge of the fire department. Before entering upon the duties
of his office, he shall execute a bond to the village in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with such sureties as the village council shall
approve, conditioned as the law prescribes. (Village Code § 3-2)
B. Duties:
1. General: The fire chief shall have sole control and command over all persons connected with the fire department of the village, while on duty and
shall possess full power and authority over its organization and discipline and, to that end, he may prescribe and establish, from time to time, such
lawful rules and regulations as he may deem advisable, subject to the approval of the village council. (Village Code § 3-3)
2. Custodian Of Property: The fire chief shall have the custody of all the public property of the fire department, subject to the supervision of the
commissioner of accounts and finances and whenever any of the apparatus shall require to be repaired, cause the same to be repaired. (Village
Code § 3-4)
C. Reports: The fire chief shall, on or before the fourth Monday in every month, make out in writing over his signature, and hand to the commissioner of
accounts and finances, a payroll containing the names of all the officers and members of the fire department and the amount due to each of them set
opposite his name, which report shall be verified, by oath of the fire chief, before the village clerk or any notary public. Upon being satisfied with the
correctness of such payroll, said commissioner shall audit the same. Included in each monthly report shall be stated, in detail, the number of fires
attended, the date of each, its cause, as nearly as can be ascertained, the probable amount of damage, insurance, if any, and all other information
relating thereto. (Village Code § 3-7)
1-6A-3: FIRE DEPARTMENT BOARD:
A. Board Created: Pursuant to the provisions contained in the Illinois Compiled Statutes, there shall be elected, by ballot, from the active firefighters of the
village, three (3) firefighters to constitute a board to be known as the fire department board of the village. Said board shall designate one of their
number as president another as secretary and a third as treasurer. Provided, however, that in lieu of appointing a treasurer, the village treasurer shall
be the treasurer of said board. In the event that a person, other than the village treasurer, is appointed treasurer, he shall give sufficient bond to the
village, which bond shall be approved by the village council, conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of the duties of his said office,
as required by law.
In the event of the failure, resignation or inability to act of any member of said board elected under the provisions of this section, the successor to such
member shall be elected at an election which shall be called by said board. Each member shall hold his office until his successor is duly appointed and
qualified. (Village code § 3-8)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 27/416
B. Rules And Regulations: Said fire department board of the village shall make all rules and regulations with respect to the department, and the
management of the money to be paid to the treasurer. The village treasurer shall pay to the treasurer of the fire department, or shall set aside, all sums
received by the village from foreign fire insurance companies as provided by law1; and all said monies so received from foreign fire insurance
companies shall be paid out upon the order of the fire department board, for the use, maintenance and benefit of the department specifically related to
equipment for the safety and/or protection of the members of the fire department. (Ord. O-21-89, 12-27-1989)
1-6A-4: FIRE INSPECTION BUREAU:
A. Bureau Created; Members: There is hereby created a fire inspection bureau for the village consisting of the fire chief and a deputy fire inspector who
shall not be a member of the regular fire department. The fire inspector shall be appointed by the village council at a salary to be determined by the
village council. The fire chief shall be in charge of the fire inspection bureau and its personnel.
B. Duties:
1. General: The fire inspection bureau and its personnel shall be and are hereby empowered to enter any building, structure or premises whether the
same is completed, occupied, uncompleted or unoccupied to determine whether such buildings, structures or premises are or have been
constructed, maintained or occupied in accordance with the applicable ordinances, statutes and laws of the village and the state of Illinois.
2. Other Inspections: This chapter shall not limit or prohibit the fire chief from detailing regular fire department personnel to make such additional fire
inspections as may be deemed necessary. (Ord. O-24-71, 12-27-1971)
1-6A-5: SPECIAL FIREFIGHTERS:
The village council shall have the power to appoint special firefighters to supplement the regular department, in the event of emergency, disaster or when
such necessity exists. Special firefighters shall be subject to such rules and regulations as shall be prescribed by the fire chief; and orders, ordinances and
resolutions of the village council. (Village code § 3-6)
1-6A-6: PENSION FUND:
A. Fund Established: There is established a firefighters' pension fund under, and in accordance with, the provisions of the laws of the state of Illinois2; and
there shall be set apart, to constitute such fund, the monies as specified in said act. (Village code §§ 3-10, 3-11)
B. Board Of Trustees:
1. Created: A board composed of five (5) members shall constitute a board of trustees to administer the pension fund and to designate beneficiaries
thereof. Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor. Two (2) members of the board shall be active participants of the pension
fund who are elected from the active participants of the fund. One member of the board shall be a person who is elected by and from the
beneficiaries of the fund. Each member of the board so elected shall hold office for a term of three (3) years and until his or her successor has been
duly elected and qualified. The members appointed by the mayor shall hold office for alternate terms of two (2) years, and until his or her successor
has been duly appointed and qualified. (Ord. O-25-08, 6-9-2008)
2. Powers And Duties:
a. The said board shall have the exclusive control and management of the fund created in the manner provided by the statutes of the state of Illinois,
and shall see to the assessment and collection of monies as provided by law.
b. The board of trustees shall make all needful rules and regulations, for the discharge of its duties; and shall hear and decide all applications for
relief or pensions, under the provisions of the applicable statutes.
c. The board shall have the power to provide for the payment, from said fund, of all monies which may be necessary for the expenses of the board.
d. The board shall cause to be kept a record of all its proceedings and meetings. (Village code § 3-13)
ARTICLE B. POLICE DEPARTMENT
1-6B-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED; MEMBERS:
There is hereby established a police department for the village, which shall consist of the chief of police, one deputy chief, three (3) lieutenants, seven (7)
sergeants, and such number of police officers as the village council shall from time to time prescribe. Members of the police department shall receive such
compensation as the village council shall determine by ordinance or resolution. (Ord. O-05-16, 3-28-2016)
1-6B-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
A. Appointment; Bond: The chief of police shall be appointed by the village council and shall be in charge of said police department. Before entering upon
the duties of his office, he shall execute a bond to the village in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), with such sureties as the village council
shall approve, conditioned as the law prescribes. (Village code § 4-2)
B. Duties:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 28/416
1. The chief shall have general supervision of the administration of the police department, and its officers and members, and shall have custody, care
and control of the public property of the police department, subject to the directions of the village council; and of all firearms and other equipment; the
books and records of said police department. He shall devote his whole time to the affairs of said village in preserving the peace, safety, order and
cleanliness thereof. He shall be charged with the duty of protecting the rights of persons and property, and shall cause to be enforced all ordinances
of the village. (Village code § 4-3)
2. The chief of police shall be, and is hereby designated as, the custodian of lost, abandoned or stolen property. (Village code § 4-6)
1-6B-3: DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE:
There is hereby created the position of deputy chief, to be appointed by the chief of the police department. The deputy chief position shall be an exempt
rank immediately below that of the chief. The deputy chief may be appointed from any rank of sworn, full time officers of the village police department, but
must have at least five (5) years of full time service as a police officer in that department. The deputy chief shall serve at the discretion of the chief and, if
removed from that position by the chief, shall revert to the rank immediately held prior to appointment to the deputy chief position. The provisions of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-17 regarding the discharge or suspension of a member of the department shall be applicable to the position of deputy
chief of police. (Ord. O-62-02, 12-23-2002)
1-6B-4: POLICE OFFICER REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATIONS:
A. Appointments: Police officers shall be appointed in the manner provided by statute and shall be subject to such rules and regulations as shall be
prescribed from time to time by the village council and the board of fire and police commissioners. (Ord. O-12-86, 8-11-1986)
B. Duties: It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to enforce the laws of the nation, state and ordinances of the village and to preserve
order and peace and to arrest violators of said laws and ordinances. (Ord. O-12-86, 8-11-1986; amd. Ord. O-25-05, 6-13-2005)
1-6B-5: SPECIAL POLICE:
The mayor may appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the village council, any additional number of special police to do special duty at any fixed
place within the village. Persons so appointed shall be subject to all rules and regulations governing the police force of said village, and to such special
rules and regulations as the chief of police may make concerning such special police. They shall possess all the powers and privileges, in connection with
the performances of their special duties, of regular police officers. (Village code § 4-5)
1-6B-6: AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE:
A. Authority; Appointments:
1. The commissioner of the department to which the powers and duties of the police department are assigned is hereby authorized to appoint auxiliary
police officers as employees of the village. Prior to appointment, all proposed auxiliary police shall be fingerprinted and their fingerprints shall be
checked with the federal bureau of investigation for any possible criminal record. No person shall be appointed as an auxiliary police officer if he has
been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude. Auxiliary police officers may be terminated by the commissioner of the
department to which the powers and duties of the police department are assigned. (Ord. O-10-06, 2-13-2006)
2. Such auxiliary police shall not be members of the regular police department of the village. Auxiliary police need not be residents of the village.
Identification symbols worn by such auxiliary police shall be different and distinct from those used by the regular police department and shall be
selected and chosen by the chief of police of the village. Auxiliary police shall at all times during the performance of their duties be subject to the
direction and control of the chief of police of the village. (Ord. O-50-68, 12-21-1968)
B. Powers And Duties: Auxiliary police shall have the following powers and duties, when properly assigned and on duty:
1. To aid or direct traffic in the municipality.
2. To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters.
3. To aid in case of civil disorder.
4. To perform normal and regular police duties when assigned by the chief of police on occasions when it is impracticable for members of the regular
police department to perform normal and regular police duties.
5. If necessary, to detain arrested persons in custody overnight or on Sunday in any safe place or until they can be brought before the proper
magistrate.
6. To serve and execute all warrants for the violation of municipal ordinances, or the state criminal laws within the limits of the village, and for this
purpose to have all the common law and statutory power of sheriffs. (Ord. O-20-07, 5-30-2007)
C. Firearms: Auxiliary police shall not carry firearms except with the permission of the chief of police of the village and then only when in uniform and in the
performance of their duties.
D. Training: Auxiliary police, prior to entering upon any of their duties, shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police procedures
by the chief of police of the village. Such course of training shall be not less than the required hours in duration. Upon completion of the course of
training, the chief of police shall file a certificate attesting to the auxiliary police officer's completion of said course, with the village clerk. (Ord. O-50-68,
12-21-1968)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 29/416
1-6B-7: POLICE PENSION FUND:
A. Fund Established: There is hereby established a police pension fund under, and in accordance with, the provisions of the statutes of the state of
Illinois1; and there is hereby set apart, to constitute such fund, the monies as specified by statute. (Village code §§ 4-7, 4-8)
B. Board Of Trustees:
1. A board composed of five (5) members shall constitute a board of trustees to administer the pension fund and to designate the beneficiaries thereof.
Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor. The third and fourth members of the board shall be elected from the active
participants of the pension fund by such active participants. The fifth member shall be elected by and from the beneficiaries of the fund. The elected
members of the fund shall hold office for a term of two (2) years until his or her successor has been duly elected and qualified. The members
appointed by the mayor shall hold office for alternative terms of two (2) years and until his or her successor has been duly appointed and qualified.
(Ord. O-25-08, 6-9-2008)
2. Trustees shall be selected and fulfill their duties, and serve their tenure of office in accordance with the statutes of Illinois. (Village code §§ 4-9, 4-10)
C. Meetings: Suitable rooms for offices and meetings of such board shall be assigned by the village council. (Village code § 4-11)
1-6B-8: PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
A. A "part time police officer", when used herein, shall be defined to mean a member of the Forest Park police department who is employed by the village
of Forest Park for less than one thousand five hundred sixty (1,560) hours in any twelve (12) month period beginning on January 1 of any calendar year
and subject to the training requirements for a part time police officer as may be promulgated by the Illinois law enforcement training standards board.
(Ord. O-58-05, 11-14-2005)
B. Part time police officers shall be appointed by the commissioner of public affairs, pursuant to the provisions of section 4-5-6 of the Illinois municipal
code2. (Ord. O-2-06, 1-9-2006)
C. The council of the village of Forest Park is hereby vested with the authority to control and limit the number of part time police officers, to establish the
salary for part time police officers and to determine the total number of hours to be worked by all part time police officers. (Ord. O-58-05, 11-14-2005)
D. All part time police officers shall be deemed at will employees of the village, and their employment terminated or their hours of employment decreased
by the commissioner of public affairs, when in his judgment the efficient conduct of municipal affairs so demands. (Ord. O-2-06, 1-9-2006)
E. All part time police officers hired under the provisions of this section shall be at least twenty one (21) years of age and under thirty five (35) years of
age, shall possess a high school diploma or an equivalent high school education, and shall complete the training required of part time police officers
established by the Illinois law enforcement training standards board. The foregoing age limitation does not apply to any person previously employed as
a policeman in a regularly constituted police department of any municipality or to any person who has served as an auxiliary policeman pursuant to 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-30-20 for at least five (5) years and is under forty (40) years of age. No person shall be hired as a part time police
officer unless he or she is a person of good character and not a habitual drunkard, gambler, or person who has been convicted of a felony or crime
involving moral turpitude.
F. The hiring standards for part time police officers, as set forth in subsection E of this section, shall be submitted by the chief of police to the Illinois law
enforcement training standards board.
G. Part time police officers shall be deployed in accordance with the provisions of any collective bargaining agreement which addresses such deployment.
H. No part time police officer employed pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be subject to any of the provisions contained in section 10-2.1-1 et
seq., of the Illinois municipal code3, and the provisions contained therein for the hiring of full time police officers, discipline of full time police officers
and termination of full time police officers shall not apply to part time police officers hired under the provisions of this section. (Ord. O-58-05, 11-14-
2005)
ARTICLE C. DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC PROPERTY
1-6C-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED; MEMBERS; DUTIES:
There is hereby established a department of public property for the village, which shall consist of such number of employees as the village council shall
from time to time prescribe, and who shall be under the supervision of the commissioner of public property. The members of the department of public
property shall perform the duties described in section 1-4-3-5 of this title or as otherwise provided by the village council. (Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004)
ARTICLE D. CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT
1-6D-1: PURPOSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 30/416
The purpose of this article is to provide for fair and efficient enforcement of certain village ordinances as may be allowed by law and directed by ordinance,
through an administrative adjudication of violations and establishing a schedule of fines and penalties, and authority and procedures for collection of
unpaid fines and penalties1. (Ord. O-19-99, 6-28-1999; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
1-6D-2: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby established a municipal department to be known as the Forest Park code hearing department, to have the power to enforce compliance
with such municipal ordinances as from time to time may be authorized by the village council and permitted by law. The establishment of the code hearing
department does not preclude the mayor and village council from using any other method to enforce ordinances of the village. (Ord. O-19-99, 6-28-1999;
amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
1-6D-3: ADMINISTRATIVE COMPOSITION:
The code hearing department shall be composed of a hearing officer, an ordinance enforcement administrator, system coordinator/computer operator and
hearing room security personnel, with the powers and authority as hereinafter set forth.
The commissioner in charge of health and safety, with the approval of the entire village council, is hereby authorized to appoint persons to hold the
positions set forth in this section. Other than the hearing officer, one person may hold and fulfill the requirements of one or more of the above stated
positions and compensation for each of the above stated positions shall be as approved by the village council.
A. Hearing Officer: The hearing officer shall preside over all adjudicatory hearings and shall have the following powers and duties:
1. Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the existence of the code violation;
2. Issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant testimony at the hearing, upon the request of the parties or their representatives;
3. Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;
4. Issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a code violation exists; and
5. Impose penalties, sanctions or such other relief consistent with applicable code provisions and assess costs upon finding a party liable for the
charged violation, except however, that in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to impose a penalty of incarceration.
B. Ordinance Enforcement Administrator: The ordinance enforcement administrator is authorized and directed to:
1. Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of any ordinance violation as may be permitted by law and directed by ordinance.
2. Adopt, distribute and process all notices as may be required under this article or as may reasonably be required to carry out the purpose of this
article.
3. Collect monies paid as fines and/or penalties assessed after a final determination of liability.
4. Certify copies of final determinations of an ordinance violation adjudicated pursuant to this article, and any factual reports verifying the final
determination of any violation liability which is issued in accordance with this article and the laws of the state of Illinois.
5. Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and maintain the administrative adjudication system hereby created.
6. Collect unpaid fines and penalties through private collection agencies and pursuit of all postjudgment remedies available by current law.
C. System Coordinator/Computer Operator: The system coordinator/computer operator is hereby authorized and directed to operate and maintain the
computer programs for the administrative adjudication system of the code hearing department hereby created on a day to day basis, including, but not
limited to:
1. Input of violation notice information.
2. Establish hearing dates and notice dates.
3. Record fine and penalty assessments and payments.
4. Issue payment receipts.
5. Issue succeeding notice of hearing dates and/or final determination of liability; issue notice of immobilization; issue notice of impending
impoundment; issue notice of impending driver's license suspension, as directed by the ordinance enforcement administrator in accordance with the
provisions hereinafter set forth.
6. Keep accurate records of appearances and nonappearances at administrative hearings, pleas entered, judgments entered, sanctions imposed, if
any, fines and penalties assessed and paid.
D. Hearing Room Security Personnel: The hearing room security personnel shall be qualified off duty, full time, part time or auxiliary police officers who are
hereby authorized and directed to:
1. Maintain hearing room decorum.
2. Have and execute authority as is granted to courtroom deputies of the circuit court.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 31/416
3. Perform such other duties or acts as may reasonably be required and directed by the hearing officer or ordinance enforcement administrator. (Ord.
O-19-99, 6-28-1999; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
ARTICLE E. DEPARTMENT OF STREETS AND PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS
1-6E-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED; MEMBERS; DUTIES:
There is hereby established a department of streets and public improvements for the village, which shall consist of such number of employees as the
village council shall from time to time prescribe, and who shall be under the supervision of the commissioner of streets and public improvements. The
members of the department of streets and public improvements shall perform the duties described in section 1-4-3-4 of this title or as otherwise provided
by the village council. (Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
Chapter 7
ETHICS
1-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall be given these definitions:
CAMPAIGN FOR ELECTIVE OFFICE: Any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination, election or appointment of any
individual to any federal, state or local public office or office in a political organization, or the selection, nomination or election of presidential or vice
presidential electors, but does not include activities: a) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative or administrative action; b) relating
to collective bargaining; or c) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
CANDIDATE: A person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a
vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in the election code1.
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in the Illinois public labor relations act2.
COMPENSATED TIME: With respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time
requirement imposed as a condition of his employment, but for purposes of this chapter, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods,
personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are
not fixed, "compensated time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the control of the employer and any other time when the
officer or employee is executing his official duties, regardless of location.
COMPENSATORY TIME OFF: Authorized time off earned by or awardedto an employee to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of
the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of his employment.
CONTRIBUTION: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in the election code3.
EMPLOYEE: A person employed by the village, whether on a full time or part time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the direction
and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor.
EMPLOYER: The village of Forest Park.
GIFT: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not
limited to, cash, food and drink and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of an
officer or employee.
LEAVE OF ABSENCE: Any period during which an employee does not receive: a) compensation for employment; b) service credit towards pension
benefits; and c) health insurance benefits paid for by the employer.
OFFICER: A person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for
service in his official capacity.
POLITICAL ACTIVITY: Any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include
activities: a) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative or administrative action; b) relating to collective bargaining; or c) that are
otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
POLITICAL ORGANIZATION: A party, committee, association, fund or other organization, whether or not incorporated, that is required to file a statement
of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under the election code4, but only with regard to those activities that require filing with the
state board of elections or a county clerk.
PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITY: A. Preparing for, organizing or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration or other
political event.
B. Soliciting contributions including, but not limited to, the purchase of, selling, distributingor receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser,
political meeting or other political event.
C. Soliciting, planning the solicitation of or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value or intended as a campaign contribution.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 32/416
D. Planning, conducting or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization
for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
E. Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign
for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
F. Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question.
G. Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort
to get voters to the polls.
H. Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any
referendum question.
I. Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office.
J. Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires.
K. Distributing, preparing for distribution or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for
elective office or for or against any referendum question.
L. Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question.
M. Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question.
N. Serving as a delegate, alternate or proxy to a political party convention.
O. Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election.
PROHIBITED SOURCE: Any person or entity who:
A. Is seeking official action: 1) by an officer; or 2) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee;
B. Does business or seeks to do business: 1) with the officer; or 2) with an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee;
C. Conducts activities regulated: 1) by the officer; or 2) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or
D. Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or nonperformance of the official duties of the officer or employee. (Ord. O-20-
04, 5-10-2004)
1-7-2: PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES:
A. No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited political activity during any "compensated time", as defined herein. No officer or
employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the village in connection with any prohibited political activity.
B. At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require another officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity: 1) as part of that
officer's or employee's duties; 2) as a condition of employment; or 3) during any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal time off).
C. No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee being
awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or
otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit in consideration for his participation in any prohibited
political activity.
D. Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for an officer or employee to engage in as part of his official duties, or activities that are
undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis which are not prohibited by this chapter.
E. No person either: 1) in a position that is subject to recognized merit principles of public employment; or 2) in a position the salary for which is paid in
whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant in aid
programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely because he is a member or an officer of a political committee, of a political party
or of a political organization or club. (Ord. O-20-04, 5-10-2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 33/416
1-7-3: GIFT BAN:
A. Prohibitions: Except as otherwise permitted by this section, no officer or employee, and no spouse of or immediately family member living with any
officer or employee (collectively referred to herein as "recipients"), shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any "prohibited source", as defined
herein, or which is otherwise prohibited by law or ordinance. No prohibited source shall intentionally offer or make a gift that violates this section.
B. Exceptions: Subsection A of this section is not applicable to the following, and each of the exceptions listed in this subsection is mutually exclusive and
independent of every other exception:
1. Opportunities, benefits and services that are available on the same conditions as for the general public.
2. Anything for which the officer or employee, or his spouse or immediately family member, pays the fair market value.
3. Any: a) contribution that is lawfully made under the election code; or b) activities associated with a fundraising event in support of a political
organization or candidate.
4. Educational materials and missions.
5. Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business.
6. A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, great aunt, great
uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law,
daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half sister, and
including the father, mother, grandfather or grandmother of the individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee.
7. Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the circumstances, the
gift was provided because of the official position or employment of the recipient or his spouse orimmediately family member and not because of the
personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the circumstances under
which the gift was offered, such as:
a. The history of the relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts between
those individuals;
b. Whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient, the individual who gave the gift sought a tax deduction or business reimbursement for the gift;
and
c. Whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient, the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar gifts to other
officers or employees, or their spouses or immediate family members.
8. Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy five dollars ($75.00) per person in value on a single calendar day, provided that the food or
refreshments are: a) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or prepared; or b) catered. For the purposes of this paragraph,
"catered" means food or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any means.
9. Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation and other benefits resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities that are
not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position or
employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to others in similar circumstances.
10. Intragovernmental and intergovernmental gifts. For the purpose of this section, "intragovernmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or
employee from another officer or employee, and "intergovernmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee of
another governmental entity.
11. Bequests, inheritances and other transfers at death.
12. Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars
($100.00).
C. Disposition Of Gifts: An officer or employee, his spouse or an immediate family member living with the officer or employee, does not violate this chapter
if the recipient promptly takes reasonable action to return a gift from a prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to its value to
an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under the internal revenue code of 1986, section 501(c)(3), as now or hereafter amended,
renumbered or succeeded. (Ord. O-20-04, 5-10-2004)
1-7-4: ETHICS ADVISOR:
A. The mayor, with the advice and consent of the village council, shall designate an ethics advisor for the village. The duties of the ethics advisor may be
delegated to an officer or employee of the village, unless the position has been created as an office by the village.
B. The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees of the village concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the
provisions of this chapter and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the village council. (Ord. O-
20-04, 5-10-2004)
1-7-5: ETHICS COMMISSION:
A. Commission Created; Members: There is hereby created a commission to be known as the ethics commission of the village. The commission shall be
comprised of three (3) members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the village council. No person shall be appointed as a member
of the commission who is related, either by blood or by marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected officer of the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 34/416
B. Terms: At the first meeting of the commission, the initial appointees shall draw lots to determine their initial terms. Two (2) commissioners shall serve
two (2) year terms and the third commissioner shall serve a one year term. Thereafter, all commissioners shall be appointed to two (2) year terms.
Commissioners may be reappointed to serve subsequent terms.
C. Organization; Quorum And Voting: At the first meeting of the commission, the commissioners shall choose a chair from their number. Meetings shall be
held at the call of the chair or any two (2) commissioners. A quorum shall consist of two (2) commissioners, and official action by the commission shall
require the affirmative vote of two (2) members.
D. Removal Of Commissioners: The mayor, with the advice and consent of the village council, may remove a commissioner in case of incompetence,
neglect of duty or malfeasance in office after service on the commissioner by certified mail, return receipt requested, of a copy of the written charges
against the commissioner and after providing the commissioner an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel upon not less than ten (10) days'
notice. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments.
E. Powers And Duties: The commission shall have the following powers and duties:
1. To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers.
2. Upon receipt of a signed, notarized, written complaint, to investigate, conduct hearings and deliberations, issue recommendations for disciplinary
actions, impose fines in accordance with subsection 1-7-5F8 of this chapter, and refer violations of section 1-7-2 or 1-7-3 of this chapter to the
appropriate attorney for prosecution. The commission shall, however, act only upon the receipt of a written complaint alleging a violation of this
chapter and not upon its own prerogative.
3. To receive information from the public pertaining to its investigations and to require additional information and documents from persons who may
have violated the provisions of this chapter.
4. To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all
officers and employees of the village to cooperate with the commission during the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal to cooperate with
requests by the commission shall constitute grounds for discipline or discharge.
5. The powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this chapter.
F. Complaints:
1. Complaints alleging the violation of this chapter shall be filed with the ethics commission.
2. Within three (3) business days after the receipt of a complaint, the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the
respondent that a complaint has been filed against him and a copy of the complaint. The commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt
requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within three (3) business days after receipt by the commission. The
notices to the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of the
complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed.
3. Upon not less than forty eight (48) hours' public notice, the commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and, if the complaint is
deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this chapter, to determine whether there is probable cause, based on the evidence presented by the
complaint, to proceed. The meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the open meetings act. The commission shall issue
notice to the complainant and the respondent of the commission's ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause to
proceed within seven (7) business days after receiving the complaint.
If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violationof section 1-7-3 of this chapter and there is a determination of probable cause, then the
commission's notice to the parties shall include a hearing date scheduled within four (4) weeks after the complaint's receipt. Alternatively, the
commission may elect to notify in writing the attorney designated by the corporate authorities to prosecute such actions and request that the
complaint be adjudicated judicially. If the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation, or if there is no determination of probable cause,
then the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint, and that
notice shall be made public.
If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section 1-7-2 of this chapter, then the commission shall notify in writing the attorney
designated by the corporate authorities to prosecute such actions, and shall transmit to the attorney the complaint and all additional documents in the
custody of the commission concerning the alleged violation.
4. On the scheduled date and upon at least forty eight (48) hours' public notice of the meeting, the commission shall conduct a hearing on the
complaint and shall allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. The hearing may be closed to the public only if authorized
by the open meetings act.
5. Within thirty (30) days after the date the hearing or any recessed hearing is concluded, the commission shall either: a) dismiss the complaint; or b)
issue a recommendation for discipline to the alleged violator and to the village administrator (or to the mayor, if the alleged violator is the village
administrator), or impose a fine upon the violator, or both. The particular findings in the case, any recommendation for discipline and any fine
imposed shall be a matter of public information.
6. If the hearing was closed to the public, the respondent may file a written demand for a public hearing on the complaint within seven (7) business
days after the issuance of the recommendation for discipline or imposition of a fine, or both. The filing of the demand shall stay the enforcement of
the recommendation or fine. Within fourteen (14) days after receiving the demand, the commission shall conduct a public hearing on the complaint
upon at least forty eight (48) hours' public notice of the hearing and allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. Within
seven (7) days thereafter, the commission shall publicly issue a final recommendation for discipline to the alleged violator and to the village
administrator (or to the mayor, if the alleged violator is the village administrator) or impose a fine upon the violator, or both.
7. If a complaint is filed during the sixty (60) days preceding the date of any election at which the respondent is a candidate,the commission shall
render its decision as required under subsection F5 of this section within seven (7) days after the complaint is filed, and if a complaint is filed during
the seven (7) days preceding that election, the commission shall render such decision before the date of that election, if possible.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 35/416
8. The commission may fine any person who intentionally violates any provision of section 1-7-3 of this chapter in an amount not less than one
thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The commission may fine any person who knowingly files a
frivolous complaint alleging a violation of this chapter in an amount not less than one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The commission may recommend any appropriate discipline up to and including discharge.
9. A complaint alleging the violation of this chapter must be filed within one year after the alleged violation. (Ord. O-20-04, 5-10-2004)
1-7-6: PENALTIES:
A. A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 1-7-2 of this chapter may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other
than a penitentiary for a period of not more than three hundred sixty four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five
hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
B. A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 1-7-3 of this chapter is subject to a fine in an amount of not less than one thousand one
dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
C. Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this chapter to the local enforcement authorities, the state's
attorney or any other law enforcement official may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of
not more than three hundred sixty four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
D. A violation of section 1-7-2 of this chapter shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by an attorney for the village by filing in the circuit court a sworn
complaint charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction shall require the
establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt.
A violation of section 1-7-3 of this chapter may be prosecuted as a quasi-criminal offense by an attorney for the village or, if an ethics commission has
been created, by the commission through the designated administrative procedure.
E. In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any provision of
section 1-7-2 or 1-7-3 of this chapter is subject to discipline or discharge. (Ord. O-20-04, 5-10-2004)
Chapter 8
MUNICIPAL FINANCES
1-8-1: NEGOTIABLE INSTRUMENTS:
The village clerk and comptroller are authorized and directed to assess a charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) against any person who pays any account due
the village by check, draft, money order or any other negotiable instrument which is not honored by the drawee or person, firm or corporation directed to
pay the check, draft, money order or other negotiable instrument. (Ord. O-49-09, 7-27-2009)
ARTICLE A. PURCHASING
1-8A-1: PURCHASING POLICY AND PURPOSE:
This policy shall create guidelines for the acquisition of goods and services by the village, and the purpose of this policy is to provide clear guidelines for
the procurement of goods and services by the village, in accordance with Illinois law. In addition:
A. The policy will allow the village to obtain the highest quality products, materials and services in the most cost efficient manner, while maintaining
accountability to the taxpayers; and
B. The policy will ensure that the public contracting process is conducted with the highest ethical standards and that all prohibitions on personal interests in
contracts are strictly enforced. (Ord. O-22-01, 6-25-2001)
1-8A-2: ETHICS IN PUBLIC CONTRACTING:
No person holding any municipal office within the village, either by election or appointment, may in any manner be financially interested, directly or
