3-3-7: TERM; CONDITIONS REGARDING FEES:
A. Term Of License; Renewal Fees: Each license shall be issued for a period no longer than six (6) months and shall terminate on either April 30 or
October 31 next following its issuance. One-half (1/2) of the annual license fee must be paid on or before May 1 each license year, and one-half (1/2) of
the annual license fee must be paid on or before November 1 each license year. Failure to make the required payment by the dates set forth herein
shall preclude the issuance or renewal of a license. (Ord. O-09-08, 3-24-2008)
B. Failure To Pay; Revocation: In the event installments are not paid when due, the mayor shall promptly revoke such licenses and the failure to make
such payment shall also be cause for revocation. (Village code § 7-10)
C. Proration Of Fee: The fee to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar months which have expired in the license year prior to the issued
license. (Village code § 7-11)
D. Disposition Of Fees: All such fees shall be paid to the local liquor control commissioner at the time of application being made, and shall be forthwith
turned over to the village treasurer. In the event the license applied for is denied, the fee shall be returned to the applicant. If the license is granted, the
fee shall be deposited in the general corporate fund or in such other fund as shall have been designated by the local liquor control commissioner by
proper action. (Village code § 7-12)
3-3-8: RECORDS:
The local liquor control commissioner shall keep, or cause to be kept, a complete record of all such licenses issued by him, and shall furnish the village
clerk, village treasurer and chief of police each with a copy thereof. Upon the issuance of any new license or the revocation of any old license, the local
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 71/416
liquor control commissioner shall give written notice of such action to each of these officers within forty eight (48) hours of such action. (Village code § 7-
13)
3-3-9: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
A. Transfer And Renewal: A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year after issuance, unless sooner revoked as in this
chapter provided, and shall not constitute property; nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution; nor shall it be alienable or
transferable voluntarily or involuntarily or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall cease upon the death of the licensee, and
shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and
the trustee or any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale or
manufacture of alcoholic liquor under the order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt
licensee after the death of such decedent or such insolvency or bankruptcy, until the expiration of such license, but no longer than six (6) months after
the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. A refund shall be made of that portion of the license fee paid for any period in which the licensee
shall be prevented from operating under the license, in accordance with the provisions in this subsection. (Village code § 7-18)
B. Location:
1. General: No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church, school (except schools
offering instruction limited to cooking or wine classes), hospital, home for aged or indigent persons, or for veterans, their spouses or children, or any
military or naval station; provided, however, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to
restaurants, food shops or other places where sale of alcoholic liquor is not the principal business carried on, nor to the renewal of a license for the
sale at retail of alcoholic liquor on premises within one hundred feet (100') of any church or school where such church or school has been
established within such one hundred feet (100') since the issuance of the original license.
Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the issuance of a license to a church or a private school to sell at retail alcoholic liquor if any such sales are
limited to periods when groups are assembled on the premises solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption
of alcoholic liquors. (Ord. O-54-03, 12-22-2003)
2. Change Of Location: A retail liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in the premises prescribed in the application and
license. Such location may be changed only upon the written permit to make such change issued by the local liquor control commissioner. No
change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the laws of this state
and the ordinances of the village. (Village code § 7-19)
C. View From Street: In premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor is licensed (other than a restaurant, hotel or club or a premises which is licensed
pursuant to the class A6 or B2 license provisions), no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the windows or upon the
doors of such licensed premises, nor inside such premises, from the street, road or sidewalk at all times; and no booth screen partition, or other
obstruction, nor any arrangement of lights or lighting, shall be permitted in or about the interior of such premises, which shall prevent a clear view into
the interior from the street, road or sidewalk. Said premises must be so located that there shall be a full view of the entire interior of such premises from
the street, road or sidewalk. All rooms where liquor is sold for consumption upon the premises shall be continuously lighted during the business hours
by a natural light or artificial, white light so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible. In case the view into any such licensed
premises, required by the foregoing provisions, shall be wilfully obscured by the licensee or by him wilfully suffered to be obscured, or in any manner
obstructed, then such license shall be subject to revocation in the manner provided by law. In order to enforce the provisions of this section, the local
liquor control commissioner shall have the right to require the filing with him of plans, drawings and photographs showing the clearance of view as
above described and required. (Ord. O-30-06, 5-8-2006; amd. Ord. O-09-08, 3-24-2008)
D. Closing Hours:
1. General:
a. Except as provided in subsection D2, D3, D4, D5 or D6 of this section, it shall be unlawful to sell, permit to sell, or give away, alcoholic liquor
between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., except on Saturday and Sunday and on any day officially designated
for observance of the following holidays: New Year's Day (January 1), the day after St. Patrick's Day (March 18), and Thanksgiving Day, on which
days alcoholic liquor may not be sold between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
b. It shall be unlawful to remain open for business, or to admit the public to any premises in, or on, which alcoholic liquor is sold at retail, during the
hours within which the sale of such liquor is prohibited, provided, however, that restaurants, clubs or hotels may remain open during such hours, so
long as no alcoholic liquor may be sold or consumed by the public during such hours.
2. Class A2 Licenses: Hours for the consumption of alcoholic liquor in a restaurant with a class A2 license shall be from eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to
eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. Sunday through Thursday, and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on Friday and Saturday.
3. Class A6 Licenses: Hours for the consumption of wine and the sale of packaged wine products in a premises with a class A6 license shall be from
eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on any day of the week. (Ord. O-09-08, 3-24-2008)
4. Class B1 Licenses: Effective November 1, 2013, it shall be unlawful to sell, give away or deliver, alcoholic liquor between the hours of eleven o'clock
(11:00) P.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on each day. (Ord. O-26-13, 9-23-2013)
5. Class B2 Licenses: Hours for the consumption of wine and the sale of packaged wine products in a premises with a class B2 license shall be from
eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on any day of the week.
6. Class C Licenses: Hours for the consumption of alcoholic liquor in a restaurant with a class C license shall be from eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to
eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. Sunday through Thursday, and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on Friday and Saturday.
(Ord. O-09-08, 3-24-2008; amd. Ord. O-26-13, 9-23-2013)
E. Insurance And Indemnification: No license shall be granted to any applicant until such applicant shall furnish evidence satisfactory to the local liquor
control commissioner that such applicant is covered by a policy of dramshop insurance issued by a responsible insurance company authorized and
licensed to do business in the state of Illinois, insuring such applicant against liability which applicant may incur under the provisions of 235 Illinois
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 72/416
Compiled Statutes 5/6-21. The village shall be named a certificate holder on such policy of insurance, which shall provide that such policy shall not be
canceled or denied renewal unless the village is provided at least thirty (30) days' prior written notice thereof.
The provisions of this subsection shall be liberally construed and each applicant and license holder shall have the burden of providing the local liquor
control commissioner with satisfactory evidence that said insurance is in full force and effect at any particular time during the term of any such license.
Failure to do so after the issuance of any local liquor license shall render said license void ab initio.
As a condition of such license, the licensee shall be required to save and hold harmless, and indemnify the village, its officers, agents, employees and
officials from any and all claims or causes of action arising out of the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises or the sale of alcoholic
liquor. (Ord. O-09-08, 3-24-2008)
F. Live Music: In any premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor is licensed, all exterior windows and doors to the licensed premises shall remain
closed during the playing or performing of any live music. (Ord. O-20-08, 5-27-2008)
G. Removal Of Waste Material And Litter: It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the village to maintain the exterior of the
licensed premises in a safe, clean and sanitary manner at all times, including the duty to remove all waste material and all litter, including, but not
limited to, cigarette and cigar butts and paper from the public sidewalk, parkway and right of way adjacent to the licensed premises. All such waste
material and litter shall be placed in a refuse container for removal by the licensed premises' waste hauler. Any violation of such duty may result in the
revocation of the liquor license in the manner provided by law. (Ord. O-41-08, 10-14-2008)
3-3-10: SANITARY REQUIREMENTS:
A. Premises: All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage of such liquor for such sale, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition and shall be provided with sanitary equipment as follows:
1. Hot and cold running water for the cleaning and washing of glassware and similar utensils; and, the trough wherein said glassware and utensils are
cleaned and washed shall contain a nonharmful, humane chemical of sufficient potency to eliminate bacteria.
2. Sinks for kitchen use.
3. Not less than one lavatory and water closet for the use of each sex. (Village code § 7-21)
4. The wastewater from sinks, dishwashing machines, and all other fixtures likely to contain grease, located in any such establishment, shall before
entering the sewer, go into an approved and separating catch basin or grease trap. In the event a grease trap is used in said establishment, it shall
first be approved by the director of public health and safety. (Village code § 7-21; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
5. In addition to the foregoing requirements, the said establishment shall fully comply with all the ordinances of the village and statutes of the state of
Illinois regulating the conditions of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption. (Village code § 7-21)
B. Employees: It shall be unlawful to employ, in any premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, any person who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier
of, any contagious, infectious or venereal disease; and it shall be unlawful for any person, who is afflicted with or a carrier of any such disease, to work
in or about any premises or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or distribution of such liquor. (Village code § 7-22)
3-3-11: MINORS:
A. Employment: No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall sell, draw or mix or be permitted to sell, draw or mix any alcoholic liquor in any
premises licensed for the sale or dispensing of alcoholic liquor under this chapter. The provisions of this subsection shall not be construed to prevent
the employment of persons who are at least eighteen (18) years of age as waiters or waitresses in restaurants, hotels, or motels for the purpose of
serving food and alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises. (Ord. O-20-08, 5-27-2008)
B. Sales To:
1. No licensee or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of any licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any
person under the age of twenty one (21) years or to any intoxicated person or to any person known to him to be under legal disability or in need of
mental treatment.
2. No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall give or deliver alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty
one (21) years except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service.
C. Purchases By: No person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited shall consume, purchase or accept alcoholic liquor or have
alcoholic liquor in his possession. This subsection shall not apply to the dispensing or consumption of alcoholic liquor by a person under twenty one
(21) years of age in the performance of a religious ceremony or service, or the consumption by a person under twenty one (21) years of age under the
direct supervision of the parent, or parents or person in loco parentis in the privacy of a home. (Ord. O-22-96, 8-12-1996)
D. Misrepresentation Of Age: It shall be unlawful for any minor to misrepresent his age for the purpose of purchasing, obtaining or consuming alcoholic
liquor in any place within the village where alcoholic liquor is sold or offered for consumption. (Ord. O-29-00, 7-10-2000)
E. Presence Of Minors Prohibited:
1. Unlawful: It shall be unlawful for the holder of a liquor license, his agent or employee, to permit any person under the age of twenty one (21), except
waiters and waitresses, to be in or remain in any room or place in which alcoholic liquor (inclusive of beer and/or wine) is served, within an
establishment whose principal business is the sale of alcoholic liquor.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 73/416
2. Exceptions:
a. This subsection shall not apply to any minor who is accompanied by his parent(s) or legal guardian(s); however, the presence of such parent or
guardian does not grant the right or privilege to any person under the age of twenty one (21) to consume or possess any type of alcoholic liquor.
b. This subsection shall not apply to any restaurant or other establishment whose principal business activity is not the sale of alcoholic liquor.
However, such exception shall not apply to restaurants or other establishments wherein the kitchen/food preparation area is closed and food is no
longer being consumed or offered for sale and the premises are dispensing alcoholic liquor in any room or place in the premises. (Ord. O-30-00, 7-
10-2000)
3-3-12: AMUSEMENT ESTABLISHMENTS:
A. Definition: The term "amusement" as used herein is defined to mean and include any public show, theatrical, animate or inanimate exhibition, musical,
music, mechanical or manually operated entertainment device, or any other entertainment offered, operated, presented or exhibited to the public.
B. Restrictions:
1. No licensee shall sponsor, conduct, or permit amusements in any licensed premises unless the application for a license therefor has been submitted
to and approved by the local liquor commissioner and the village council.
2. In addition to the other regulations in this code governing the issuance of licenses or permits for amusements in any licensed premises, animated
entertainment in premises with a class A license with less than three thousand one (3,001) square feet shall not consist of more than three (3)
persons. (Ord. O-12-80, 6-23-1980)
3-3-13: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
A. Peddling Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the village. (Village code § 7-20)
B. Preservation Of The Peace:
1. It shall be the duty and responsibility of each liquor license holder, his agents or employees to maintain the premises in a peaceable and orderly
manner so as not to allow any employee, patron or member of the public to commit any act, which act is done in an unreasonable manner so as to
alarm or disturb another or to provoke a breach of the peace.
2. Each liquor license holder shall employ sufficient agents or employees on the premises in order to maintain the peace. Any employee, agent or
person acting on behalf of the liquor license holder shall be suitably trained to maintain the peace of the premises and shall not act in any manner so
as to promote or aggravate situations which may result in physical altercations, fighting or other acts of an unreasonable manner so as to alarm or
disturb another or provoke a breach of the peace.
3. No liquor license holder, his agents or employees shall knowingly permit any fighting which shall consist of physical contact of an insulting or
provoking nature or cause physical harm to an individual.
4. "Premises", as defined for the purposes of this section shall mean the actual physical space within the establishment where alcoholic beverages are
sold to the public, any area set aside for the use by the general public (restrooms or lounges), any area used by the liquor license holder, his agents
or employees for preparation of services (kitchen and storage areas) and any outdoor area wherein the public is served or waiting to be served or
where customers are authorized to park any vehicle as well as the areas of ingress and egress to such parking facility.
5. Every liquor license holder, agent or employee who is present and observes any type of criminal activity or fighting, as defined above, is required to
immediately notify the police department. The police department shall then notify the local liquor commissioner of any conduct or patrons or other
persons on the premises of a liquor license establishment which results in any type of criminal activity, fighting or a breach of the peace.
6. Failure to report any incident as required under this subsection within two (2) business days may subject the liquor license holder to a revocation or
suspension of the retail liquor dealer's license, as well as possible fines imposed by the local liquor commissioner in the manner provided by statute.
7. The local liquor commissioner shall have the right and/or authority to revoke or suspend the retail liquor dealer's license as well as impose fines or
take any other legal action necessary to prevent the reoccurrence of a public nuisance as hereinabove defined in the manner provided by statute.
(Ord. O-31-00, 7-10-2000)
3-3-14: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE; IMPOSITION OF FINES:
A. Examination: The mayor of the village of Forest Park shall serve as local liquor control commissioner and he shall have the right to examine, or cause to
be examined, under oath, any applicant for a local liquor license or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension and/or fine has been
served, as provided by statute or this chapter, and to examine or cause to be examined the books and records of any such licensee to hear testimony
and take proof for his information in the performance of his duties, and for such purpose to issue subpoenas which shall be effective in any part of this
state. For the purpose of obtaining any of the information desired by the local liquor control commissioner under this chapter, he may authorize his
agent to act on his behalf, as provided by statute.
B. Powers And Duties: The local liquor control commissioner shall have the following powers, functions and duties with respect to licenses issued
hereunder:
1. To suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke any local liquor license issued by him, if he determines that the local liquor licensee has
violated any ordinance, resolution or regulation enacted by the village or the licensee has violated any of the provisions of the liquor control act of
1934 or other law of the state of Illinois or any regulation adopted by the state of Illinois liquor control commission.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 74/416
2. In addition to or in lieu of a license suspension or revocation as herein provided, the local liquor control commissioner is further authorized to levy a
fine upon the licensee if he determines that the local liquor licensee has violated any ordinance, resolution or regulation enacted by the village or the
licensee has violated any of the provisions of the liquor control act of 1934 or other law of the state of Illinois or any regulation adopted by the state of
Illinois liquor control commission. The fine imposed shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a first violation within a twelve (12) month
period, one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a twelve (12) month period, and two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00) for a third or subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month period. Each day upon which a violation continues shall constitute a
separate violation. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no more than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in fines may be imposed upon any licensee
during the annual period of his or her license. All proceeds from such fines shall be paid into the general corporate fund of the village of Forest Park.
3. The local liquor control commissioner is hereby authorized to enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time upon any premises
licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions of the municipal code or resolution or regulations of the village of Forest Park or any
provisions of the Illinois liquor control act of 1934 or other law of the state of Illinois or this chapter, or any of the rules or regulations adopted by him
or by the state commission have been or are being violated, and at such time to examine the premises of said licensee in connection therewith.
C. Hearing Procedure:
1. Notice: No local liquor license shall be revoked, suspended, and no licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing before the local liquor
control commissioner or his or her designee with no less than a three (3) day written notice to the licensee setting forth the nature of the violation(s)
alleged and affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend.
2. Procedure:
a. Open To Public; Record Of Proceedings: All such hearings shall be open to the public and an official record shall be made by a certified court
reporter in attendance;
b. Motions To Be In Writing: All motions shall be in writing and shall be served upon the local liquor control commissioner at least one day prior to
presentation;
c. Motion For Continuance: No motion for a continuance first made on the date of the hearing shall be granted unless by agreement of the parties
and approved by the local liquor control commissioner or for good cause shown;
d. Disposition By Determination, Stipulation, Agreed Settlement, Consent Order, Or Default: Disposition of any matter brought before the local liquor
control commissioner for hearing may be made by determination by the local liquor control commissioner, or by stipulation, agreed settlement,
consent order, or default;
e. Reasons For Action; Service: If the local liquor control commissioner determines that the licensee is not liable for the offense charged or that the
local liquor license shall be revoked or suspended and/or a fine imposed, the local liquor control commissioner shall state the reasons for such
determination in a written order setting forth that the licensee is not liable for the offense charged or setting forth the period of suspension or that
the license has been revoked and/or the amount of the fine imposed, as the case may be; and he shall serve a copy of such written order within
five (5) days upon the licensee;
f. Emergency Closure: If the local liquor control commissioner has reason to believe that continued operation of any licensed premises presents an
imminent threat to the health or welfare of the village, he may, upon the issuance of a written order stating the reason(s) for such conclusion and
without notice or prior hearing, order the licensed premises closed for a period not to exceed seven (7) days. The local liquor control commissioner
shall afford the licensee an opportunity to be heard during the seven (7) day period in accordance with the hearing procedures set forth herein;
g. Appeal Of Local Liquor Control Commissioner Decision: Any licensee aggrieved by a decision of the local liquor control commissioner may appeal
that decision pursuant to the provisions of section 5/7-9 of the Illinois liquor control act of 19347, provided, however, that any appeal of the
proceedings for the imposition of a revocation or suspension and/or fine shall be limited to review of the official record of the proceedings before
the local liquor control commissioner.
D. Use Of Premises After Revocation: When any local liquor license shall have been revoked for cause, no local liquor license shall be granted to any
person or entity for the period of one year thereafter for the conduct of the sale of alcoholic liquor in the premises described in the order of revocation,
unless the local liquor control commissioner vacates the revocation order or unless the revocation order was entered as to the offending licensee only.
(Ord. O-51-09, 8-10-2009)
3-3-15: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
(Rep. by Ord. O-51-09, 8-10-2009)
3-3-16: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL HEARING OFFICER:
A. There is hereby created the administrative position of local liquor control hearing officer. The local liquor control hearing officer shall serve at the
discretion of the mayor. Such appointment or removal of the local liquor control hearing officer shall be made in writing by the mayor and such
appointment shall set forth the duties and responsibilities of the local liquor control hearing officer consistent with the provisions of the liquor control act
of 19348.
B. Compensation for the local liquor control hearing officer shall be as from time to time determined by the village council. (Ord. O-55-07, 11-13-2007)
3-3-17: ALCOHOL SELLERS AND SERVERS EDUCATION AND TRAINING:
A. Definitions:
ALCOHOL SERVER: Person(s) who sell, pour, mix or serve open containers of alcoholic beverages at retail and anyone whose job description entails
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 75/416
the checking of identification for the purchase of open containers of alcoholic beverages at retail or for entry into the licensed premises. The definition
of alcohol server excludes a distributor or importing distributor conducting product sampling as authorized in section 6-31 of the liquor control act of
19349, a registered tasting representative, as provided in 11 Illinois administrative code 100.40, conducting a tasting, as defined in 11 Illinois
administrative code 100.10, a special event retailer or volunteer serving alcoholic beverages at a charitable function or an instructor engaged in training
or educating on the proper technique for using a system that dispenses alcoholic beverages.
LICENSEE: The holder of a village of Forest Park class A, A1, A2, A3, A7, B1 or B2 village of Forest Park retail local liquor license.
STATE CERTIFIED BASSET TRAINING PROGRAM: A BASSET program licensed by the state of Illinois liquor control commission (ILCC) as required
by sections 3-12 (11.1) and 6-27 of the liquor control act of 193410 and title 77 of the Illinois administrative code, chapter XVI, section 3500.
B. Completion Of Program: All alcohol servers, as herein defined, and managers of liquor licensed establishments shall have successfully completed an
ILCC BASSET approved seller/server training program within one hundred twenty (120) days of the first date of their employment by the licensee.
C. New Employees: New employees required to successfully complete BASSET training shall perform their duties under the direct supervision of a person
who has successfully completed BASSET training until they have successfully completed an ILCC BASSET approved seller/server training program.
D. Certificates Of Completion: Photocopies of certificates of completion for all persons required by this section to have completed BASSET training shall
be maintained, by the licensed establishment, on the licensed premises, in such a manner that will allow the immediate inspection, upon demand, by
any law enforcement officer of the village of Forest Park, Illinois state police, agents of the Illinois liquor control commission or local liquor control
commissioner of the village of Forest Park.
E. Penalty: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any licensee to employ or act as agent or manager to any person in violation of this
section. (Ord. O-30-15, 11-9-2015)
Chapter 4
AMUSEMENTS
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
AMUSEMENT: Any public show, theatrical exhibition, circus or any other entertainment offered, operated, presented or exhibited to the public.
AMUSEMENT PLACE: Any building, hall, room, grounds, picnic grove or enclosure where the public may be admitted, with or without the payment of a fee
or charge, for the purpose of witnessing or engaging in an amusement, whether musical or otherwise, picnics, dancing or skating by patrons or other
persons. (Village Code § 8-1)
3-4-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; FEES:
No person shall operate or manage any amusement which is open to the public without obtaining a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be
made in the manner provided for in this code. The license fees for such licenses shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this title.
Any person sponsoring an amusement or place of amusement defined herein shall be required to provide adequate police protection for such activity
consisting of at least one officer or other authorized person for each one hundred (100) patrons or less, and shall be responsible for the payment of such
police protection. (Ord. O-11-80, 6-23-1980)
3-4-3: COIN OPERATED MUSICAL DEVICES:
A. Definition: The term "coin operated musical device" is hereby defined to mean and include all devices, machines or apparatus designed and used for
the electrical or mechanical reproduction of music for amusement or entertainment, the operation of which is governed or controlled by the deposit of
coins or tokens.
B. License Required: It shall be unlawful to own, operate, keep or maintain a coin operated musical device in any place ofbusiness open to the public in
the village without first obtaining a license therefor.
C. Application For License: The application for a license to own, operate, keep or maintain a coin operated musical or amusement device, or machine shall
be made in the manner provided for in this chapter.
D. License Fee: The annual license fee for each device or machine shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this title.
E. Conditions Of License:
1. License Not Assignable Or Transferable: No license granted pursuant to the terms of this section shall be assigned or transferred to any other
person, nor shall any such license authorizing any person, other than the licensee named herein, to keep, operate or maintain said device, or
machine, unless the entire business in which the device is located has been sold and the assets thereof transferred to the purchaser.
2. Hours Of Operation: No person shall permit the operation of any device licensed hereunder between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M., with the exception of duly authorized liquor licensees in whose establishments the device may be operated between the hours
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 76/416
during which the sale of alcoholic liquor is permitted1. (Ord. O-2-96, 1-22-1996)
3-4-4: COIN AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENTS:
A. Definition: For purposes of this section, the term "automatic amusement" shall mean any mechanical or electronic amusement machine or device, the
operation of which is governed by the insertion of coins, tokens, chips or similar objects (and which does not return any money or property to the
player) returns to the player thereof no money or property, excluding machines or devices which return vocal or musical sounds or which are regulated
in section 3-4-3 of this chapter.
B. License Required: No person shall deliver, install or cause to be delivered or installed, an automatic amusement machine within the village for use by
any other person for gain or profit from operation unless a license has been issued for the current license period.
C. Application For License: In addition to the license application provided for in this section, the applicant for the license provided for herein shall file a
statement of the method and manner that will be employed to assure that the automatic amusement machines will not be used for gambling and will
not be accessible to minors unaccompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
D. License Fee: An annual license fee as provided in section 3-5-1 of this title is imposed upon each qualifying automatic amusement used in the village
for gain or profit from operation.
E. Conditions Of License:
1. Gambling Prohibited: No person shall keep, permit to be kept or use an automatic amusement for the awarding of money, property or anything else
of value. No license shall be issued for any automatic machines that display a poker hand or dice or other material commonly associated with a
gambling activity in the manner as displayed and used in play.
2. Display Of License: It shall be the duty of the licensee to affix the license in a conspicuous place on the licensed automatic amusement machines.
Inspections of the machines for licenses can be conducted anytime and at least twice annually.
3. Use By Minors: No person shall permit or allow any minor unaccompanied by a parent or legal guardian to use an automatic amusement machine.
4. Miscellaneous Provisions:
a. The annual license fee for the machine shall be paid at the time of the application's approval and is nonrefundable and nontransferable. (Ord. O-1-
96, 1-22-1996)
b. The village clerk shall either approve a license, require the statement be modified to further comply with this section, deny the application or
impose conditions upon the licensee to require conformance with this section. (Ord. O-1-96, 1-22-1996; amd. 2004 Code)
c. The applicant may appeal the decision of the village clerk to the entire village council by filing a notice of appeal with the village clerk within thirty
(30) days of the date of decision by the village clerk.
d. The license for any coin operated amusement currently licensed upon the terms of this section will be forfeited in the event that the machine fails
to comply with all provisions of this section at any time during the license period. A fine for a violation of this section and a new license fee may be
imposed if the license is thereafter reinstated.
e. The applicant for a license under this section must provide the name, address and current phone number for the distributor of the machines to be
used, and that distributor may be subject to a detailed background investigation.
f. The location in which additional coin operated amusements are placed will be inspected at any time by the fire department and may be evaluated
to determine compliance with occupancy requirements. (Ord. O-1-96, 1-22-1996)
F. Violations: Whoever violates any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof be fined as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-
1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. O-1-96, 1-22-1996; amd. 2004 Code)
3-4-5: MOTION PICTURE AND OTHER THEATERS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a moving picture or vaudeville show, or similar entertainment, where an admission fee,
except for the benefit of a religious, educational or charitable organization, is charged and regular performance is given, until a license for the same has
been issued, as hereinafter provided. (Village Code § 8-9)
B. Application: Applications for such licenses shall be made in the manner provided for in this code. (Village Code § 8-10)
C. License Fees: The annual fee for such license shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this title. (Village Code § 8-11)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Aisles: Aisles and rooms used for this purpose, shall have in the aggregate a width of not less than twenty inches (20") for each one hundred (100)
of seating capacity of such room, and no aisle shall have a width of less than two feet six inches (2'6"). Every aisle passageway, entrance and exit
shall be free of turnstiles, railings or other obstructions. (Village Code § 8-12)
2. Exits: A least two (2) entrance doors shall be provided, and no entrance door shall be less than four feet (4') in width. If the rear of the building abuts
upon any alley, there shall be provided not less than two (2) emergency exits leading directly to said alley. If the side of the auditorium abuts upon a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 77/416
street or alley, one exit shall be placed at a distance of not more than five feet (5') from the stage and the other exit shall be located at a distance half
way between the foyer and the stage wall. (Village Code § 8-13)
3. Doors: All doors affording ingress, or egress, to the building shall open outward and shall not be obscured by curtains or draperies; and no door shall
be locked or fastened during the time such building is open to the public. (Village Code § 8-14)
4. Projection Booths: The walls, floor and ceiling of every moving picture booth or machine house, shall be built of four inch (4") hollow tile or four inch
(4") solid concrete, supported on iron beams or columns. The door of the operating room to be metal clad and swing outward. There shall be a metal
smoke or flue pipe eighteen inches (18") in diameter, extending from the ceiling to three feet (3') above the roof of the machine house, and
terminating in the open air. (Village Code § 8-15)
5. Exit Signs: The word "exit" shall appear in letters six inches (6") high over the openings to every means of egress from suchroom. (Village Code § 8-
16)
6. Fire Apparatus: Approved portable fire extinguishers, or pumps, shall always be kept ready for use about the room; and each theater shall be
provided with an approved automatic fire alarm apparatus connected with the fire hose. (Village Code § 8-17)
7. Lighting: All electrical lighting shall be installed in accordance with the electrical code, and shall be of such intensity as to adequately illuminate all
areas. (Village Code § 8-18)
E. Carnivals, Street Shows, Etc.: No permit shall be granted for any carnival, street show, circus or other amusement, on any public street or sidewalk,
except by order of the village council. (Village Code § 8-21)
F. Athletic Exhibitions:
1. It shall be unlawful to conduct operate or exhibit, any race, baseball game, boxing or wrestling match or any other athletic contest, or exhibition, for
private gain, for admission to which a fee is charged, without having procured a license therefor.
2. The proprietor of such exhibition shall submit to the village clerk, a statement verified under oath, of the gross receipts of each game, contest or race
within one week after such exhibition. At the same time, such proprietor, or person exhibiting or operating such exhibition, shall pay to the village
clerk, a sum equal to three percent (3%) of the gross receipts2.
3. Sufficient members of the police department shall be admitted, free of charge to all such exhibitions for the purpose of preserving and maintaining
order. The village clerk may post a person, or any number of persons, at the box office of each such performance; and may examine all the books
pertaining to such performance showing, or tending to show, the gross receipts. (Village Code § 8-22)
G. Violation; Penalty: Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall be fined as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of
this code for each offense. Each day that the violation continues shall be regarded as constituting a distinct and separate offense. (Village Code § 8-24;
amd. 2004 Code)
3-4-6: BILLIARD AND POOL TABLES:
A. License Required: No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a billiard, pool, bagatelle or pigeonhole table, open to the public, without first obtaining
a license therefor. (Village Code§ 8-25)
B. License Fee: The annual fee for any such license shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this title. (Village Code § 8-26)
C. Conditions Of License:
1. Minors: No person who keeps, conducts or operates any billiard or pool table, or who keeps, conducts or operates any room or rooms, or enclosures
or such as kept, operated or conducted shall permit, or allow, any minors under the age of eighteen (18) years to play thereon; or to use such table;
or to be, or remain in, or frequent any such room or enclosure. (Village Code § 8-27; amd. 2004 Code)
2. Hours Of Operation: No billiard hall, or other hall licensed hereunder, shall be open for business, or used, between the hours of one o'clock (1:00)
A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Village Code § 8-28)
D. Penalty: Any person violating the provision of this section shall be fined as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code for each offense.
Al separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during, or which, a violation occurs or continues. (Village Code § 8-29; amd. 2004 Code)
3-4-7: BOWLING ALLEYS:
A. License Required: No person shall operate or maintain a bowling alley open to the public without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village Code § 8-30)
B. License Fee: The annual fee for such license shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this title. (Village Code § 8-31)
C. Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code for each
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Village Code § 8-32; amd.
2004 Code)

any noncompliance on the part of a licensee. (Ord. O-17-07, 4-23-2007)
3-5-2: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 82/416
A. Any person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, and the articles contained herein, shall be punished as provided in the
general penalty provisions of section 1-3-1 of this code. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate
offense.
B. In addition to the general penalties provided for noncompliance with this chapter, any person who has not complied with the requirements contained in
subsection 3-5-1C of this chapter shall incur a penalty as follows:
1. If renewal in accordance with subsection 3-5-1C of this chapter does not occur before June 1, the licensee shall incur a penalty of one hundred
percent (100%) of the original license fee.
2. If renewal in accordance with subsection 3-5-1C of this chapter does not occur before July 1, the licensee shall incur a penalty of two hundred
percent (200%) of the original license fee. (Ord. O-17-07, 4-23-2007)
ARTICLE A. SALES AND RETAIL ESTABLISHMENTS
3-5A-1: DRY GOODS STORES:
A. License Required: No person shall own, operate or conduct a dry goods store, children's wear store, dress shop, vanity goods, fur shop, gift shop,
hosiery shop, millinery store, men's furnishings store or lingerie store without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-95; amd. 2004 Code)
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for a dry goods store, or any of the miscellaneous shops or stores set forth in this section, shall be as set out in
section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-96)
C. Sanitation Requirements: All such stores and shops must be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. (Village Code § 11-97)
3-5A-2: HARDWARE AND PAINT STORES:
A. Definitions:
RETAIL HARDWARE STORE: Any establishment operated for the sale of, or offering for sale, at retail, any of the following articles: hardware, tinware,
aluminum ware, enamel ware, cutlery, tools, implements, apparatus, machinery, plumbing; engineer's, janitor's, blacksmith's, contractor's or electrical
supplies; gas, plumbing or electrical fixtures; other articles or wares, made largely of metals; kerosene. Provided, however, that dealers, or
establishments; or parts of establishments of a similar nature, specifically defined and licensed elsewhere in this code, shall be exempt from the
provisions of this section.
RETAIL PAINT STORE: Any establishment operated for the sale, at retail, of any paints, dry colors, wallpaper, varnishes, calcimine, white or red lead,
raw or boiled linseed oil, turpentine, drier, benzine, naphtha; or painters' tools, supplies or equipment. Provided, however, that dealers or
establishments of a similar nature specifically defined and licensed by other provisions of this code, shall be exempt from the provisions of this section.
(Village Code § 11-123)
B. License Required: No person shall engage in the business of a retail hardware or paint store without having first obtained a license therefor. (Village
Code § 11-124)
C. License Fees: Fees for retail hardware and/or paint stores, as licensed herein, are set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-125)
3-5A-3: BICYCLE SHOPS:
A. Definitions:
BICYCLE SHOP: A shop, store or other place of business where bicycles are sold at retail, or where bicycle accessories are sold, or where bicycles
are repaired or rented. (Village code § 11-43)
B. License Required: No person shall establish, maintain or operate a bicycle shop for the sale or rental of bicycles without first obtaining a license
therefor. (Village code § 11-44)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for a bicycle shop shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-45)
D. Rental Agencies: Bicycles offered for rent by a rental agency shall be equipped with lights and all safety equipment required and shall be kept in safe
working order. The chief of police shall make periodic inspection of bicycle shops to ascertain that they are complying with all the requirements of the
laws of the village and of the state of Illinois. (Village code § 11-46)
3-5A-4: BOILER AND HEATING PLANT DEALERS:
A. License Required: No person shall engage in the business of installing steam, vapor or hot water boilers within the village, without first obtaining a
license therefor. (Village code § 11-47)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 83/416
B. License Fees: License fees for conducting the business of selling, installing or replacing steam, vapor or hot water boilers, shall be as set out in section
3-5-1 of this chapter. The number of employees shall be determined by the largest number employed at any time, in the preceding year. For the first
year, the fee and license shall be for the number of employees stated in the application. (Village code § 11-48)
C. Approval Required: Any such person conducting the business of installing or replacing boilers or furnaces, shall comply with the provisions of the
ordinances relative to buildings; and work shall be subject to the approval of the director of public health and safety. (Village code § 11-49; amd. Ord.
O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
D. Disposal Of Wastes: Any person conducting the business of installing boilers shall, upon completion of each job, remove all old or surplus material
within three (3) days. Said material shall not be placed on vacant lots, streets or alleys, but must be removed outside of the corporate limits of the
village within the time above specified. (Village code § 11-50)
3-5A-5: MACHINE SHOPS:
A. Definition:
MACHINE SHOP: A place, building or structure in which machines are made or metal parts thereof are repaired, or where parts of machines, tools,
implements, gears, dies, screws or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped, punched, stamped or repaired by means of various articles of machinery.
(Village code § 11-163)
B. License Required: No person shall operate a machine shop without first obtaining a license therefor. Provided, however, that this section shall not apply
to any other businesses, if any, specifically licensed under this code. (Village code § 11-164)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for a machine shop shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-165)
D. Sanitary Requirements:
1. Every machine shop shall be kept in a clean, sanitary condition. All articles made, altered, repaired or finished in such establishment shall be kept
free from vermin and any other matter of an infectious or contagious nature. No person suffering from any active, contagious or infectious disease
shall be employed in any such establishment.
2. All waste matter shall be disposed of at least once each day, and in such manner as not to cause a nuisance.
3. In all machine shops, adequate ventilation, washing and toilet facilities shall be provided. (Village code § 11-166)
3-5A-6: PAWNBROKERS:
A. License Required: No person shall operate or conduct the business of a pawnbroker without obtaining a license therefor. (Village code § 11-194)
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for a pawnbroker shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-195)
C. Records Kept: Every pawnbroker, doing business in the village, shall keep a record of every article pledged with him, or sold to him. This record shall be
open to the inspection of any police officer at any time. (Village Code § 11-196)
D. Weapons: Every pawnbroker shall keep every revolver, pistol, blackjack or other weapon in his possession under lock and key. (Village Code § 11-197)
3-5A-7: PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT VENDORS:
A. Definitions:
COMMERCIAL SOLICITOR: A person engaged in the business of obtaining orders or subscriptions for merchandise while going from place to place, in
the village, on the public ways, in commercial establishments, or on residential property, in order to contact persons where such persons have made no
previous request, invitation or appointment.
ITINERANT VENDOR: A person who conducts a temporary or transient business selling goods, wares or merchandise, with the intention of not
continuing such business for more than one hundred twenty (120) days, and who, for the purpose of carrying on such business, uses, leases, or
occupies a room, building, or other structure, for the exhibition of such wares or merchandise.
NONCOMMERCIAL SOLICITOR: A person engaged in an appeal for funds, support or aid for nonprofit organizations promoting charitable,
educational, religious or legitimate public action causes.
PEDDLER: A person who sells or offers for sale any commodity or article while traveling from place to place, and who carries such commodity or article
on his person or in a vehicle for delivery at the time of sale.
SOLICITOR: A person engaged in a business for profit, who seeks to obtain subscriptions for books, magazines, newspapers or other publications, not
delivered at the time of sale, or offering to furnish services or inviting orders for services.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 84/416
B. License Required:
1. Application: Every person seeking to be a "peddler", "solicitor", "itinerant vendor", or "commercial solicitor", as those terms are defined in subsection
A of this section, must first obtain a license from the village clerk by completing an application on a form to be furnished by the village clerk, and such
applicant shall furnish the following information:
a. Name and address of present place of residence and length of residence at such address, and residence address for three (3) years next
preceding the date of application;
b. Business address if other than residence address;
c. The applicant's social security number and date of birth;
d. A physical description of the applicant;
e. Name and address of the person by whom the applicant is employed or represents, and the length of time of such employment or representation;
f. Name and address of employer during the past three (3) years, if other than the present employer;
g. A brief description of the nature and purpose of the business, promotion, solicitation, organization, cause, and/or the goods or services offered;
h. Period of time for which license is sought;
i. The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for license under this section, if any;
j. Whether any similar license issued to the applicant has ever been revoked by any municipality;
k. Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this section or an ordinance of any other municipality
regulating such similar activity;
l. Evidence that the applicant is authorized to solicit for the organization represented;
m. Whether the applicant has been convicted of a felony within the preceding ten (10) years, or convicted of a misdemeanor or ordinance violation
within the preceding ten (10) years, and the nature of the offense.
n. The applicant shall also furnish a form of photo identification, either a valid driver's license or a state issued photo ID, at the time the application is
submitted to the village clerk.
2. Investigation: The application shall be investigated by the police department, which shall conduct a criminal background check to determine whether
the applicant has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor or ordinance violation within the last ten (10) years. The applicant shall pay the cost of
such criminal background investigation, which shall be included within the license fee set forth in subsection B4 of this section.
3. Issuance Prohibited: No license shall be issued to a person who:
a. Submits an application containing any false information;
b. Has been convicted of a felony within the last ten (10) years;
c. Has been convicted of a misdemeanor or ordinance violation within the last ten (10) years, if the basis for the conviction is reasonably related to
the activity for which such license is sought.
4. License Fee: The annual license fee for activities described in this section shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter, which license fee shall
include the cost of conducting a criminal background investigation and of furnishing a photo identification card to the licensee.
C. Regulations For Peddlers, Commercial Solicitors, Solicitors And Itinerant Vendors:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the activities regulated by subsection B of this section without first securing a license therefor.
2. Each person shall at all times, while exercising the privilege in the village incident to such license, carry and display upon his person a photo
identification card which shall be issued by the village at the time that the license is issued. Such identification card shall be required to be returned
to the village upon the expiration of the license. A fee for the cost of furnishing such identification card shall be included in the license fee identified in
subsection B4 of this section.
3. It shall be unlawful for any such person to remain upon any private property after having been asked by the owner or occupant thereof to leave such
property.
4. It shall be unlawful for any such person who is uninvited by the owner or occupant to engage in such licensed activity upon any private premises or
residence or business located thereon, if such premises or residence has posted thereon a sign which reads "No Solicitation" in a location which is
reasonably visible to persons who intend to enter upon such property.
5. It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in such licensed activity to use any plan, scheme or ruse or make any statement which indicates or
implies that the purpose of such person's solicitation is other than to obtain orders for or to make sales of goods or services.
6. No such person shall interfere with either vehicular or pedestrian traffic on the public right of way.
7. It shall be unlawful for any such person to perform the licensed activity by shouting or by using any sound device in connection with such licensed
activity, including bells or amplifying systems.
D. Revocation Of License: The village council may revoke licenses required by this section upon receipt of information or upon its own investigation, after
hearing and upon notice to the holder of the license, by reason of the violation of any provisions of this section or the misrepresentation of any
statement set forth in the application for such license.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 85/416
E. Noncommercial Solicitors:
1. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit funds for charitable, religious, patriotic or philanthropic purposes within the village
without first securing a permit therefor. This provision shall not apply to any organization operated without profit where the solicitation is among its
members or in the form of contributions or donations at the regular services of any church, society, lodge, benevolent order or fraternity or similar
organizations and such organizations are exempt from the following subsections regulating solicitations. All noncommercial solicitors, as the term is
defined in subsection A of this section, shall submit to the village clerk evidence of compliance with all federal and state requirements for the
organization for which the applicant seeks to solicit. Solicitors for national or local organizations who have obtained a permit and have engaged in
noncommercial solicitation in the village for over five (5) years shall not be required to submit an application for permit required in this subsection,
provided such organization may be required to register the names and addresses of its solicitors with the chief of police. No fee shall be charged for
a noncommercial solicitor.
2. Application: Any person not exempt by the preceding subsection desiring to engage in the solicitation of funds for charitable, religious, patriotic or
philanthropic purposes, shall file with the village clerk an application for a permit, which permit shall state the name of the organization applying for
the permit, its address and headquarters, the names and address of its principal officers and manager, the purpose for which the solicitation is made,
the name of the person by whom the receipts shall be disbursed, the name and address of the person in direct charge of conducting the solicitation,
an outline of the methods to be used in conducting the solicitation, the beginning and ending of the period of such solicitation, the amount of wages,
fees, commissions, expenses or emoluments to be paid to anyone in connection with the solicitation, to whom paid and the amount thereof, a
financial statement for the last fiscal year including the amount raised and the cost of raising it and its final disposition, a statement of the character of
work done by the organization within the village, such other information as may be required by the village council in order for it to fully determine the
kind and character of the proposed solicitation, and whether such a solicitation is in the interest of and not inimical to the public welfare, and the
statement that the permit will not be used or represented as an endorsement by the village council.
3. Investigation: Upon receipt of the application provided for in the preceding subsection, the council shall make, or cause to be made, such
investigation as it shall deem necessary, and if satisfied that the solicitation is for a bona fide charitable, religious, patriotic or philanthropic purpose,
and is prompted solely by a desire to finance the cause in question, that the persons in charge of the solicitation are responsible and reliable
persons, the village council shall then direct the village clerk to issue a permit to such organization for a period not to exceed one month.
4. Revocation: The village council may revoke permits required by this section upon receipt of information or upon its own investigation, after hearing
and upon notice to the holder of a permit, by reason of the violation of any provision of this section or the misrepresentation of any statement set
forth in the application for such permit.
5. Exemption: The following organizations or individuals shall be exempt from the provisions of this subsection E:
a. Scouting organizations;
b. Campfire Girls;
c. Children's sports organizations;
d. Children soliciting for school supported activities.
F. Hours Of Operation:
1. Noncommercial solicitors shall be permitted to solicit from ten thirty o'clock (10:30) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. local time, Monday through
Saturday. Soliciting shall not be conducted at any other times.
2. Peddlers, solicitors (other than noncommercial), itinerant vendors and commercial solicitors shall not engage in such activity except between nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. local time on Monday through Friday. (Ord. O-17-05, 5-9-2005)
3-5A-8: SECONDHAND DEALERS:
A. License Required: No person shall operate or conduct a secondhand store without first having obtained a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-217)
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for a secondhand store shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-218)
C. Records Kept: Every person operating a secondhand store shall keep a record of all articles purchased and sold, which shall be open to the inspection
of the police department at all times. (Village Code § 11-219)
3-5A-9: JUNK SHOPS:
A. License Required:
1. No person shall exercise, carry on or engage in the business of keeping a junk shop, or what is commonly called a junk shop, for the purchase, sale,
barter, exchange or other dealing in or storage of: rags, paper, bagging, old rope, old iron, brass, copper, tin, slush, lead, empty bottles or other junk;
nor exercise, engage in or carry on any such business at any other house or place, other than that designated in his license; nor draw, drive or cause
to be drawn or driven through the streets of this village any handcart, wheelbarrow or other car or vehicle, for the purpose of collecting or disposing
of such article; nor shall any person be entitled to have a cart, or carts, or other vehicle or vehicles to be used for the aforesaid purpose without first
obtaining a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-132)
2. A separate license shall be obtained by every junk dealer for each cart, wagon or other vehicle used in his business. (Village Code § 11-134)
3. No keeper of a junk shop shall, during the period of his license as such, receive or hold a license to carry on the business of a pawnbroker or of a
secondhand dealer. (Village Code § 11-140)
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for a junk shop shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-133)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 86/416
C. Bond: Every person licensed under the provisions of this section shall, at the time of receiving his license, execute a bond to the village, with good and
sufficient sureties to be approved by the village council, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned for the due observance of all
ordinances of the village, now in force, or which may hereafter be passed, respecting the keeping of junk shops and junk wagons. (Village Code § 11-
137)
D. Location Restrictions:
1. Every license granted to any keeper of a junk shop shall designate the house or place in which the person receiving such license, shall be
authorized to carry on such business. (Village Code § 11-135)
2. No person shall locate, establish, conduct or maintain any junk shop or junk yard within four hundred feet (400') of any church, hospital, public or
parochial school. Said distance shall be measured by the shortest, straight line between the junk shop or junkyard sought to be located and
established, conducted or maintained, and any such building used for the purpose of a church, hospital or parochial or public school. (Village Code
§ 11-146)
3. In case any person, so licensed as aforesaid, shall remove his place of business from the place designated in such license, he shall immediately
give notice to the village collector, and have the change noted upon such license. (Village Code § 11-136)
E. Vehicle Requirements: Every vehicle used in the collection of junk shall be marked on the outside of such vehicle, in letters and figures at least two
inches (2") in height, with the name and address of the licensee. When the location for the business licensed hereunder is changed, the new location
shall be changed on the sides of the vehicle used by such licensed dealer, and made to correspond with such new place of business. (Village Code
§§ 11-136, 11-138)
F. Conditions Of License:
1. Services Offered: No keeper of a junk shop shall receive any article or thing by way of pledge or pawn, nor shall he loan or advance any sum of
money on the security of any article or thing. (Village Code § 11-139)
2. Purchases From Minors Prohibited: No keeper of a junk shop shall purchase any articles of whatsoever nature from any minors without the written
consent of their parents or guardians under a penalty as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code for each offense. (Village Code
§ 11-141; amd. 2004 Code)
3. Time Of Possession: No keeper of a junk shop shall expose for sale, sell or dispose of any article or articles within ten (10) days of the time of
purchasing the same, nor until the same has been in the premises, wherein the same are offered, exposed or sold, at least ten (10) days, under a
penalty as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code. (Village Code § 11-142; amd. 2004 Code)
4. Hours Of Operation: No keeper of a junk shop shall purchase, in the way of his business, any goods, articles or things from any person between the
hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Village Code § 11-143)
5. Lost Or Stolen Goods: Every keeper of a junk shop, who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things which may have been lost
or stolen, or alleged or supposed to have been lost or stolen, shall forthwith, on demand, exhibit the same to any member of the police department.
(Village Code § 11-144)
6. Disturbing The Peace: It shall be unlawful for any person conducting or maintaining a junkyard, to break up old boilers, iron or other junk by means
of hammers, sledges or other mechanical devices in such a manner as to disturb the peace and quiet of the residents in the immediate vicinity of any
such secondhand store, junk shop or junk yard; or to do any other act or acts which will disturb the peace and quiet of any such resident. (Village
Code § 11-147)
7. Sanitary Requirements: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or maintain any such junk place of business, as herein described, in such
manner that the premises, and the sidewalks in front thereof, are kept and permitted to remain in an unsanitary condition. (Village Code § 11-148)
G. Supervision And Inspection: The chief of police by himself, or by any officer designated by him, shall have general supervision over all keepers of junk
shops; and shall also have the power to inspect their respective places of business, and all articles or things kept therein, whenever he shall deem it
necessary so to do. (Village Code § 11-145)
3-5A-10: RESIDENTIAL (GARAGE AND YARD) SALES:
A. Defined: A residential sale includes the sale of more than five (5) items of personal property from a residential premises and includes, but is not limited
to, sales designated "garage", "rummage", "estate", "yard", "lawn", "patio", "room", "attic" or "porch" sale. (Village Code § 11-267)
B. Registration: No person shall conduct a residential sale in the village without first submitting an application for such sale with the village clerk who shall
review the same and, provided the applicant qualifies under the provisions of this section, the village clerk shall issue an approved receipt.
C. Fees: The registration fee for a residential sale shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-268)
D. Limitations:
1. No more than two (2) sales may be conducted by any member of a family, or an estate in any residence during any calendar year. Participation by a
person or representative of an estate in any other residence sale shall be considered one sale for such participant.
2. A residential sale shall be conducted during daylight hours and for not more than three (3) days.
3. Personal property offered for sale may not be displayed in any front yard or any public property adjacent to the residential premises.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 87/416
4. Signs advertising such sale may not be posted on public property or any public way. Any signs posted on public property or on any public way will be
removed and the permit holder will be charged twenty five dollars ($25.00) per sign for removal. A double faced sign not exceeding six (6) square
feet may be posted on the premises during the time the sale is being conducted. (Village Code § 11-269)
3-5A-11: VENDING MACHINES:
A. Definition:
VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical container or device used for the sale or offering for sale of any article, the operating of which is governed or
controlled by the deposit of a coin or token.
B. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of installing, keeping or maintaining vending machines within the village
without first having obtained a license therefor. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, use or permit to be used, upon his premises any vending
machine owned and operated by a person who has not obtained a license as herein provided.
C. Application And Inspection: The village clerk shall require the execution of an application form with all of the information to be required included thereon,
including the name and home address of the applicant, together with the business and business address and the type of machine and place where said
machine is to be installed.
The health officer of the village shall cause an inspection to be made of the premises where any food vending machine is to be placed and shall also
inspect the food vending machine. (Ord. O-19-77, 6-27-1977)
D. License Fee: The annual license fee shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Ord. O-19-77, 6-27-1977; amd. Ord. O-49-01, 12-10-2001)
E. Requirements: No food vending machine shall be installed or kept in any toilet or washroom. The health officer of the village shall make periodic
inspections of the place of business of the food vending machines and the articles of food purveyed therefrom.
The health officer shall also see that all such equipment and food products are in a clean, sanitary and wholesome condition. (Ord. O-19-77, 6-27-
1977)
ARTICLE B. SERVICE BUSINESSES AND ESTABLISHMENTS
3-5B-1: AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an auction or to do business as an auctioneer without having first obtained a license
therefor.
B. License Fee: The fee for auctioneers shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-1)
C. Requirements And Restrictions:
1. Auctions In Public Places: No person shall sell or attempt to sell at public auction any goods, wares, merchandise or other things upon any street,
alley or public place in the village. (Village code § 11-2)
2. Disturbances: All auctions shall be conducted in an orderly manner, and it shall be unlawful to create or permit any disturbance or disorderly conduct
at any auction. (Village code § 11-3)
3-5B-2: BARBERSHOPS:
A. Definition: A "barbershop" is hereby defined to mean any place maintained or conducted, where shaving and/or haircutting of men, women or children,
or other tonsorial work, is carried on. (Village code § 11-13)
B. License Required: No person shall operate a barbershop without having first obtained a license therefor. (Village code § 11-14)
C. License Fee: The annual fee shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-15)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Sanitary Requirements: All places used as barbershops shall be kept in a clean, proper and sanitary condition. All necessary measures shall be
taken to properly safeguard the life and health of all patrons and persons employed therein against communicable and contagious diseases. (Village
code § 11-16)
2. Hygienic Requirements: All persons employed or working in any barbershop shall be clean and free from disease. All towels and washcloths used
shall be washed with soap and water and boiled before each use. All receptacles, finger bowls, utensils, vessels and other appliances shall be kept
in a clean and sanitary condition. Receptacles used for soiled articles shall be of metal construction or other impervious material. Headrests must be
covered with a clean cloth or paper, and such covers must be renewed after each use by a patron. All scissors, clippers, razors, combs and brushes
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 88/416
must be kept clean and free from infected material and must be thoroughly sterilized by the use of an approved disinfectant, or by boiling after use on
each person. (Village code § 11-17)
E. Revocation Of License: The director of public health and safety may, at any time, recommend a revocation of any license issued under the terms of this
section. The village council shall revoke such license whenever it shall appear that a licensee has violated the provisions of any law or ordinance.
Procedures for revocation of licenses are found at section 3-1-6 of this title. (Village code § 11-18; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
3-5B-3: BEAUTY PARLORS:
A. Definition: A "beauty parlor" is herein defined to mean any building, room, place or establishment or established for the purpose of cosmetic or
beautifying treatments, wherein is carried on the application of cosmetic preparations to the human body by the use of devices, apparatus, appliances
or other means; or, whenever it takes place, the arranging, dressing, marcelling, curling, waving, cleansing, singeing, bleaching, coloring, dyeing, tinting
or other treatments, to the hair of any person. (Village code § 11-19)
B. License Required: No person shall establish, maintain or operate any "beauty parlor", as defined herein, without first having obtained a license therefor.
(Village code § 11-20)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for a beauty parlor shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-21)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Sanitary Requirements: It shall be the duty of every person licensed to conduct a beauty parlor to, at all times, keep the premises wherein such
establishments are conducted in a clean and sanitary condition. All measures must be taken to properly safeguard the life and health of all patrons of
such establishments. (Village code § 11-22)
2. Hygienic Requirements: No person suffering from a contagious or communicable disease, shall be employed in a beauty parlor. All scissors,
clippers, tweezers, razors, scalpels, combs, brushes or other instruments must be kept free and clean from infected material, and must be thoroughly
sterilized by the application of an approved disinfectant or by boiling after each use upon a patron. Shaving mugs and brushes must be thoroughly
scalded before being used by any person. Headrests must be covered with a clean cloth or paper, and such covering shall be removed after each
use by a patron. (Village code § 11-23)
E. Revocation Of License: The director of public health and safety may, at any time, recommend the revocation of any license issued under the terms of
this section. The village council shall revoke any license whenever it shall appear to their satisfaction that a licensee has violated the provisions of any
law or ordinance. Procedures for revocation of licenses are found at section 3-1-6 of this title. (Village code § 11-24; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. O-7-10, 2-
8-2010)
3-5B-4: BENCHES:
A. Definition: A "bench" is a seat, located upon public property along any public way for the accommodation of passersby awaiting transportation. (Village
code § 11-25)
B. Permit Required:
1. Required: No person shall install or maintain any bench on any street without a permit. A separate permit must be obtained for each bench, which
permit shall be valid only for the particular location specified thereon. Each permit shall bear a separate number, and not more than two (2) permits
shall be issued for any one location. (Village code § 11-27)
