2. Application Denied: The application shall be denied if the village council shall find that the maintenance of the bench would tend to obstruct passage
along any public way, or to create a hazard, or would otherwise be detrimental to the public safety, welfare or convenience. (Village code § 11-29)
3. Permit Displayed: Each bench must have displayed thereon, in a conspicuous place, the name of the permittee and the permit number. (Village code
§ 11-35)
4. Time Limitation: Any permit issued under this section shall be canceled and revoked if the permittee fails to install the bench within sixty (60) days
after the date of the issuance of the permit. (Village code § 11-32)
5. Revocation Of Permit: Any permit may be revoked, or renewal thereof denied, for any violation or any of the provisions of this section, for any fraud
or misrepresentation in the application or any reason which would have been grounds for denial of the application. Procedures for revocation of
licenses are found at section 3-1-6 of this title. (Village code § 11-30; amd. 2004 Code)
C. Fees: Annual fees shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. The application shall be canceled and denied if the applicant fails to deposit the
annual fee and accept the permit within ten (10) days after notice of the approval of the application by the village council. (Village Code §§ 11-28, 11-
31)
D. Insurance Requirements:
1. Insurance Required:
a. No permit shall be issued pursuant to this section unless the applicant shall post and maintain with the village council a policy of public liability
insurance approved by the village council and conditioned as hereinafter provided.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 89/416
b. The policy shall be conditioned that the permittee will indemnify and save harmless the village, its officers and employees, from any and all loss,
costs, damages, expenses or liability which may result from or arise out of the granting of the permit, or the installation or maintenance of the
bench for which the permit is issued. The permittee will pay any and all loss or damage that may be sustained by any person as a result of, or
which may be caused by or arise out of such installation or maintenance. The policy of insurance shall be maintained in its original amount by the
permittee at his expense at all times during the period for which the permit is in effect. In the event that two (2) or more permits are issued to one
permittee, one such policy of insurance may be furnished to cover two (2) or more benches. Each policy shall be of such a type that its coverage
shall be automatically restored immediately from and after the time of the reporting of any accident from which liability may thereafter accrue.
(Village Code § 11-41)
2. Insurance Limits: The limits of liability upon any policy of insurance, posted pursuant to the requirements of this section, shall, in no case, be less
than thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) for bodily injuries or death of one person. The permissible limit of liability for bodily injuries or death of more
than one person shall depend upon the number of bench permits covered thereby, and shall not be less than the amount specified in the following
schedule:
No. Of Bench Permits Limit Of Liability
1 to 10 $ 30,000.00
11 to 50 40,000.00
51 to 100 60,000.00
101 or more 100,000.00
(Village Code § 11-42)
E. Conditions Of Permit:
1. Location: The village council shall designate the locations where said benches are to be erected. (Village Code § 11-40)
2. Distance From Curbs: No permittee shall locate or maintain any bench at a point less than eighteen inches (18") or more than thirty inches (30") from
the face of the curb, and each bench must be kept parallel with the curb. (Village Code § 11-33)
3. Dimensions: No bench shall be more than forty two inches (42") high, nor more than two feet six inches (2'6") wide, nor more than seven feet (7')
long overall. (Village Code § 11-34)
F. Advertising On Benches:
1. Placement: No advertising matter or sign shall be displayed upon any bench except upon the front and rear surfaces of the backrest, and not more
than seventy five percent (75%) of each such surface shall be used. (Village Code § 11-37)
2. Create Traffic Distractions: No advertisement or sign on any bench shall display the words "stop", "look", "drive-in", "danger" or any other word,
phrase, symbol or character calculated to interfere with, mislead or distract traffic. (Village Code § 11-38)
G. Prohibited Locations: Benches are prohibited in the following locations:
1. In any alley.
2. At any location where the distance from the face of the curb to the property line is less than eight feet (8').
3. At any location, at a distance more than fifty feet (50') from the nearest intersecting street. Provided that, wherever, in the opinion of the village
council, observance of this requirement would result in inconvenience or hardship, this requirement may be waived by the village council.
4. At any place, except an existing street railway stop or passenger bus stop. (Village Code § 11-26)
H. Inspection And Maintenance: It shall be the duty of the permittee to maintain such bench at all times in a safe condition and at its proper and lawful
location, and to inspect each bench periodically. The director of public health and safety shall supervise the maintenance and erection of all benches
under the provisions of this section. (Village code §§ 11-36, 11-39; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
3-5B-5: DRUGSTORES AND DRUGGISTS:
A. Definition:
RETAIL DRUGSTORE: Any establishment where prescriptions for drugs or medicines are filled or compounded; or where medicines, drugs, chemicals,
therapeutic preparations, druggist sundries, invalid and infant foods, physicians' supplies, proprietary medicines, toilet articles and other articles
commonly sold in drugstores are sold, offered for sale or kept with the intention of selling at retail or supplying to physicians, dentists, veterinarians or
other practitioners. (Village code § 11-86)
B. License Required: No person shall operate a drugstore without having first obtained a license therefor. (Village code § 11-87)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for such a license shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-88)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 90/416
D. Sanitary Requirements: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any drugstore in an unsanitary condition. Unsanitary conditions shall be deemed
to exist if drugs, medicines or food preparations, used in the process of drugs or other articles, are not securely protected from flies or other insects or
vermin; from dust, dirt or other foreign or injurious matter; or if refuse, dirt or waste products are allowed to accumulate; or if measures, containers or
other utensils or apparatus are not kept clean; or if the clothing of operatives or persons employed in the handling or preparation of drugs, medicines or
food preparation is unclean; or if adequate toilet facilities, soap and clean towels are not provided for in such drugstores. (Village code § 11-89)
3-5B-6: DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENTS:
A. Definition:
DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENT: Any structure, store, building or other place where the service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning (as a process
incidental to dry cleaning), dyeing, spotting and/or finishing any cloth fabric is rendered as a business. (Village code § 11-90)
B. License Required: No person shall conduct, operate or maintain any dry cleaning establishment in the village without having first obtained a license
therefor. (Village code § 11-91)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for such cleaning establishments shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-92)
D. Sanitary Requirements: A dry cleaning establishment shall be kept free from inflammable wastes so far as possible. It shall be unlawful to maintain or
permit a stove or open flame of any kind on the premises. Smoking on such premises is hereby prohibited, and appropriate signs to that effect shall be
posted in conspicuous places in the establishment. The premises must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, free from rats, mice and vermin. No
person afflicted with a contagious or venereal disease shall be employed in any such establishment. (Village code § 11-93)
E. Inspections: It shall be the duty of the fire chief, or his duly authorized officer, to inspect each dry cleaning establishment at least once every six (6)
months. (Village code § 11-94)
3-5B-7: LAUNDRIES AND LAUNDERETTES:
A. Laundries:
1. Definition:
LAUNDRY: Any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion thereof which is used for the purpose of washing, drying, starching or
ironing shirts, dresses, underwear, collars, cuffs or other wearing apparel; table, bed or other household linens, towels, curtains, draperies or other
washable fabrics for the general public. It also includes any private laundry maintained or operated in connection with any hotel, restaurant or public
institution, except a hospital, school or charitable institution, where no charge is made for laundry services. (Village code § 11-149)
2. License Required: No person shall operate the business of a "laundry", as defined in this section, without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village
code § 11-150)
3. License Fee: The annual license fee for maintaining and operating a laundry shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-
152)
4. Conditions Of License:
a. Hygienic And Sanitary Requirements: No person shall be permitted to sleep in any laundry; nor shall any sleeping room or living room, be in direct
communication with any laundry. No laundered or unlaundered fabric belonging to the trade of any laundry shall be stored or kept in any room
which is used for living purposes. (Village code § 11-153)
b. Maintenance Required: Every room or place used as a laundry, or for the storage of unlaundered or laundered fabrics in connection therewith,
shall at all times be kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition; and shall be kept free from rats, mice, vermin and all
matters of an infectious or contagious nature.
c. Employees: No person who has a contagious disease, tuberculosis or other similar malady shall work in any laundry. (Village code § 11-154)
d. Plumbing And Drainage: Every laundry shall be provided with adequate sanitary plumbing and drainage facilities. (Village code § 11-155)
e. Segregation Of Fabrics: Every person owning, managing or conducting any laundry shall be required to provide proper facilities and equipment for
the separate handling of clean and soiled fabrics. No clean or laundered fabrics shall be allowed to come in contact with any unlaundered or soiled
fabrics of any kind at any time. (Village code § 11-156)
5. Inspections: It shall be the duty of the director of public health and safety to inspect, or cause to be inspected, at least three (3) times per year, all
premises wherein laundries are conducted, for the purpose of ascertaining whether the provisions of this section and the laws of the state of Illinois
are being complied with. (Village code § 11-157; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
6. Revocation: A license issued under this section may be revoked for cause by the village council, upon a report by the director of public health and
safety, that the maintenance of any laundry is detrimental to the health and welfare of the residents of the village. Procedures for revocation of
licenses are found at section 3-1-6 of this title. (Village code § 11-151; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
B. Launderettes:
1. Definition:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 91/416
LAUNDERETTE: Any place, building or structure having one or more automatic washing machines, which are rented, leased or hired out to the
public for consideration and for use upon the premises. (Village code § 11-158)
2. License Required: No person shall operate the business of "launderette", as defined in this section, without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village
code § 11-159)
3. License Fee: The annual license fee shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-160)
4. Sanitary Requirements: Every launderette shall be kept and maintained in a clean, sanitary condition at all times. (Village code § 11-161)
5. Inspections: The director of public health and safety shall inspect every launderette, at least three (3) times per year, in order to determine that the
provisions of this section and the laws of the state of Illinois are being complied with. (Village code § 11-162; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
3-5B-8: AMBULANCES:
A. License Required: No person shall own or operate any ambulance used for the purpose of transporting sick or injured persons in the village without
obtaining a license therefor. A license shall not be required for any ambulance operated by the United States, state, county, municipal or other
governmental agency but shall conform to all other regulatory portions of this section. (Village Code § 11-102)
B. Application For License: Application for an ambulance license shall be made as required by this code for other licenses on the form supplied by the
village. If the ambulance is to be garaged in the village, the village will cause an investigation to be made of location where the ambulance will be
garaged to determine whether or not the site is sanitary.
The ambulance shall also be inspected to determine whether or not the ambulance is being maintained in a safe, sanitary and healthful manner, carries
the proper equipment to transport the sick and injured, and to ascertain compliance with all national, state and local laws. No license shall be issued
unless the inspections of the premises and/or ambulance are satisfactory. (Village Code § 11-103)
C. License Fee: The license fee for such license shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-104)
D. Village Ambulance:
1. Service: Ambulance service by the village shall be available to a sick or injured person in emergency cases from locations in the village where such
person was stricken by sickness or injured, and except for emergency situations, to be transported to the nearest hospital as selected by a physician
or legal guardian but, in the absence of such selection, to the nearest hospital of the following hospitals as determined by the ambulance crew to be
reasonably specialized in the illness or injury of the patient: Oak Park Hospital, West Suburban, MacNeal, Hines V.A. or Loyola, except that,
whenever possible, trauma victims shall be taken to Loyola. (Ord. O-20-98, 6-22-1998)
2. Fees: The fees to be charged for ambulance service shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter.
It shall be the intent of the village to collect all monies owed for services rendered, with no distinction between residents and nonresidents, other than
the fees charged.
The rate shall be adjusted on January 1 of each year considering, among other factors, the inflation factors relating to increases in the consumer
price index. (Ord. O-35-05, 7-26-2005)
3-5B-9: EXPRESS SERVICES:
A. License Required: No person shall operate the business of expressing, carting, delivering or operating hearses, omnibuses, limousine service or other
vehicles for hire, without first obtaining a license therefor.
B. Designation: Every vehicle used for such business shall have printed thereon, in a place easily visible from the side of the vehicle, the name and
address of the owner, in letters legible to one of normal eyesight at a distance of twenty five feet (25').
C. License Fee: The license fee shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Ord. O-4-90, 3-12-1990)
3-5B-10: HOTELS:
A. Definition:
HOTEL: Every building, which is not a rooming house, and which is maintained as an inn, hotel, motel, family hotel or apartment hotel, with or without
meals, in which three (3) or more sleeping rooms are used, or maintained, for the accommodation of guests. (Village Code § 11-126)
B. License Required: No person shall own, operate or maintain a hotel without having first obtained a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-127)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for such license, shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter, and shall be payable in advance. (Village Code
§ 11-128)
D. Sanitary Requirements: Every hotel shall be kept clean and free from any accumulation of dirt or similar material. The owner, operator or manager of
any hotel shall thoroughly cleanse the premises to the satisfaction of the director of public health and safety, and every hotel, and part thereof, shall be
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 92/416
kept in good repair. (Village code §§ 11-129, 11-130; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
E. Inspections: Every hotel in the village shall be inspected by the director of public health and safety at least once each year. Such inspection shall cover
all matters pertaining to the sanitary conditions of the premises, including the ventilation of all rooms; and the condition of such rooms with respect to
light, heat, ventilation and general sanitation. (Village code § 11-131; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
3-5B-11: ROOMING HOUSES:
A. Definition:
ROOMING HOUSE: Every dwelling house, furnished room house, lodging house, boarding house and any other similarly occupied building, structure
or portion thereof, kept, held or used, where sleeping or lodging is provided for compensation for three (3) or more persons for a definite period; except
for housing of a college or institution, not operated for profit. (Village code § 11-207)
B. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, keep, manage or operate a rooming house without first obtaining a license therefor.
(Village code § 11-208)
C. License Fee: The annual fee for rooming houses shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-209)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Compliance With Code: All rooming houses shall comply with the housing code of the village1. (Village code § 11-210)
2. Inspections: The director of public health and safety shall inspect all rooming houses at least three (3) times per year. (Village code § 11-211; amd.
Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
3. Register Kept: The manager and/or operator of every rooming house shall keep a register in which shall be entered the name and residence of every
person who becomes a lodger, boarder or guest therein. (Village code § 11-212)
3-5B-12: NURSING HOMES:
A. Definition:
NURSING HOME: Any institution or place used for the reception or care of three (3) or more persons who are dependent, or not capable of properly
caring for themselves; and shall include homes for the aged or infirm, refugees and shelters. (Village code § 11-184)
B. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the regularly constituted authorities of the United States, state, county or village, or any
other association or institution which has been accredited, certified or licensed by the state of Illinois, pursuant to an act of the legislature to regulate
the treatment and control of the aged and infirm, to open, conduct, manage or maintain any home, as defined in this section, without first having
obtained a license therefor. (Village code § 11-185)
C. License Fee: The annual fee for a nursing home shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-186)
3-5B-13: SCAVENGERS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a scavenger, or the collection or disposal of animal, human or
vegetable refuse or offal, without having first obtained a license therefor. (Village code § 11-213)
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for a scavenger shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this code. (Ord. O-16-02, 3-25-2002)
C. Conditions Of License:
1. Vehicles: All vehicles used by a scavenger in his business shall be watertight and equipped with airtight covers, for such portions as are used for the
transportation of refuse. (Village code § 11-215)
2. Disposal: It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in any place within the village or within one mile thereof. (Village
code § 11-216)
3-5B-14: UNDERTAKERS:
A. License Requirements:
1. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain an undertaking establishment, or to operate as an undertaker or mortician without
first having obtained a license therefor. (Village code § 11-245)
2. License Fee: The annual license fee for an undertaker shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-246)
3. Buildings And Premises:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 93/416
a. Specifications: No person shall be licensed to carry on the business of undertaking in any establishment, store or place unless such
establishment, store or place used for the undertaking business shall be provided with a compartment, or room, completely shut off from other
parts of such establishment, store or place. Such compartment or room shall have free outside ventilation and light and its floor shall be
constructed of, or covered with, a nonabsorbent material. The premises shall be connected with a sewer by an approved deep water seal trap, and
all drains from this compartment or room shall be drained by a vitrified tile sewer, which shall not be less than six inches (6") internal diameter.
Said sewer shall begin outside the wall of the building, and shall separately and independently connect such drains with the public sewer in the
street. The walls of the room, to a height of five feet (5') above floor level, shall be constructed of, or covered with, a nonabsorbent material.
(Village code § 11-247)
b. Ventilation:
(1) Windows: In every building, establishment, store or place hereafter erected or converted to carry on the business of undertaking, every room or
anteroom, where practicable, shall have a window, or windows, opening directly upon a street, alley, yard or court. The total area of such
window, or windows, shall be at least ten percent (10%) of the floor area and at least one-half (1/2) of each window shall be made to open.
(Village code § 11-248)
(2) Mechanical: If it is impractical to ventilate such room, or rooms, or anteroom as aforesaid, such room, rooms or anterooms shall be ventilated
by an approved, mechanical ventilation supply system, which system shall supply at least one and two-tenths (12/10) cubic feet of air, per
minute, per square foot of floor area. The supply shall be taken from the outer air, at an uncontaminated source, through a screened opening, at
a point not less than ten feet (10') above the street level; except that, if an air washer or other cleansing medium approved by the director of
public health and safety, is installed in connection with the system, the supply need not be taken from this height. (Village code § 11-249; amd.
Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
It shall be the duty of the owner, agent, architect or party in possession or control of any building, establishment, store or place hereafter erected
or converted, who carries on the business of undertaking in which a mechanical system of ventilation shall have been installed, under the
requirements of this section, upon completion of such system, to notify the director of public health and safety, in writing, at least twenty four (24)
hours in advance of the making of a test of such system. Each such system, or unit, shall be tested for volumetric efficiency by the owner, or his
representative or the director of public health and safety. Such system shall not be considered as meeting the requirements of this section until it
shall have been approved by the director of public health and safety. Every such mechanical ventilating system shall, at all times, be kept in
good repair and operation, so as to ensure the required ventilation of all rooms and compartments planned to be ventilated thereby, during all
hours of human occupancy. (Village code § 11-250; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
4. Applicability Of Provisions: Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as requiring alterations in the construction or equipment of buildings,
establishments, stores or places in existence in which the business of undertaking is being actively carried on at the time of the passage of this
section; and which, at the time of their construction, were built in compliance with the ordinances then in force. (Village code § 11-251)
5. Multiple Locations: Any license, issued as hereinbefore provided, shall entitle the licensee to engage in, carry on or conduct the business of
undertaking only at and from the store, room or place designated in such license. If the applicant for such license shall desire to carry on, conduct or
engage in the business of undertaking at more than one store, room or place in the village, he shall be permitted to do so only upon payment of a
license fee as provided in subsection A2 of this section for such store, room or place. (Village code § 11-252)
6. Operators: No person other than a licensed undertaker or licensed assistant, shall be permitted to manage or control any undertaking room, store,
place or establishment; or to prepare dead bodies for burial or cremation (other than the embalming by a state licensed embalmer); or to conduct
funerals in the capacity of an undertaker. (Village code § 11-253)
B. Dead Bodies:
1. Exposure: No person shall retain, expose or allow to be retained or exposed the dead body of any human being. (Village code § 11-254)
2. Public Exhibition: It shall be unlawful for any person to make public display of, or in any way place on exhibition, the dead body of a person.
Provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to prevent the display of a body to relatives and friends. (Village code
§ 11-255)
3. Duty Of Discovery: It shall be the duty of every person who has discovered the body of a dead human being to notify the police. (Village code § 11-
256)
3-5B-15: VETERINARY HOSPITALS:
A. License Required: No person shall operate the business of a veterinary hospital without first having obtained a license therefor. (Village code § 11-257)
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for each veterinary hospital shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-258)
C. Sanitary Requirements: All veterinary hospitals shall be kept free and clean, and maintained in a sanitary condition, satisfactory to the director of public
health and safety. (Village code § 11-259; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
D. Disturbing The Peace: No person licensed under this section, shall keep or harbor any animal which, by noises, shall disturb the peace of any family,
individual or neighborhood. (Village code § 11-260)
3-5B-16: CATCH BASIN AND SEWER CLEANERS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person within the village to engage in the business of cleaning, collecting or transporting the contents of
catch basins, sewers or kindred refuse by wagon, cart or otherwise or, in any manner, to engage in the business of cleaning catch basins and sewers
without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village code § 11-79)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 94/416
B. Exceptions: Licensed plumbers or licensed sewer builders who may clean catch basins or sewers as an incident to the repair of such catch basins or
sewers, shall not be required to obtain such license. (Village code § 11-80)
C. License Fee: The annual fee for such a license shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-81)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Disposition Of Sewage: The contents taken from catch basins and sewers, in cleaning and repairing the same, shall not be permitted to remain in
any receptacle, wagon or vehicle used to transport and remove such contents. The same shall be transported and disposed of at a place outside of
the village. (Village code § 11-83)
2. Regulations: All substances taken from catch basins and sewers shall be conveyed to the place of disposal, either in closely covered, watertight, iron
or steel wagons, boxes or receptacles, or in closely covered iron, galvanized iron or steel cans or receptacles. It shall be unlawful for any person to
collect or remove materials from catch basins or sewers in wooden receptacles, or to haul them in wooden wagons or boxes. Such carts, vehicles,
receptacles and utensils used in connection with such business, when not in use, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. (Village code § 11-
85)
3. Illegal Storage: No such receptacle or vehicle containing such material shall be permitted to be stored overnight in any building, barn, shed, yard or
place on public or private property. The storage overnight of any of the materials taken from catch basins or sewers upon any premises within the
village, shall be deemed and is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. (Village code § 11-84)
E. Revocation: Any license granted under this section may be revoked upon written notice by the village council to the holder, whenever, upon the
recommendation of the director of public health and safety, it shall be made to appear to the village council that the licensee has violated the provision
of this section or is conducting said business in violation of any other ordinance of the village or laws of the state of Illinois. Procedures for revocation of
licenses are found at section 3-1-6 of this title. (Village code § 11-82; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
3-5B-17: CHILDCARE NURSERIES:
A. Definition:
NURSERY: An institution or place in which are received three (3) or more children, not of common parentage, during part or all of the day or for less
than twenty four (24) hours of continuous care apart from their parents or guardians. The term is further construed to include day nurseries, nursery
schools, group daycare homes, child playgroups or other similar units operating under any other name. The term shall not include kindergartens or
preschools established under proper public school auspices as provided by law; nor kindergartens or nursery schools established in connection with
parochial or other properly established grade schools. (Village code § 11-178)
B. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the regular constituted authorities of the United States, state, county or village, to
conduct or operate a nursery without first having obtained a license therefor. (Village code § 11-179)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for such nursery shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-180)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Structural Requirements: Every nursery shall be adequately ventilated in conformity with the building provisions of this code2. When necessary,
doors and windows of a nursery shall be provided with screens and every appliance necessary for the exclusion of insects. Each nursery shall be
adequately supplied with hot and cold water and toilet facilities. (Village code § 11-181)
2. Sanitary Requirements: Every nursery shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition according to the requirements of the director of public health
and safety. (Village code § 11-182; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
E. Inspections: It shall be the duty of the director of public health and safety to inspect all nurseries not less than three (3) times per year. (Village code
§ 11-183; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
ARTICLE C. MOTOR VEHICLE ESTABLISHMENTS
3-5C-1: AUTOMOBILE ACCESSORY, TIRE AND BODY REPAIR SHOPS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling auto accessories or tires, or to conduct an automotive body
repair shop without having first obtained a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-4)
B. License Fees: License fees are as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code §§ 11-5, 11-6)
C. Conditions Of License:
1. Location: It shall be unlawful for any person to locate, build, construct or maintain any repair shop within two hundred feet (200') of any building used
as and for a hospital, church or school or the grounds thereof. No person shall locate, build, construct or maintain any repair shop in the village on
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 95/416
any street in which two-thirds (2/3) of the buildings on both sides of the street are exclusively for residential purposes, or within one hundred feet
(100') of any such block. (Village Code § 11-7)
2. Sanitary Conditions: All repair shops conducted and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be kept in a clean condition.
Oil, grease, dirt, refuse and inflammable material of any kind shall not be permitted to accumulate in any manner so as to constitute a fire hazard; nor
shall they be carried from any such repair shop onto streets, sidewalks or alleys of the village.
3. Obstructions: Vehicles or obstructions shall not be permitted to block the streets, parkways, sidewalks or alleys near or adjacent to any repair shop.
Vehicles shall not be parked in such a way as to interfere with the free use of the streets, parkways or alleys by the public. (Village Code § 11-8)
3-5C-2: AUTOMOBILE SALESROOMS:
A. Definition:
AUTOMOBILE SALESROOM: Any building, structure, premises, enclosure, lot or other place within the village where the business of dealing in new
and/or used automobiles, trucks or any similar self-propelled vehicles, or parts thereof, is conducted or carried on. (Village Code § 11-9)
B. License Required: No person shall manage, conduct, carry on or operate an automobile salesroom without having first obtained a license therefor.
(Village Code § 11-10)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for each automobile salesroom shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-12)
D. Location: No person shall manage, conduct, carry on or operate an automobile salesroom within two hundred feet (200') of any building used as and for
a hospital, church or school, or the grounds thereof; nor shall any person manage, conduct, carry on or operate an automobile salesroom or used car
lot in the village in any block in which two-thirds (2/3) of the buildings, on both sides of the street, are used exclusively for residence purposes. (Village
Code § 11-11)
3-5C-3: FILLING STATIONS:
A. Definitions:
FILLING STATION: Any place of business where gasoline or any highly volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion engines are sold or
offered for sale at retail and dispensed into the fuel tanks of such motor vehicles. This definition shall also include the private storage and dispensing of
such products, whether the storage is maintained for the use, or benefit, of the owner, lessee, agents or employees of either/or of any others. (Village
Code § 11-105)
B. License Required: No person shall manage, conduct, operate or carry on the business of a filling station without having first obtained a license therefor.
(Village Code § 11-106)
C. License Fees: The annual license fee for a filling station shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-107)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Location: No person shall locate, build, construct or maintain any filling station within two hundred feet (200') of any building used as a church or
school. (Village Code § 11-108)
2. Storage: Except as otherwise permitted by ordinance, storage of flammable liquids shall be outside of buildings. (Village Code § 11-109)
3. Smoking: It shall be unlawful for any person to permit smoking in any filling station. (Village Code § 11-110)
3-5C-4: GARAGES:
A. Definitions:
GARAGE: Any building or structure used for the storing or parking of more than four (4) motor driven vehicles.
STORING OR PARKING: Includes, but is not limited to, storing, parking or display of motor driven vehicles for sale, exchange or repair. (Village Code §
11-118)
B. License Required: No person shall conduct, operate or maintain a garage without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-119)
C. License Fees: The annual license fee for the operation of a garage shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. Provided, however, that the above
fees shall not be charged for spaces allocated for cars that are to be repaired, sold or exchanged. And further provided, no license fee shall be charged
in those cases where a landlord furnishes garage space to provide off-street parking for the use of his tenants only. (Village Code § 11-120)
D. Repairs: No motor vehicle shall be repaired in any garage unless a license for an auto repair shop shall have been obtained. (Village Code § 11-121)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 96/416
E. Inspections: All garages shall be inspected by the building director and the fire chief at least once every three (3) months. (Village Code § 11-122)
3-5C-5: PARKING LOTS:
A. Definition:
PARKING LOT: Any place, premises or enclosure, other than a licensed, public garage, where four (4) or more automobiles may be stored or parked
for compensation. (Village Code § 11-187)
B. License Required: No person shall operate, conduct or maintain a parking lot without obtaining a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-188)
C. License Fees: Fees shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. No license fee shall be charged where a parking lot is established by a landlord
to provide off street parking for the use of tenants only. (Village Code § 11-189)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Barriers: All owners, operators or managers of parking lots shall maintain a substantial barrier on, or adjacent to, the property lines. The barriers
shall be so located that no portion of any vehicle, parked on a lot, shall extend over the property line. (Village Code § 11-190)
2. Surfacing: Parking lots shall be kept free from dust by frequent sprinkling, or the use of calcium chloride or other material so that the same shall not
become a nuisance to adjacent property owners or others. Parking lots shall have a smooth and durable service, adequately drained, that will not
retain water, and which will remain free from dust or other particles. (Village Code § 11-192)
3. Lighting: Where night parking is permitted, parking lots shall at all times be adequately lighted. Lights shall be so arranged so as to reflect the light
away from adjoining lots, where said adjoining lots are used for residential purposes. (Village Code § 11-193)
4. Maintenance: Each licensee shall keep the sidewalks surrounding the parking lot free from dirt, ice, sleet and snow. (Village Code § 11-191)
ARTICLE D. BUILDING CONTRACTORS AND CONSTRUCTION
3-5D-1: BUILDING CONTRACTORS:
A. License Required: No person shall conduct, manage, operate or carry on the business of:
General contractor
Contractor of carpentry work
Contractor of masonry work
Contractor of cement work
Contractor of plastering and lathing
Contractor of structural iron work
Contractor of painting and decorating
Contractor of tile, marble and mosaic
Contractor of tuck pointing and cleaning
or engage in the construction, erection, finishing, repair, wrecking or alteration of buildings or other structures within the limits of the village, without
obtaining a license as hereinafter provided and posting a ten thousand dollar ($10,000.00) surety bond from an insurance company licensed to transact
business in the state of Illinois. The bond shall be conditional upon the faithful observance and performance of the ordinances of the village, and for the
costs of correcting any and all defective work of the contractor. (Ord. O-21-93, 9-13-1993)
B. Application For License: Any person desiring a license to carry on the business of building contractor, as described in subsection A of this section, and
engaged in the construction, erection, finishing, repair, wrecking or alteration of buildings or dwellings, shall make application to the commissioner of
public property; stating the name and residence of the applicant, if an individual; the officials, if a corporation; and the place of business and kind of
contracting business proposed to be carried on by said applicant; and the experience which said applicant has had. (Village code § 11-56; amd. Ord.
O-36-04, 9-13-2004)
C. Investigation And Approval: The commissioner of public property shall: (Village code § 11-57; amd. Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004)
1. Cause an investigation to be made of the statements in such application, and as to whether the applicant has the necessary equipment and
experience to engage in the proposed business. (Village code § 11-57)
2. Transmit to the village council the application together with his recommendation for or against the issuance of such license. Upon payment of the
license fee to the village clerk, the village council shall issue or cause to be issued to the applicant a license. (Village code § 11-58)
D. License Fees: For the purpose of this section, each of the contracting businesses set out in subsection A of this section, including a building wrecking
contractor, shall be and is considered as a separate business, requiring a separate annual license fee as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. Any
contracting business set out in subsection A of this section may, in lieu of an annual license, obtain an individual job license for the fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00). (Village code §§ 11-59, 11-60; amd. Ord. O-43-10, 8-9-2010)
E. Expiration: Every annual license shall expire on April 30 of each year after its issuance. An individual job license shall expire upon completion of the
specific job for which the license was issued. (Ord. O-43-10, 8-9-2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 97/416
3-5D-2: EXCAVATORS:
A. Definition:
EXCAVATOR: A person who, with horses and teams, electrically equipped apparatus, steam shovels or other mechanical device or devices, or by day
labor, excavates, removes or carries away dirt, rock, cinders, building material, sand, debris or other substance or materials in order to construct the
foundation of any house, residence, store or other public or private building or structure requiring a foundation to be constructed below the level of the
street, or any sewer, vault or other like work requiring removal of dirt, rock, sand, debris or other substance. (Village Code § 11-98)
B. License Required: No person shall conduct the business of an excavator without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-99)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee to be paid the village collector under the provisions of this section shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this
chapter. (Village Code § 11-100)
D. Bond: No person shall proceed with the business of excavation without first having given a bond to the village, in the sum of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00), with sureties, approved by the village council and conditioned to keep and save harmless the village, its officers, agents and employees,
from all liability to any person by reason of damage to person or property growing out of the said operation of excavating, as defined herein. Said
person shall also obtain and maintain adequate liability insurance. (Village Code § 11-101)
3-5D-3: MATERIAL YARDS:
A. License Required: No person shall keep, carry on, conduct or maintain a yard or other place for the purpose of storing, keeping for sale, offering for
sale, selling or buying building materials such as stone, gravel, sand, cement, tile, pipe or other building materials; coal, lumber, tools or other
contractor's equipment, without first obtaining a license therefor. A separate license shall be required for each location of a material yard. (Village Code
§§ 11-167, 11-169)
B. License Fee: The annual license fees for a material yard shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-168)
C. Conditions Of License:
1. Change Of Location: If, after the issuance of a license, any changes are made in the location of the business covered thereby, no business shall be
engaged in or carried on at a new location until notice of such change shall have been given by the licensee to the village clerk and consent to the
transfer to such new location is obtained from the village council. (Village Code § 11-170)
2. Fire Protection: No person shall establish, maintain, conduct or operate any material yard unless such place of business is equipped with suitable
fire protection. In each yard, there shall be a standpipe of a diameter of not less than one and one-half inches (11/2"), connected with the water main.
Such standpipe shall be at least five feet (5') in height and connected with a hose of a diameter of not less than, one and one-half inches (11/2") with
sufficient length of hose to reach any part of the premises occupied by such place. Each lumber yard or yard where lumber is stored shall also be
equipped with not less than two (2) fire extinguishers of five (5) gallon capacity each of a make and design approved by the board of fire
underwriters. (Village Code § 11-171)
3-5D-4: ROOFERS:
A. Definition:
ROOFER: Any person who makes a business of roofing, reroofing or repairing roofs on buildings or other structures. (Village Code § 11-203)
B. License Required: No person shall engage in the business of a roofer without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-204)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for a roofer shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. However, in lieu of a license, a roofer may apply for,
and obtain, a permit to repair any specified building within the village upon making an application therefor to the director of public health and safety. In
such case, the permit fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for an individual job where the contract price shall be less than fifty dollars ($50.00). (Village
code § 11-205; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
D. Bond: Before any person shall engage in the business of a roofer, such person shall file with the village clerk a bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00), with sureties, to be approved by the village council, which bond shall be conditioned to save the village harmless from any and all
damages that may accrue to or be chargeable against the village on account of an inconsequence of the use of the public ways of the village in such
roofing business; and further conditioned to require immediate repair and clearing of any portion of the public ways utilized by the roofer. (Village code
§ 11-206)
3-5D-5: SHEET METAL WORKERS:
A. License Required: No person shall conduct a sheet metal work business, which includes hot air furnace installation or repair, metal ceiling or gutter
work, or any kind of sheet metal work, without first obtaining a license therefor. (Village code § 11-220)
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for a sheet metal business shall be as provided in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village code § 11-221)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 98/416
C. Removal Of Wastes: All persons engaged in the business of sheet metal or hot air furnace work shall, upon completion of each job, remove any and all
older surplus metal or other material within forty eight (48) hours. No metal or material shall be placed on vacant lots, streets, alleys or public ways.
(Village code § 11-222)
ARTICLE E. BUSINESSES RELATING TO VEGETATION
3-5E-1: FLORISTS:
A. Definition:
FLORIST: Any person engaged in the business of selling flowers, plants, trees or shrubs of all varieties and description, at wholesale or retail. (Village
Code § 11-111)
B. License Required: No person shall operate the business of florist without first having obtained a license therefor. (Village Code § 11-112)
C. License Fee: The annual license fee for doing business as a florist shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-113)
D. Conditions Of License:
1. Sanitary Requirements: Every establishment where the business of florist is operated shall be kept in a sanitary condition. No decayed,
unwholesome, contaminated or diseased flowers, plants or other vegetation shall be allowed to remain in or about said establishment. The florist
establishment shall be kept clear of rubbish and inflammable matter. (Village Code § 11-114)
2. Use Of Public Ways: It shall be unlawful to use any public street, alley, parkway or sidewalk or any other public place in the village for the display of
flowers, plants or shrubs offered for sale. (Village Code § 11-115)
3-5E-2: FORESTRY AND LANDSCAPING:
A. License Required: No person shall engage in the business of forestry or landscaping without first having obtained a license therefor. The term "forestry
or landscaping", as used in this section, shall mean planting, trimming, removal of trees and shrubs and lawn care.
B. License Fee: The annual fee for such license shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this chapter. (Village Code § 11-116)
C. Bond: Before any person shall be licensed under this section, he shall deposit with the village clerk a bond in the penal sum of twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00) with surety, to be approved by the mayor and village council to indemnify and save harmless the village from any and all loss, costs,
expense or liability of any kind whatsoever which the village may suffer by reason of the issuance of such license, or by reason of any act or thing done
or neglected to be done under or by virtue of the authority given in such license.
D. Insurance: No person licensed under this section shall be permitted to plant, trim or remove any tree or shrub in the village unless such person shall
procure and file with the village clerk a standard form of public liability and property damage insurance, insuring the village, its officers and agents from
any and all liability for damage resulting from such planting, trimming or removal of trees within the village. Such insurance policies shall be written by a
qualified insurance company under the laws of the state of Illinois and shall be in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for one person, one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one accident, and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for property damage. Such insurance policy shall be
kept in effect for as long as the license shall be valid. (Village Code § 11-117)
Chapter 6
NEWSPAPER STANDS AND VENDING MACHINES
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
DISTRIBUTOR: A person, firm or corporation responsible for operating or maintaining a newspaper stand or newspaper vending machine on the public
way in the village.
NEWSPAPER STAND: Any attended structure from which any newspapers, magazines or periodicals are distributed or sold.
NEWSPAPER VENDING MACHINE: Any self-service or coin operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser used for the display and sale of
newspapers or other news periodicals.
PARKWAY: That area between the sidewalk and the curb of any street, and where there is no sidewalk, that area between the edge of the roadway and
property line adjacent thereto.
PUBLIC WAY: All that area dedicated to public use for public street purposes and shall include, but not be limited to, roadways, parkways, alleys and
sidewalks.
ROADWAY: That portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel.
SIDEWALK: Any surface provided for the exclusive use of pedestrians. (Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 99/416
3-6-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE:
A. Permits: It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, place, maintain or operate a newspaper stand or newspaper vending machine on any public way in
the village without first obtaining a permit for such stand or machine from the village clerk.
B. Fee: The annual permit fee for such machine shall be as set out in section 3-5-1 of this title and be due on May 1 of each year and will expire on April
30 of each year, evidenced by a decal in the form prescribed by the village clerk and affixed tosaid newspaper stand or newspaper vending machine.
C. Application For Permit: Application for such permit shall be made in writing to the village clerk upon the form provided, and shall contain the name and
address of the applicant, the proposed specific location of said newspaper vending machine or newspaper stand and shall be signed by the applicant.
(Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
3-6-3: CONDITIONS OF PERMIT:
A. An express condition of the issuance of such permit, the permittee thereby agrees to indemnify and save harmless the village, its officers and
employees against any loss, liability or damage, including expenses and costs for bodily or personal injury, and for property damage sustained by any
person as the result of installation, use or maintenance of the newspaper vending machine or newspaper stand within the village.
B. Permits shall be valid for one year and shall be renewable upon application in the manner prescribed in subsection 3-6-2C of this chapter and upon
payment of a permit fee.
C. No permit for a newspaper vending machine or newspaper stand shall be issued unless the applicant shall first procure and deliver to the village clerk a
liability and property damage insurance policy in a company and form satisfactory to the village clerk, protecting the village, its officers and agents,
against any and all liability for damages resulting from the installation, use or maintenance of the machine or stand covered by the permit, for not less
than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one person killed or injured in a single accident; not less than two hundred thousand dollars
($200,000.00) for two (2) or more persons killed or injured in any one accident, and not less than twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for property
damage in any one accident. Such insurance shall be kept in force by the applicant with initial and renewal premiums prepaid in advance of the periods
covered, so long as the machine or stand for which the permit issued shall remain on the public way. (Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
3-6-4: STANDARDS FOR MAINTENANCE AND INSTALLATION:
A. No newspaper vending machine shall exceed five feet (5') in height, thirty inches (30") in width or two feet (2') in depth.
B. Newspaper stands shall not exceed six feet (6') in height nor occupy more than ten (10) square feet.
C. No newspaper vending machine or stand shall be used for advertising signs or publicity purposes other than the display, sale or purchase of the
newspaper or news periodical sold therein.
D. Each newspaper vending machine shall have affixed in a readily visible place the name and address of the distributor and the telephone number of a
working telephone service to report a malfunction, secure a refund in the event of a malfunction of the coin return mechanism, or give the notices
provided for herein.
E. Newspaper vending machines and newspaper stands shall be kept in good clean and neat maintenance. (Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
3-6-5: LOCATION AND PLACEMENT:
The location and placement of newspaper stands or newspaper vending machines shall be subject to the following provisions:
A. No newspaper vending machine or stand wholly or in part shall project onto, into or over any part of the roadway of any public street, or which rests,
wholly or in part, upon, along or over any portion of the roadway of any public street.
B. No newspaper vending machine or stand shall be permitted to rest upon, in or over any public sidewalk, parkway or public way, when such site or
location is used for public utility purposes, public transportation purposes or other governmental use, or when such newspaper vending machine
unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including any legally marked or stopped vehicle, the ingress into or
egress from any residence or place of business, or the use of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes or other objects permitted at or
near said location.
C. When any newspaper vending machine or stand is chained, bolted or otherwise attached to any public property, such attachment shall be of rust and
stain resistant material.
D. Newspaper vending machines may be placed next to each other, provided that no group of newspaper vending machines shall extend for a distance of
more than seven feet (7') along a curb.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 100/416
E. No newspaper vending machine or newspaper stand shall be placed, installed, used or maintained:
1. Within three feet (3') of any marked crosswalk.
2. Within twelve feet (12') of the curb return of any unmarked crosswalk.
3. Within five feet (5') of any fire hydrant, fire call box, police call box or other emergency facility.
4. Within five feet (5') of any driveway.
5. Within three feet (3') ahead or fifteen feet (15') to the rear of any sign marked a designated bus stop.
6. Within three feet (3') of the outer end of any bus bench.
7. At any location whereby the clear space for the passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than eighty percent (80%) of clear space for such
passage.
8. Within three feet (3') of or on any public area improved with lawn, flowers, shrubs, trees or other landscaping. (Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
3-6-6: ABANDONMENT:
Any newspaper vending machine that remains empty for a period of three (3) days shall be deemed to have been abandoned and disposed of by the
department of public property as worthless property. (Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
3-6-7: VIOLATIONS:
In the event of a violation of the provisions of this chapter, the village clerk shall issue a notice to the distributor to correct the violation. The notice shall be
delivered verbally and confirmed in writing. In the event of failure of the distributor to correct the violation within five (5) days, excluding Saturdays,
Sundays and all legal holidays, after the mailing of said notice, the village clerk shall remove the newspaper vending machine or stand and dispose of the
machine or stand as in the case of abandoned machines or stands set forth in section 3-6-6 of this chapter. (Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
3-6-8: APPEALS:
If the distributor objects to the determination of the village clerk that the use, installation and maintenance of the newspaper vending machine violates any
provisions of this chapter, then the distributor may within ten (10) days after the notice required in section 3-6-7 of this chapter appeal the determination to
the mayor and village council by letter stating the reason for the appeal and a hearing thereon shall be held within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice
of appeal. The appealing party shall be given not less than five (5) days notice of the hearing. The decision of the mayor and village council shall be final.
(Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
3-6-9: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
In addition to the enforcement procedures provided in section 3-6-7 of this chapter, it shall be within the power and discretion of the village clerk to
suspend or revoke the permit for continued or repeated violation or infractions of any provision of this chapter. Suspension or revocation shall be
mandatory for the third violation of section 3-6-5 of this chapter. Rights to notice and appeal shall be the same as provided in section 3-6-8 of this chapter
and this section, as inthe case of violations. (Ord. O-8-82, 5-10-1982)
Chapter 7
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICIAL: The terms of this chapter shall be administered by the mayor of the village, who shall be the enforcement officer, or his
authorized representative.
EMPLOYEE: Any and all persons other than massage therapists who render any service for the licensee but has no physical contact with customers or
clients.
LICENSEE: The operator of a massage establishment.
MASSAGE: Any method of pressure on, friction against or stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, bathing, touching, binding, painting, irritating or
stimulating of external soft parts of the body with hands or with the aid of any manual, mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance, with or without such
supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptic oils, powder, creams, lotions, soaps, ointments or other similar preparations commonly used in
this practice.
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT: Any establishment having its place of business where any person engages in or carries on permits to be engaged or
carried on any of the activities set out in the definition of "massage" herein.
MASSAGE SERVICES: The providing of a massage or massages by any person.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 101/416
MASSAGE THERAPIST: Any person who, for any consideration whatever, engages in the practice of "massage" as herein defined.
PERSON: Any individual, copartnership, firm, association, joint stock company, corporation or any combination of individuals of whatever form or
character.
SEXUAL OR GENITAL AREA: The sexual or genital area of any person shall include the genitals, pubic area, anus or perineum of any person, or the
vulva or breasts of a female. (Ord. O-14-75, 11-8-1975)
3-7-2: MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT LICENSES:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on, or to permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, upon
any premises in the village, the operation of a "massage establishment", as herein defined, without first having obtained a license from the village clerk,
after the approval of the administrative official and the village council.
B. Application For License; Fee: Every applicant for a permit to maintain, operate or conduct a massage establishment shall file an application in duplicate,
under oath, with the village clerk upon a form provided by the village clerk, and pay a nonrefundable filing fee as set out in section 3-5-1 of this title to
the village clerk, who shall issue a receipt which shall be attached to the application filed with the village clerk. The village clerk shall, within fifteen (15)
days thereafter, refer copies of such application and all additional information to the board of health, fire department, building department and the
administrative official and village council. Within forty five (45) days, the village agencies shall inspect the premises proposed to be operated as a
massage establishment, and make recommendations to the administrative official concerning compliance with the codes of the village. Upon receipt of
the recommendations of the respective village agencies, the administrative official shall notify the applicant as to whether his application has been
granted, denied or held for further investigation. The period of such additional investigation shall not exceed an additional thirty (30) days unless
otherwise agreed to by the applicant. The administrative official shall advise the applicant in writing as to whether the application has been granted or
denied. If the application is denied or held for further investigation, the administrative official shall advise the applicant in writing of the reason for such
refusal.
The failure or refusal of the applicant to promptly give any information relevant to the investigation of the application, or the refusal or failure of
applicant to appear at any reasonable time and place for examination under oath regarding said application, or the refusal of applicant to submit to or
cooperate with any inspection required by this section, shall be grounds for denial of the application.
C. Contents Of Application: The application for a license to operate a massage establishment shall set forth the exact nature of the massage to be
administered and the proposed place and facilities thereof.
In addition thereto, any applicant for a license, and each partner or limited partner of an applicant, if a partnership applicant, and each officer and
director of a corporate applicant and any stockholder of a corporate applicant holding more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of the corporate
applicant, shall furnish the following information:
1. Written proof that each individual is at least eighteen (18) years of age;
2. All residential addresses for the past three (3) years;
3. The business, occupation or employment of each individual for the three (3) years immediately preceding the date of application;
4. The previous experience of the individual in massage or similar business;
5. Whether the individual has had any license denied, revoked or suspended in the village or any other state or city for a massage establishment, the
reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation of the individual subsequent to such suspension, revocation or denial;
6. Any conviction, forfeiture of bond or plea of nolo contendere upon any criminal violation or village ordinance violation (except minor traffic violations),
within a five (5) year period;
7. If the applicant is a corporation, or a partner of any partnership is a corporation, then the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown
in the articles of incorporation, together with the state of incorporation and proof of authority to do business in the state of Illinois.
D. Issuance Of License: Upon receipt of the recommendation of the respective agencies and with the information contained in the application, together
with all additional information provided therein, the administrative official shall direct the issuance of the license by the village clerk to the applicant to
maintain, operate or conduct a massage establishment, unless the administrative official shall find:
1. That the operation of the massage establishment as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with the applicable laws of the state of
Illinois and the village, including, but not limited to, the building, health, planning, housing, fire prevention and zoning codes of the village; or
2. That the applicant or any other person who shall be directly or indirectly engaged in the management and operation of the massage establishment
has been convicted of: a) a felony; b) an offense involving sexual misconduct with children; c) any provision of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-6
et seq.; or
3. That the operation of the massage establishment as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would violate the provisions of this chapter.
The license provided herein shall be for an initial term ending April 30 next following the issuance of the license, unless sooner suspended or
revoked. Such license must be renewed annually, and any renewal shall be for a term of one year from May 1 to April 30.
E. Revocation Or Suspension Of License: Any license issued for a massage establishment may be revoked or suspended by the administrative official,
after a hearing, for good cause. The administrative official shall give to the licensee at least fifteen (15) days written notice of the charges and an
opportunity for a public hearing before the administrative official, at which time the licensee may present evidence bearing upon the question. Cause for
revocation or suspension shall include the violation of the provisions of this chapter or of any criminal statute of the state of Illinois by the applicant, or
by any employee of the licensee or any massage therapist employed by the licensee; provided that the violation of this chapter or any criminal law of
the state of Illinois shall not be a cause for revocation or suspension unless the licensee shall have had actual or constructive knowledge of such
violations in the exercise of due diligence. It shall also be cause for revocation or suspension that the applicant has made a false statement on any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 102/416
application for permit under this chapter, or in the event that the licensee shall refuse to permit any authorized police officer or authorized member of
the police department, building department, board of health or of the fire department of the village to inspect the premises or the operations thereof at
reasonable times.
When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to any person for the period one year thereafter for the conduct
of a massage establishment in the premises described in such revoked license. (Ord. O-14-75, 11-8-1975)
3-7-3: MASSAGE THERAPIST PERMITS:
A. Permits Required: Any person who engages in the practice of "massage", as herein defined, shall file an application for a permit as a massage
therapist, which application shall be filed with village clerk upon the form provided by him, and shall pay fees as set out in section 3-5-1 of this title to
the village clerk, who shall issue a receipt which shall be attached to the application filed with the village clerk.
B. Application For Permit: The application for a permit for a massage therapist shall contain the following:
1. Name and residence.
2. Social security number.
3. Written evidence that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age.
4. Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for three (3) years immediately preceding the date of application.
5. Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of, pleaded nolo contendere to, or suffered a forfeiture of bond on a charge of committing any
violation of the village ordinances or state statute (except minor traffic violations). In the event any answer is in the affirmative, then the applicant
shall state the place and court in which such conviction, plea or forfeiture was had, the specific charge and the sentence imposed as a result thereof.
6. The applicant shall further undergo a physical examination and present the written results thereof for contagious and communicable diseases which
shall include a recognized blood test for syphilis, a culture for gonorrhea, a test or tests which will demonstrate freedom from tuberculosis, and each
test shall have been made by a licensed physician and all laboratory tests shall be in laboratories approved by the village. The applicant shall then
present a certificate with the results of each such examination signed by a physician licensed in the state of Illinois stating that the person examined
is either free from any contagious or communicable disease or is incapable of communicating any such disease to others. Each applicant shall
undergo the physical examination provided herein and present to the village clerk the certificate required herein prior to the commencement of
employment and at least once each twelve (12) months thereafter.
7. The applicant shall further meet professional skills requirements established by regulations adopted by the Forest Park board of health. Upon proof
of satisfactory compliance with the board of health regulations the applicant shall be issued a certificate by the board of health certifying compliance
with the regulations and this certificate shall be attached to the license application.
There shall be excepted from the provisions of this subsection any person who shall be registered as a physical therapist by the state of Illinois under
the provisions of 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 90/0.05 et seq., which person shall not also be required to obtain a permit as massage therapist.
C. Issuance Of Permit: The administrative official and village council shall direct the issuance by the village clerk of a permit for a massage therapist within
twenty one (21) days following the application and the providing of all information required by this chapter, unless the administrative official finds that
the applicant for a permit has been convicted of a felony, an offense involving sexual misconduct with children or any violation of 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-6 et seq., or unless he finds that the applicant has failed to provide all of the information and certificates required by this chapter.
Each permit for a massage therapist, pursuant to this chapter, shall terminate on April 30 following its issuance, and any renewal shall be for a one year
term commencing May 1 and ending April 30 thereafter and shall be carried by the permit holder while engaged in his employment.
D. Revocation Or Suspension Of Permit: A permit for massage therapist may be revoked or suspended where it appears that the massage therapist has
been convicted of any offense which would be cause for denial of a permit upon an original application, has made a false statement on an application
for a permit or has committed an act in violation of this chapter. The administrative official shall give the permit holder a written notice specifying the
grounds of suspension or revocation. The permit holder may, within fifteen (15) days from the date of such revocation or suspension, file a written
request for public hearing, which hearing shall be held within fifteen (15) days after the filing of request for same, and at which time the permit holder
may present evidence bearing upon the question. The administrative official shall then issue a written order as to whether the permit shall be revoked
or suspended within five (5) days after the date of hearing. (Ord. O-14-75, 11-8-1975)
3-7-4: REQUIRED FACILITIES:
No massage establishment shall receive a permit or be operated, established or maintained unless the establishment shall comply with each of the
following minimum regulations:
A. All massage tables, bathtubs, shower stalls, bath areas and floors shall have surfaces which may be readily disinfected.
B. Separate bathing, dressing, locker, toilet, massage room facilities shall be provided for female and male patrons, so that female and male patrons may
be served simultaneously in the event that patrons of both sexes are permitted.
C. The premises shall have adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing nondisposable instruments and materials used in administering massages.
Such nondisposable instruments and materials shall be disinfected after use on each patron.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 103/416
D. Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. When five (5) or more employees or patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the same
time, separate toilet facilities shall be provided. Lavatories or washbasins shall be provided with both hot and cold running water and shall be installed
in either the toilet room or vestibule. Lavatories or washbasins shall be provided with soap and a dispenser and with sanitary towels.
E. Closed cabinets shall be provided for use in the storage of clean linens, towels and other material used in administering massages. All soiled linens,
towels and other materials shall be kept in properly covered containers or cabinets which shall be kept separate from the clean storage areas. (Ord. O-
14-75, 11-8-1975)
3-7-5: OPERATING REGULATIONS:
A. Every portion of the massage establishment, including appliances and apparatus, shall be kept clean and operated under sanitary conditions.
B. Price rates for ail services shall be prominently posted in the reception area in a location available to all prospective customers.
C. All employees, including massage therapists, shall wear clean, nontransparent outer garments covering the sexual and genital areas, and such other
garments shall be restricted in use to the massage establishment.
D. A separate dressing room for each sex must be available on the premises, with individual lockers for each employee, massage therapist.
E. Doors to the dressing rooms shall open inward and shall be self-closing.
F. All massage establishments shall be provided with clean laundered sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use
thereof and stored in a sanitary manner.
G. The sexual or genital areas of patrons must be covered with towels, cloths or undergarments when in the presence of an employee, massage therapist.
H. It shall be unlawful for any person in a massage establishment to place his hand upon or to touch with any part of his body, or to fondle in any manner,
or to massage, a sexual or genital area of any person.
I. No massage therapist, employee or licensee, shall perform, offer or agree to perform any act which shall require the touching of the patron's genital
area.
J. All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, baths and steam rooms and any other physical facilities shall be in good repair and maintained in a clean and
sanitary condition.
K. Oils, creams, lotions and other preparations used in administering massages shall be kept in clean closed containers or cabinets.
L. No massage therapist shall administer a massage to a patron exhibiting any skin fungus, skin infection, skin inflammation or skin eruption, unless a
physician duly licensed by the state of Illinois shall certify in writing that such person may be safely massaged, describing the conditions under which
such massage may be performed.
M. Each massage therapist shall wash his or her hands in hot running water using a proper soap or disinfectant before administering any massage to any
patron.
N. No massage establishment shall permit any agent or employee who is a member of one sex to treat a member of the opposite sex unless such
treatment is undertaken by or under the immediate direction or supervision of a person who is licensed in the practice of medicine, physical therapy or
beauty culture by the state of Illinois. (Ord. O-14-75, 11-8-1975)
3-7-6: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE AND PERMIT:
A. Advertising: No massage establishment holding a license under this chapter shall depict, place, publish, distribute or cause to be depicted, placed,
published or distributed any advertising matter that suggests to prospective patrons that any services are available other than those services permitted
by this chapter, or which would suggest that employees, massage therapists are dressed in any manner other than that permitted by this chapter, and
all advertisements shall contain the number of the village license held by the massage establishment.
B. Outcall Registration: Any massage therapist who provides any of the services provided in this chapter at any hotel or motel must first register his name
and the permit number with the owner, manager or person in charge of such hotel or motel. No outcall massage service may be operated other than by
