In such cases where a tenant has multiple exposures, such as a corner location, such tenant shall be permitted to locate signage on the side
exposure, but such signs shall be limited to three-fourths (3/4) of a square foot based on the side secondary exposure. Sign allocation of the
primary frontage exposure shall be limited to that side of the building.
c. Window area signs, permanent or temporary, may not cover more than fifty percent (50%) of any window unit square footage (1/2 of the total
window area).
4. Inflatable Signs: In a B-3 district, an inflatable sign may be erected for a period of not more than ten (10) days and with a maximum frequency of no
more often that twelve (12) times per year. In all other business and industrial zones, such inflatable signs shall be permitted for a period of not more
than fourteen (14) days, and with a maximum frequency of no more often than three (3) times per year. Such signs shall be special event signs, and
are semitemporary in their nature.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 298/416
B. Signs Allowed Without Permit, Fee Or Inspection: Except as regulated by sections 8-6-6 and 8-6-7 of this chapter and/or as expressly prohibited in
section 8-6-9 of this chapter, and notwithstanding any other contrary provisions of this code, the following signs may, subject to the following limitations,
be erected and maintained in any district without obtaining a sign permit or paying the fee required for such permit:
1. Bulletin Board Signs: Such signs shall be limited to no more than one wall or ground sign per zoning lot, shall be no more than twenty five (25)
square feet in area, and shall be permitted only in connection with public, religious and civic institutions. No such sign shall be higher than six feet
(6'), nor be closer to any sidewalk or street line than eight feet (8'), or closer to any other lot line than six feet (6') or, in either case, no closer than the
distance of the required yard or setback, whichever is less. No such sign shall permitted in any residential district.
2. Civic Event Signs: Such signs shall be limited to no more than one wall or ground sign per zoning lot. No such sign shall be larger than thirty two (32)
square feet in area. Such signs shall be displayed for a period of not more than fourteen (14) days unless an application has been filed and
specifically approved for a longer period of time by the director upon application filed therefor. Signs permitted under this subsection shall be
removed within two (2) days after the end of the event.
3. Election Signs: Such signs shall be located entirely on private property pursuant to the owner's consent, shall be permitted no more than thirty (30)
days prior to an election, and shall be removed within two (2) days after that election. Unless such sign includes on its face the name of the person or
organization responsible for such sign, the owner of the private property on which such sign is located shall be deemed responsible for such sign.
4. Governmental Signs: The content and size of any such sign shall not exceed the requirements of the law, ordinance or regulation pursuant to which
such sign is erected.
5. Holiday Decorations: Such signs shall be displayed; notwithstanding any other provisions of this section to the contrary, such signs may be of any
type, number, area, height, location, illumination or animation so long as they create no safety hazard, nuisance or adverse impact on the adjacent
properties.
6. Memorial Signs: Such signs shall be limited to no more than one wall or ground sign per zoning lot, shall be made of durable materials such as
bronze, stone or concrete, shall not be illuminated, and shall not exceed three (3) square feet in area. No ground sign shall be higher than two feet
(2'), or closer to any sidewalk or street line than ten feet (10') or any lot line than six feet (6').
7. Nameplate Signs: Such signs shall be limited to no more than one wall or ground sign per occupancy, shall be no more than one square foot in area
per occupancy and in no event may the aggregate total be more than three (3) square feet in area, and shall not be illuminated. No nameplate
ground sign shall be higher than four feet (4') nor closer to any sidewalk or street line than ten feet (10') or to any lot line than six feet (6').
8. Official Flags And Emblems: Such signs may be displayed on flagpoles and when so displayed shall not exceed twenty four (24) square feet in area.
Such signs also may be displayed in the form of a wall sign and when so displayed shall not exceed three (3) square feet in area.
9. On Site Informational Signs: Such signs shall be limited to wall or ground signs of not more than three (3) square feet in area, shall be, if a ground
sign, not more than four feet (4') in height, and shall be illuminated only as necessary to accomplish their intended purpose. No such sign shall be
permitted in any residential district.
10. Political Message Signs: Such signs shall be permitted on private property; provided, however, that no more than two (2) such signs shall be
permitted per lot, no such sign shall be located within any required yard or setback and no such sign shall exceed six (6) square feet in sign area.
11. Private Garage Sale Signs: Such signs shall be no more than six (6) square feet in area, shall be located entirely on the premises where such sale
is to be conducted, shall be clearly marked with the name, address and telephone number of the person responsible for the removal of such sign,
shall be erected not more than twenty four (24) hours before such sale, and shall be removed within twenty four (24) hours following the conclusion
of such sale. No ground sign shall be higher than four feet (4'), nor closer to any sidewalk or street line than ten feet (10') or any lot line than six feet
(6').
12. Private Warning Signs: Such signs, such as those displaying private parking and/or off street loading condition, and private traffic control signs shall
be no more than two (2) square feet in area each, shall be limited to the number necessary to accomplish the intended purpose, and shall be
illuminated only as required to accomplish such purpose.
13. Restaurant Menu Display: Such signs shall be permitted only in the B-1 and B-2 business districts. Only one such sign shall be permitted per
zoning lot. No such sign shall exceed three (3) square feet in total sign area.
14. Temporary Use Signs: Such signs may include:
a. Signs announcing events, such as grand openings, going out of business, under new management, birthday announcements and births.
b. Signs announcing the sale of seasonal products, such as Christmas trees, farmer's market, etc.
Every such temporary use sign is subject to the following conditions, and the conditions set out in section 8-6-7 of this chapter:
(1) Ground signs shall not to exceed thirty six (36) square feet, nor be more than four feet (4') tall per sign face and shall not exceed six feet (6') in
overall height as measured from the immediate adjacent grade;
(2) Wall and window signs shall comply with the area limitation for such structural sign;
(3) Such signs shall be limited to a period of thirty (30) days unless otherwise provided by the director;
(4) May be displayed up to three (3) times within one calendar year on any given property;
(5) Shall be located on the lot of which such temporary use serves;
(6) Shall be of sturdy construction and shall not be detrimental to the character of the area;
(7) Shall be removed within twenty four (24) hours following termination of the temporary use;
(8) May not obstruct the vision triangle.
15. Window Signs, Temporary: The aggregate area of all such signs shall not exceed fifty percent (50%) of the area of the window in which they are
exhibited nor block any window area required for light, ventilation or emergency exit by any applicable code. No such sign shall be illuminated, nor
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 299/416
shall any such sign shall be permitted in any residential district. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-6: SIGN SPECIFICATIONS:
A. Ground Signs:
1. Ground signs shall not obstruct the required vision triangle on corner lots. Every ground sign shall comply with all requirements of the village's
building code.
2. No ground sign shall exceed twenty four feet (24') in height above the grade of the street to which the face of the sign is directed or in the event that
the sign faces two (2) streets, the grade of the street at the lowest level measured to the top of the sign.
B. Roof Signs: Roof signs are prohibited.
C. Wall Signs:
1. No wall sign shall be so erected as to cover the doors or windows of any building or as to prevent free ingress and egress to and from any window,
door or fire escape of any building.
2. No wall sign shall extend beyond the building line more than twelve inches (12") except, however, that if the sign is illuminated, lighting reflectors
may project up to six feet (6') beyond the building line but in no event beyond the right of way line. All wall signs must be safely and adequately
attached to the building.
3. No signs shall be painted directly on the outside wall of any building.
D. Projecting Signs: Projecting signs are permitted in the Madison Street sign district only.
1. Due to the older development pattern along Madison Street, where the buildings have been constructed without side yards or open space on the
street front, these properties do not have the opportunity for ground or pole signs. Accordingly, the properties abutting both sides of Madison Street,
from Harlem Avenue to 73.12 feet west of Jackson Boulevard shall constitute the Madison Street sign district. Projecting signs shall be permitted in
this district only, and are prohibited in the rest of the village.
2. Projecting signs may extend to a maximum of one foot (1') back from the curb line as established for the majority of the block face, but the maximum
projection shall not exceed ten feet (10') from the face of the building.
3. The permitted projection shall be determined by the location of the sign in reference to the building facade, with a projection of three inches (3")
being permitted for each one foot (1') that the sign is located from the edges of the building. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
4. With the exception of awnings, no projecting sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained so that its lowest edge is less than ten feet (10') above
the sidewalk or less than fifteen feet (15') above an alley. Awnings may be located no lower than eight feet (8') above the sidewalk and no lower than
fifteen feet (15') above any alley. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998; amd. Ord. O-4-01, 1-8-2001)
5. No projecting vertical sign shall extend above the roof or top of the cornice wall.
6. All projecting signs shall be constructed to satisfy the requirements of the village's building code.
7. Projecting signs shall be made of metal or wood.
8. Every projecting sign shall be securely attached to the building in such a fashion that the supports are not visible, but instead are contained and
concealed by the sign body.
E. Banner Signs:
1. No section of a banner sign made of plastic, canvas or other cloth nor shall it be more than thirty two (32) square feet in area. No more than one
section shall be attached to any twenty feet (20') frontage of any building abutting public property, nor shall any banner sign be placed in contact with
an electric sign.
2. A banner sign shall not be erected for a period to exceed thirty (30) days, without extension of permit being obtained, and no renewal shall be
granted for a period over ninety (90) days from original date of erection.
F. Marquees And Marquee Signs: Marquee and marquee signs are no longer permitted.
G. Awnings:
1. Movable: Movable awnings shall be permitted to project over the public right of way no more than five feet (5') from the front wall of the building on
which they are mounted. Such awnings shall be allowed sign content, but such sign area shall be counted as part of the permitted sign area of that
property and/or business as applicable. Such awnings may be illuminated by exterior mounted light standards from above, but not below the
awnings. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
2. Fixed: All fixed awnings shall consist of a single flat plane surface for the face panel with triangular end panels, if any. Such awnings shall not be lit
from below or within, but may be illuminated from exterior light standards from above the awning.
If the awning contains signage or advertising, other than the address number, such awning shall be considered to be a sign. If the awning signage
contains information other than the name, address and/or telephone number of the business, then such content must be approved by the village. If
the awning projects over the public right of way, with the exception of awnings located in the Madison Street sign district, the maximum area of any
advertising on the awning shall be limited to no more than ten percent (10%) of the total area of the awning. (Ord. O-18-01, 4-23-2001)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 300/416
H. Sandwich Board Signs:
1. Madison Street Sign District Only: Sandwich board signs shall be permitted in the Madison Street sign district only, as described in subsection D of
this section.
2. Business Criteria: Sandwich board signs must meet all of the following criteria:
a. The building in which the business is located is set back no more than ten feet (10') from the sidewalk on which the sandwich board will be
located.
b. The business has a customer entrance or service window which faces and is within ten feet (10') of the sidewalk on which the sandwich board
sign will be located.
3. Location On Sidewalk: Sandwich board signs shall be located entirely on a sidewalk within a public right of way or on private property and shall be
located between the two (2) lot lines of the business displaying such sign. Sandwich board signs shall not be located in a roadway, alley or vehicle
way. A minimum of four feet (4') of public sidewalk shall remain unobstructed at all times.
4. Design Criteria:
a. Size: Sandwich board signs shall be not more than ten (10) square feet in area and no more than four feet (4') in height.
b. Design: Sandwich board signs shall be professionally made and maintained in good condition. Signs shall be of an "A" frame design and properly
weighted so as not to create a windblown hazard. Signs shall not have any nails, tacks, wires or sharp metal edges protruding therefrom.
c. Illumination: Sandwich board signs shall not be illuminated.
5. Mixed Signs Prohibited: Businesses which display a sandwich board sign shall not display any other temporary use signs or banners.
6. Number Permitted: Not more than one sandwich board sign shall be permitted per business.
7. Time Restrictions: Sandwich board signs shall not be displayed before the time that the business displaying such sign is open to the public.
Sandwich board signs shall be taken down each day no later than nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. or the close of the business displaying such sign,
whichever is earlier.
8. Fees: Sandwich board signs shall be subject to the fees established in subsection 8-6-4C of this chapter. (Ord. O-18-04, 4-26-2004)
8-6-7: GENERAL STANDARDS:
The following general standards shall apply to all signs:
A. Illumination:
1. Location And Design Of Light Source: Whenever an external artificial light source is used for a sign, such source shall be located, shielded and
directed so as not to be directly visible from any public street or private residence. No receptacle or device housing a permitted light source for a sign
shall protrude more than eighteen inches (18") from the face of the sign or building to which it is attached.
2. Level Of Illumination: In no event shall the illumination of any sign, resulting from any internal or external artificial light source, exceed fifty (50) footcandles
when measured with a standard light meter held perpendicular to the sign face at a distance equal to the narrowest dimension of such sign
face. All artificial illumination shall be so designed, located, shielded and directed as to prevent the casting of glare or direct light upon adjacent
property or streets.
3. Signs Adjacent To Residential Areas: Any illuminated sign located on a lot abutting or across a street from, and visible from, any residentially zoned
area shall not be illuminated between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., except that such sign may remain
illuminated during such time as the activity to which the sign pertains is open for business as long as such sign is not a public or private nuisance.
4. Flashing Lights Prohibited: Except for public service signs expressly permitted by this chapter no flashing, blinking or intermittent lights shall be
permitted.
5. Awnings: Awnings illuminated from the interior are prohibited.
6. Neon Lights: Neon utilized to outline windows, doors and building elements is prohibited.
B. Electrical Elements: All wiring, fittings and materials used in the construction, connection and operation of electrically illuminated signs shall be in
accordance with the provisions of the village's electrical code. An Underwriter's Laboratories label, or an equivalent certification, shall be affixed to
every electrical component incorporated into a sign. Each illuminated sign shall have a readily accessible disconnection switch.
No metal sign illuminated by any means requiring internal wiring and no electrical fixtures attached to any sign shall be lower than nine feet (9') from
grade unless it is grounded by the use of a grounding conductor run with the circuit conductors and is also grounded by being bonded to a grounding
electrode at the sign site.
C. Structural Elements: The construction and structural components of all signs shall be in accordance with the standards and regulations of the village's
building code. All permanent signs shall be constructed of fire resistant materials and shall be capable of withstanding wind pressures of at least thirty
(30) pounds per square foot of surface area and of receiving dead loads based on the actual weight of the structure.
D. Minimum Elevation Of Certain Signs: The bottom of every canopy, projecting and wall sign shall be elevated at least ten feet (10') above grade, except
that one wall mounted identification sign not greater than one square foot in area may be elevated to not less than four feet (4') above grade.
Whenever possible, wall signs on the same facade shall maintain the same top and bottom elevations above grade.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 301/416
E. Obstruction Of Accessways: No sign or sign structure shall obstruct free ingress to or egress from a fire escape, door, window or other required
accessway, or be attached to any standpipe or fire escape.
F. Obstruction Of Window Surface: No sign shall project over or obstruct any window surface required for light or ventilation by any applicable provision of
the village's building code.
G. Traffic Safety:
1. Confusion With Traffic Signals: No sign shall be maintained at any location where by reason of its position, size, shape, content, color or illumination
it may obstruct, impair, obscure, interfere with the view of, or be confused with any traffic control sign, signal or device or where it may interfere with,
mislead or confuse traffic.
2. Obstruction Of Sight Triangles Prohibited: No sign, nor any part of a sign other than a supporting pole or brace no greater than twelve inches (12") in
width or diameter, shall be located in the area between two and one-half feet (21/2') and ten feet (10') from grade within the area defined in this code.
(Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
3. Signs In Rights Of Way: No sign shall be placed in or extend into or over any public property or right of way, except: a) governmental and civic signs
providing direction and/or information and as authorized in this chapter; b) bench signs as approved annually by the village council as provided in
section 3-5B-4 of this code; and c) projecting signs and sandwich board signs located in the Madison Street sign district. Civic event signs may
extend on, into or over a public right of way upon the specific prior approval of the building director. (Ord. O-18-04, 4-26-2004)
4. Civic Event Signs: No civic event signs authorized in this chapter shall be permitted except upon the specific prior approval of the director.
H. Sign Measurement:
1. Area Included: The supporting structure or bracing of a sign shall be omitted in measuring the area of the sign unless such structure or bracing is
made part of the message or face of the sign. When a sign has more than one display face, all faces shall be included in determining the total area of
the sign.
2. Area Of Signs With Backing: The area of all signs with backing shall be measured by computing the area of the sign backing.
3. Area Of Signs Without Backing: The area of all signs without backing shall be measured by computing the area of the smallest rectangular geometric
figures that can separately encompass all words, letters, figures, emblems and other elements of the sign message.
4. Area Of Signs With And Without Backing: The area of all signs formed by a combination of elements with and without backing shall be measured by
combining the area of such elements measured in accordance with the foregoing subparagraphs.
I. Signs On Lots With Multiple Users: When more than one user occupies a zoning lot, the owner of the lot shall be responsible for allocating permitted
signs among such users.
J. Sign Spacing: No sign shall be nearer than two feet (2') to any other sign or structure, other than a structure to which it is lawfully attached.
K. Obscene Matter: No sign shall include or display any obscene, indecent or immoral matter.
L. General Safety: Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, no sign shall be constructed or maintained in any area or in any manner so as to
create a nuisance or a threat to the public safety or welfare. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-8: REAL ESTATE SIGNS:
A. R-1 And R-2 Districts:
1. It shall be unlawful for any real estate broker, owner, manager, tenant or person in control of property to construct, erect, place, maintain or install on
any premises or dwelling located in the village in any district zoned R-l or R-2 by the village zoning ordinance, any sign, printed, inscribed or having
thereon any of the following words or words which have a similar meaning or connotation to said words; namely: "for rent", "for lease", "for sale",
"sold", "new house", "now selling", "visitors invited", "installed by" or "built by".
2. For the purpose of this chapter, a "sign" is defined to be a flag, bunting or any structure or material substance, its or their parts together with frame,
background or supports thereof used for advertising purposes.
3. A sign with the words "open house" or "open for inspection" shall be permitted on private residential property zoned R-1 or R-2 provided:
a. The size of the sign does not exceed twenty four inches by thirty six inches (24" x 36"); and
b. Such a sign is erected and displayed only on a Saturday or Sunday and displayed only during the time the property is open or being inspected by
prospective renters or purchasers, but in no case for longer than four (4) hours on such day.
4. Signs permitted, relating to the sale or lease of any land or building within the business or industrial districts, as specified by the village's zoning
ordinance:
a. For the purpose of selling or renting any lot or group of lots and/or any existing or proposed building or group of buildings, one sign may be
erected not exceeding ten (10) square feet in aggregate area for each facade of the building; and
b. In connection with the marketing of any subdivision of five (5) lots or more, a condominium development of five (5) or more dwelling units, an
industrial or business site of more than one acre, or any area in excess of five (5) acres, that one sign not exceeding sixty four (64) square feet in
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 302/416
total area, nor ten feet (10') in its greatest dimension may be displayed. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998; amd. Ord. O-42-00, 10-23-2000)
B. R-3 District: A "for sale" sign shall be permitted on private residential property zoned R-3 provided:
1. The private residential property is improved with a structure containing twelve (12) or more dwelling units;
2. The size of the sign shall not exceed fifteen (15) square feet;
3. A permit shall have been obtained from the village clerk upon payment of fifty dollars ($50.00) and verification of the size of the sign and the number
of dwelling units in the structure improving the property upon which such sign shall be placed;
4. The permit for the sign shall be issued for a ninety (90) day period and may be renewed for an additional ninety (90) day period provided payment is
received for renewal in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00);
5. Such sign shall be removed upon execution of a contract for the sale or exchange of the property whether or not such contract contains
contingencies which may avoid the actual closing of the conveyance;
6. No sign shall be illuminated other than by natural light. (Ord. O-42-00, 10-23-2000)
8-6-9: PROHIBITED SIGNS:
The following signs, as well as all other signs not expressly permitted by this chapter, are prohibited in all districts and shall not be erected, maintained or
permitted to continue in any district, except as provided in subsection 8-6-5B of this chapter:
A. Marquee signs.
B. Home occupation identification signs.
C. Off premises identification signs.
D. Moving or animated signs.
E. Portable signs, except when approved in connection with temporary uses pursuant to subsection 8-6-5B of this chapter.
F. Projecting signs, except in the Madison Street sign district.
G. Roof signs.
H. Temporary signs, except as expressly authorized in this section and except in connection with temporary uses pursuant to subsection 8-6-5B of this
chapter.
I. Abandoned or obsolete signs. Any sign that advertises, identifies or pertains to a business no longer conducted or a product no longer sold on the
premises where such sign is located. Such signs, including any support structures, shall be removed within thirty (30) days following cessation of the
relevant activity.
J. Any sign on a tree or utility pole, whether on public or private property.
K. Any sign on public property, except government, civic event signs and projecting signs in the Madison Street sign district, as authorized in this chapter.
L. Any sign painted directly on a wall, roof or fence.
M. Any sign using reflective paint or tape, other than a governmental sign or a warning sign.
N. Any sign used for a private purpose that imitates or closely resembles a governmental sign such as a traffic control device. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-10: POSTING BILLS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to post, stick, stamp, tack, paint or to otherwise fix or cause the same to be done by any person, any notice, placard, bill,
card, poster, advertisement or other device calculated to attract attention to the public to or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, curb or curbstone, flagstone or
any other portion of any sidewalk or street, lamp post, electric light, telegraph, telephone or trolley line pole, hydrant or upon any tree or tree box or upon
any bridge, pier, fence, gate, gatepost or system, except such as may be required by laws of the United States or the state of Illinois or by the ordinances
of the village. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-11: UNSAFE AND UNLAWFUL SIGNS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 303/416
A. Notice Given: Whenever it shall appear to the director that any sign has been erected in violation of this chapter or is in unsafe condition, or has
become unstable or insecure, or is in such condition as to be a menace to the property or health of the public, he shall, thereupon, issue or cause to be
issued a notice, in writing, to the owner of such sign or the person in charge, possession or control thereof, or if the whereabouts of such person is
known, informing such person of the violation of this chapter and the dangerous condition of such sign and directing him to make such alterations or
repairs or to do such acts or things as are necessary or advisable to place such sign in a safe, substantial and secure condition and to make same
comply with the requirements of this chapter, within such reasonable time as may be stated in said notice.
B. Failure To Comply: If the owner or person in charge, possession or control of any sign when so notified shall refuse, fail or neglect to comply with and
conform to the requirements of such notice, said director shall, upon the expiration of the time therein mentioned, alter, change, tear down or cause to
be torn down, such part of such sign which is constructed and maintained in violation of this chapter and shall charge the expense to the owner or
person in possession, charge or control of such sign, and the same shall be recovered from such owner or person by appropriate legal proceedings.
(Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-12: ABANDONED OR OBSOLETE SIGNS:
All abandoned and/or obsolete signs, including support structures, shall be removed within thirty (30) days from the cessation of business or operation by
the sign owner, or, if the sign owner is no longer available or identifiable, then the property owner shall be responsible for the removal of all signs relating
to a business or use that is no longer in operation. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-13: MAINTENANCE STANDARDS:
All signs, canopies and/or awnings and support structures shall be kept and maintained in a safe, neat and orderly condition and appearance and shall be
repaired or otherwise maintained periodically by the owner to prevent corrosion or deterioration caused by the weather, age or any other condition, and to
keep the same in a safe, neat and orderly condition and appearance. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-14: EXISTING SIGNS:
A. Nonconforming Signs: It is recognized that there are some signs in the village which do not conform to this chapter; such signs shall be considered as
nonconforming signs. It is not the intent of this chapter to encourage their survival, but to bring such signs into conformance. Nonconforming signs are
permitted to remain, subject to the following provisions:
1. May not be reestablished if discontinued for a period of thirty (30) days.
2. May not be expanded, enlarged, reerected, replaced or changed in copy.
3. May not be reconstructed after damage or destruction to an extent equal to or more than fifty percent (50%) of the sign's original value, as
determined by the enforcement official.
4. May not be moved in whole or in part to another location, unless the sign is made to conform to all regulations of the sign code; and
5. May not be structurally altered so as to prolong the life of the sign.
This provision does not include any flags, temporary signs, banners, paper or cardboard signs or inflatable signs.
B. Maintenance: Normal repair and maintenance, such as painting, repair of chains, anchors and the like, shall be allowed on nonconforming signs. (Ord.
O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-15: VARIATIONS:
Applications for a variance from the provisions of this chapter shall be filed in accordance with the provisions of the zoning regulations contained in section
9-10-6 of this code.
After a public hearing as provided in said section 9-10-6 of this code, the recommendation of the zoning board of appeals shall be forwarded to the village
council, who then shall either approve or disapprove the requested variation. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-16: OWNER UNKNOWN:
If the owner of such sign or the person in charge, possession or control thereof cannot be found or his or their whereabouts cannot be ascertained, the
director shall attach or cause to be attached to said sign, if possible, a notice of the same report that is required to be sent to the owner or person in
possession, charge or control thereof where the owner is known. If such sign shall not have been made to conform to this chapter and be placed in secure,
safe and substantial condition in accordance with the requirements of such notice within thirty (30) days after such notice shall have been attached to such
sign, it shall be the duty of the director to thereupon cause such sign or such portion thereof as is constructed and maintained in violation of this chapter to
be torn down, provided that nothing herein contained shall prevent the director from adopting such precautionary measures as may be necessary or
desirable in case of imminent danger in order to place such sign in a safe condition, the expense of which shall be charged to and recovered from the
owner of such sign or person in charge, possession or control thereof, in any appropriate proceedings therefor or thereafter. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
8-6-17: PROSECUTION OF VIOLATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 304/416
A. Any person charged with a violation of this chapter in a citation issued by an employee of the department of public health and safety, detailing the
nature of the violation may avoid prosecution by exhibiting proof of correction of the condition on or compliance with the ordinance stated to have been
violated and the payment of twenty five dollars ($25.00) within ten (10) days of issuance of said citation, or fifty dollars ($50.00) after ten (10) days but
within thirty (30) days before the hearing date, to the village clerk or the clerk's designee.
B. Absent the failure to satisfy citation, the person charged shall appear at the place, time and date designated on the citation and the commissioner of the
department or his designee shall thereupon conduct a hearing. After the hearing by the commissioner of the department or his designee, the
commissioner or the designee shall take the following action:
1. Dismiss the citation; or
2. Find that there was probable cause for the issuance of the citation and that the original amount for the commission of such violation shall remain the
same; or
3. Require the payment of a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); or
4. In the event the violator has not corrected the violation and paid the penalty within the prescribed time, or has failed to obey any order of the
commissioner or his designee issued in pursuance of this chapter, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
C. The commissioner or his designee may proceed to institute appropriate proceedings against the person cited in the circuit court of Cook County, Illinois.
D. Upon conviction thereof, the violator shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); and
where such violation is of a continuing nature, each day such person violates any such provisions or fails to conform to any such provision of this
chapter or any such order of the director, shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. O-25-98, 11-9-1998)
Chapter 7
SWIMMING POOLS
8-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
PRIVATE SWIMMING POOL: A swimming pool which is used exclusively by the occupants of the property on which it is located, his family and guests.
SWIMMING POOL: A manmade rigid or semirigid receptacle for water having a depth at any point greater than eighteen inches (18"), used or intended to
be used for swimming, wading or bathing, and constructed, installed or maintained in or above the ground outside any building. This definition does not
include collapsible plastic pools. (Village code § 24-2)
8-7-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required; Plans And Specifications: No person shall hereafter construct, cause to be constructed, operate or maintain a swimming, wading or
bathing pool without first obtaining a permit therefor from the village. Written application for such permit shall be filed with the director of public health
and safety and shall be accompanied by two (2) sets of plans and specifications sufficiently detailed to enable determination of whether the proposed
pool complies with the requirements of this chapter. No such permit for an existing pool shall be granted by the director of public health and safety until
full compliance with this chapter has been demonstrated. (Village code § 24-19; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
B. Fee Schedule: The fee for a permit for the erection or construction of a swimming pool shall be as provided in section 8-2-3 of this title. (Village code
§ 24-21)
8-7-3: ENFORCEMENT:
The director of public health and safety is charged with the duty of enforcing this chapter. For this purpose, he is hereby authorized to enter upon any
premises in the village to investigate the existence of a swimming pool and to determine whether or not any such pool complies with the requirements of
this chapter. (Village code § 24-22; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
8-7-4: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
A. Comply With Code: Every existing private residential swimming pool and every such pool constructed, installed and maintained hereafter shall comply
with all applicable provisions of this chapter, and with all the provisions of the building ordinances and codes of this village. (Village code § 24-1)
B. Existing Pools: Swimming pools in existence on the effective date hereof shall be brought into compliance with the requirements of this chapter on or
before January 1, 1959. (Village code § 24-24)
8-7-5: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Structural Design: Residential swimming pools shall be designed to withstand water pressure from within and to resist pressure of the earth when the
pool is empty, to a pressure of two thousand two hundred (2,200) pounds per square foot. Materials used shall be subject to the approval of the director
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 305/416
of public health and safety. Grade height of pools constructed hereafter not to exceed established grade. (Village code § 24-11; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-
2010)
B. Water Supply: No source of water, other than that secured from the village's waterworks distribution system, shall be used in private swimming pools.
The connection shall be as required by the plumbing code of the village1, by means of a permanent, rigid system of piping having an air-gap delivery
connection located not less than six inches (6") vertically above the flood rim of the pool. (Village Code § 24-6)
C. Discharge Maximum: Pools shall be equipped with facilities for completely emptying the pool and the discharge of the pool water to the sewer shall be
at the rate not exceeding two hundred fifty (250) gallons per minute. No direct connection shall be made to the sewer. (Village Code § 24-9)
D. Sewer System Drainage Restrictions: Water drained from the pool shall not be discharged directly into the sewer system during periods of rain or
storms. (Village Code § 24-10; amd. 2004 Code)
8-7-6: EQUIPMENT SPECIFICATIONS:
A. Filtering Systems: No swimming, wading or bathing pool in excess of two thousand five hundred (2,500) gallons capacity shall be installed or operated
without a recirculating and filtering system. (Village Code § 24-7)
B. Outlets: In swimming pools, thirty feet (30') in width or less, water circulation system outlets shall be located so as to provide at least one outlet at the
deepest point in the pool. If the pool width is more than thirty feet (30'), multiple outlets shall be provided and spaced not more than thirty feet (30')
apart, nor closer than four feet (4') to any wall. All pool drain outlets shall be equipped with gratings having an area of opening of not less than four (4)
times the cross sectional area of the outlet pipe. The gratings shall be of such design so they cannot be readily removable by bathers and will not injure
bathers' fingers. One outlet shall be provided for each eight hundred (800) square feet of surface area. (Village Code § 24-8)
C. Steps Or Ladders: Two (2) or more means of egress in the form of steps or ladders shall be provided for all private residential swimming pools. At least
one such means of egress shall be located on a side of the pool at both the deep end and shallow end of the pool. Threads of steps and ladders shall
be constructed of nonslip material and at least three inches (3") wide for their full length. Steps and ladders shall have a handrail on both sides. (Village
Code § 24-13)
D. Electrical Requirements:
1. General: All electrical installations provided for, installed and used in conjunction with private residential swimming pools, shall be in conformance
with the provisions of the electrical code of the village2. No current carrying electrical conductors shall cross private residential swimming pools either
overhead or underground or within fifteen feet (15') of such pools. (Village Code § 24-14)
2. Grounding: All metal fences, enclosures or railings near or adjacent to private residential swimming pools, which might become electrically alive as a
result of contact with broken overhead conductors, or from any other cause, shall be effectively grounded. (Village Code § 24-15)
E. Diving Boards And Apparatus: Where a swimming pool has a diving board or diving apparatus for the purpose of diving into the pool, there shall be a
clear area of not less than an eight foot (8') radius ahead of the furthermost projection of the diving board. (Village Code § 24-23)
8-7-7: LOT AREA RESTRICTIONS:
A. Minimum Distance Requirements: After the effective date hereof, swimming pools shall be so constructed that there will be at least ten feet (10')
between the main building and the swimming pool, and there shall be at least five feet (5') between a side or rear lot line, and there shall be at least five
feet (5') between any auxiliary building and the swimming pool. No swimming pool shall be built within any front yard. Pumps, filters and pool water
disinfecting equipment installation shall be located at a distance not less than eight feet (8') from any side property line. (Village Code § 24-20)
B. Walk Areas: Unobstructed walk areas not less than thirty six inches (36") wide shall be provided to extend entirely around the pool. The walk area shall
be constructed of impervious material, and the surfaces shall be of such as to be smooth and easily cleaned and of nonslip construction. The slope of
the walks shall have a pitch of at least one-fourth inch to the foot (1/4":1'), designed as to prevent back drainage from entering the pool. (Village Code
§ 24-12)
8-7-8: FENCE REQUIREMENTS3:
A. Required: Every person in possession of land within the village, either as owner, purchaser under contract, lease, tenant, or licensee, upon which is
situated a swimming pool, shall at all times maintain on the lot or premises upon which such pool is located and completely surrounding such pool, a
fence or other structure to prevent small children from inadvertently wandering into the pool. (Village Code § 24-3)
B. Restrictions: Such fence or other structure shall be not less than five feet (5') in height with no gaps or apertures (other than doors or gates) more than
four inches (4") square, such fence shall be erected along the periphery of the pool walks. (Village Code § 24-4)
C. Latches And Locks: All gates or doors opening through such enclosure shall be equipped with a self-closing and self-latching device designed to keep
and capable of keeping such door or gate securely closed and locked at all times when not in actual use to prevent small children from opening said
door or gate; provided, however, that the door of any dwelling forming any part of the enclosure hereinabove required need not be so equipped.
(Village Code § 24-5)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 306/416
8-7-9: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
A. Safety Precautions: A skilled swimmer shall be present at all times that private residential swimming pools are in use. (Village Code § 24-16)
B. Operation And Maintenance: A suitable substantial protective cover shall be provided and installed over all private residential swimming pool surfaces
during the nonswimming season or when residents are absent for a period of more than three (3) days. (Village Code § 24-17)
C. Sanitary Conditions: Every pool shall be so designed and constructed as to facilitate clearing and shall be maintained and operated in such manner as
to be clean and sanitary at all times. (Village Code § 24-18)
8-7-10: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any provisions of this chapter shall be fined as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code for each
offense, and each day on which such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Village Code § 24-25; amd. 2004 Code)
Chapter 8
FENCES
8-8-1: CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
A. Height Restrictions: No person shall build, construct, use or maintain any fence or barrier, within the village of a greater height than determined as
follows:
1. In the case of property utilized for residential, or a combination of residential and commercial purposes, six feet (6') above the surface of the ground
or above the sidewalk grade, whichever is lower.
2. In the case of property utilized solely for commercial or industrial purposes, eight feet (8') above the surface of the ground or above the sidewalk
grade, whichever is lower. (Village Code § 20-26)
The erection, use or maintenance of any such fence or barrier of a greater height than above set forth is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and any
person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall, upon conviction of such offense, be fined as
provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code for each offense. (Village Code § 20-28; amd. 2004 Code)
B. Construction Specifications:
1. The fence must be positioned so that the finished side faces away from the lot on which erected.
2. All posts for any such fences must be on the owner's side of the fence.
3. If a fence has a good side and a bad side, the good side of the fence must be placed facing out.
4. All fences shall be erected so that their finished side faces out, and the unfinished side faces the property of the person who has caused said fence
to be erected.
5. The finished side of all fences shall face away from the interior of fenced property.
6. Fences must be erected so that the posts and all other supporting members face to the owner's side. The rough part of a fence shall face the
owner's property. This restriction shall not apply in the case of a fence erected by a residential district property owner abutting a commercial or
industrial lot or an alley abutting a commercial or industrial lot.
7. Fences must be erected so that the posts and all other supporting members face to the owner's side. The rough part of a fence shall face the
owner's property.
8. All fence posts and support framework shall face the interior of the property upon which such fence is located. (Ord. O-18-90, 8-27-1990)
8-8-2: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to fences erected between any land or premises in said village and the right of way of any railroad in said village; provided
also, that fences around manufacturing establishments may, upon special permission of the mayor and village council, be built higher than provided in
subsection 8-8-1A of this chapter. (Village Code § 20-30)
8-8-3: PROHIBITED FENCES:
A. Fences With Barb Wire, Spikes, Etc.: No person shall build, construct, use or maintain any fence or barrier consisting of or made of what is called
barbed wire or of which barbed wire is a part or any electric or electrically charged fence, within the village, along the line of or in or upon or along any
street, alley or public park, or in and about or along any land lots or parks owned or controlled by the village. (Village code § 20-31; amd. 2004 Code)
Wherever in the village, in, along or through any public street, alley or park barbed wire is found in use in part or in whole for a fence or barrier, the
same shall forthwith be removed by the commissioner of public property. (Village code § 20-31; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. O-36-04, 9-13-2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 307/416
B. Harmful Materials: No owner, lessee or person in possession of any building in the village shall erect or maintain or permit to be erected about the
stairway in, or the entrance to such building, or on or about its exterior building line or upon any portion of the sidewalk adjacent to such building, any
railing, fence, guard or other protection of any kind, to be affixed or placed, or in any manner attached so as to protrude therefrom, any spike, nail or
other pointed instrument of any kind or description. Each and every day any such person shall fail or neglect to remove from such railing, fence, guard
or other protection, any such spike, nail or other pointed instrument, after notice in writing from the director of public health and safety so to do, shall
constitute a separate and distinct offense. (Village code § 20-32; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
8-8-4: REMOVAL OF FENCES:
Any person who shall fail, neglect or refuse for three (3) days after notice by the mayor or fire chief of said village to remove any fence or barrier built,
constructed, used or maintained in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, shall also be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon
conviction of such offense, be fined as provided in section 8-8-5 of this chapter for each and every day such fence shall remain at a height greater than
allowed by the provisions of this chapter, after the expiration of said three (3) days. (Village code § 20-29; amd. 2004 Code)
8-8-5: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided herein, any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction thereof be fined as provided in the general
penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code for each offense. (Village code § 20-33; amd. 2004 Code)
Chapter 9
DANGEROUS BUILDINGS
8-9-1: DEFINITION:
As used herein, the term "dangerous building" is hereby defined to mean, and include, the following:
A. Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which is dangerous to the public health because of its construction or condition; or which may
cause or aid the spread of disease; or cause injury to the health of the occupants of it or the adjoining buildings or structures.
B. Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, because of the faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is
especially liable to fire and constitutes or creates a fire hazard.
C. Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, by reason of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is liable to
cause injury or damage by a collapse or fall of the structure or part thereof.
D. Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, because of its condition or lack of doors or windows, is available to and frequented by
malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of said structure. (Village code § 10-9)
8-9-2: NUISANCE DECLARED:
It shall be unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous building in the village. It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in
charge of any such building to permit the same to remain in a dangerous condition or to occupy or permit the building to be occupied while it is in or
remains in a dangerous condition. Any "dangerous building", as defined by section 8-9-1 of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Village code
§ 19-10)
8-9-3: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE:
A. Eliminate Buildings: Whenever the director of public health and safety or any other officer of the village shall be of the opinion that any building or
structure in the village is a dangerous building, he shall file a written statement to that effect with the village clerk. The village clerk shall, thereupon,
cause a written notice to be served upon the owner and occupant or occupants thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service. Such notice
shall state that the building has been declared to be in a dangerous condition and that such dangerous condition must be removed or immediately
remedied.
If the notice has not been complied with within fifteen (15) days from the date of service of the same, the director of public health and safety may
proceed to remedy the condition or demolish the dangerous building. (Village code § 10-11; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
B. Removal Of Damaged Buildings:
1. Whenever any building within the fire limits has deteriorated or has been damaged by any cause to the extent of fifty percent (50%) of its value at the
time of damage, said building shall be torn down or removed. To ascertain whether any building has so deteriorated or been damaged, the director of
public health and safety or any other officer of the village shall notify the village clerk. The village clerk shall then appoint three (3) persons to
determine whether or not such building has deteriorated or been damaged to the extent of fifty percent (50%) or more of its value. (Village code § 10-
12; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 308/416
2. A copy of the notice of appointment of the three (3) persons to determine the damage shall be served upon the owner of the premises by personal
service or by registered mail at his last known address. (Village code § 10-12)
3. If the finding of the officer of the village is verified by the village board, the director of public health and safety or the proper officer of the village shall
then take the necessary steps to cause the building to be removed or remodeled as the situation may require. (Village code § 10-12; amd. Ord. O-7-
10, 2-8-2010)
4. It shall be unlawful to occupy or permit the occupancy of such building after such finding, until the building has been so remodeled. (Village code
§ 10-12)
Chapter 10
WRECKING BUILDINGS
8-10-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required: Before proceeding with the wrecking or tearing down of any building or other structure, a permit for such wrecking or tearing down
shall first be obtained by the owner or his agent, or the wrecking contractor or his agent from the director of public health and safety. It shall be unlawful
to proceed with the wrecking or tearing down of any building or structure, or any structural portion of such building or structure, unless such permit shall
first have been obtained. (Village code § 11-62; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
B. Fee: Application for such permit shall issue upon the payment of a fee as provided in section 8-2-3 of this title, which shall be in addition to the
contractor's license fee or individual job permit fee prescribed by the provisions of this code1.
C. Contents Of Application: Every application shall state the location and describe the building which is proposed to be wrecked or torn down. (Ord. O-5-
87, 4-13-1987)
8-10-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Before any permit is issued granting authority to wreck a building or structure for which said permit is required, the person engaged in the work of wrecking
the same shall file with the village clerk a bond, with sureties to be approved by the village board, to indemnify, keep and save harmless the village against
any loss, cost, damage, expense, judgment or liability of any kind whatsoever which the village may suffer, or which may accrue against, be charged to or
be recovered from the village or any of its officials, from, by reason of or on account of accidents to persons or property during any such wrecking
operations; and from, by reason or on account of anything done under or by virtue of any permit granted for any such wrecking operations. In each case,
such bond shall extend to and cover all such wrecking operations carried on through permits obtained hereunder by such person during any year
beginning May 1 and ending April 30 of the following year. No permit shall be issued in any wrecking work except as hereinbefore otherwise provided
during such license year and until such bond is filed. Said bond shall be in the penal sum of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) for all wrecking operations
of such buildings. There shall be an additional bond filed, in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned upon the restoring and
leveling of the premises upon which said wrecking operations have been completed. Upon the filing of such bond or bonds, the person engaged in the
work of wrecking such buildings and other structures may obtain permits for such wrecking operations as are authorized under the said bond or bonds, as
hereinbefore provided for during the license year in which the same is or are filed. Provided, however, that in case of accident or casualty in the progress
of any wrecking operations carried on under any permit so issued, or the happening of any circumstance which might, in the opinion of the director of
public health and safety, render such bond or bonds inadequate. The director of public health and safety may, in his discretion, require such additional
bond as he may deem necessary to fully protect the village from loss resulting from the issuance of such permits, before he allows the work to proceed or
before any additional permits are issued by him. (Village code § 11-67; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
8-10-3: SUPERVISION AND INSPECTIONS:
A. Supervision: Upon the issuance of the permit required in section 8-10-1 of this chapter, such building may be wrecked or torn down, provided all the
work done thereunder shall be subject to the supervision of the director of public health and safety, and to such reasonable restrictions as he may
impose in regard to elements of safety and health. Provided, further, that the work shall be kept dust free and sufficient scaffolding provided to ensure
safety of workers in and about the construction and removal of buildings. (Village code § 11-64; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
B. Inspection: Any person securing a license under this chapter shall perform his work in accordance with the rules and regulations of the director of public
health and safety and shall be subject to such inspection, during the performance of the work, as shall be deemed necessary by the director of public
health and safety; and the inspectors of the department of health and safety shall have the right to enter said premises at all times, during normal
business hours, for the purpose of inspecting any work being performed. (Village code § 11-68; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
8-10-4: WRECKING PROCEDURES:
A. Disposal Of Materials: No debris from the building wrecked or torn down shall be burned within the village limits. All debris or materials salvaged shall
be removed from the village limits within fifteen (15) days after the wrecking or tearing down of said buildings. (Village code § 11-65)
B. Backfilling: The basement of the building wrecked shall be backfilled, subject to the approval of the director of public health and safety, and in such a
manner as to prevent or guard against injury to the general public. (Village code § 11-66; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
8-10-5: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 309/416
If, at any time after the granting of such license, the director of public health and safety shall certify to the village board that any licensee hereunder has
failed to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, or of the building ordinances of the village, such license may be revoked by the village council.
(Village code § 11-69; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
Chapter 11
MOVING BUILDINGS
8-11-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required: No person shall move any building on, through or over any street, alley, sidewalk or park, or any other public place in the village
without first obtaining a permit therefor. (Village code § 11-70)
B. Application: Application for such permit shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall state the name and address of the applicant, name and
address of owner of the building, the proposed route and the number of days it is intended that the building should occupy any portion of any street,
alley, sidewalk or other public place. (Village code § 11-71)
C. Permit Fee: The fee for a permit to move any building shall be as provided in section 8-2-3 of this title for each, and every, day during which, or part of
which, said building shall be on part of any public street, alley, parkway or other public place. (Village code § 11-73)
8-11-2: BOND AND INSURANCE:
A. Bond: Before a permit shall be issued to move any building, the applicant shall execute and deliver, to the village clerk a bond, in the penal sum of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) running to the village, with surety or sureties, to be approved by the village council, conditioned upon compliance by
applicant, his servants and agents, with all the ordinances of the village, and the payment of, and indemnifying the village against any or all damages,
loss, payment, judgments, costs and claims occasioned by the said applicant or his servants or agents, in or connected with the moving of said
building, and repair, restoration and payment of any and all damages to any tree, pavement, sidewalk or any other property of the village caused by or
in connection with the moving of said building.
B. Insurance: The applicant shall also obtain an adequate insurance policy which shall insure the village against any damages and/or claims or suits which
policy shall be approved by the village council. (Village code § 11-74)
8-11-3: APPROVAL OF PERMIT:
If, upon examination of such application, contents and building, the village council shall conclude that it is not contrary to public interest and safety to
permit such moving, they shall issue or cause to be issued to applicant a permit therefor, upon making payment to the village clerk of the fee required in
subsection 8-11-1C of this chapter and filing with the village clerk and the bond provided in subsection 8-11-2A of this chapter. Such permit shall be good
only for the number of days specified therein. (Village code § 11-72)
8-11-4: MOVING PROCEDURES:
A. Lights And Warnings: Whenever a street, alley or other public place is blocked by a building which is being moved, warnings to that effect shall be
placed so as to warn vehicles from entering that portion so blocked. The person to whom such permit is issued shall keep or cause to be kept warning
signs and lights at night on such buildings so as to guard against any person or vehicle colliding with it, and shall take every reasonable precaution to
prevent said building, or any article or thing used in connection with the moving thereof, from injuring any person or property. (Village code § 11-75)
B. Wires: Whenever it shall be necessary to interfere with wires or cables of a public utility, or of the village in moving a building, the director of public
health and safety shall require proper cost of repairs thereto, to be paid by the applicant and the proper bond to be filed in guaranty thereof and shall
inspect and supervise said interference, or cause same to be inspected and supervised. (Village code § 11-76; amd. Ord. O-7-10, 2-8-2010)
C. Planking Streets: The pavement of any street, alley or sidewalk on or along which any building is being moved, shall be protected by planks of two inch
(2") thickness. (Village Code § 11-77)
D. Restrictions: No person shall be permitted to move any building which has been damaged to a greater extent than fifty percent (50%) of its value at the
time of damage by fire, decay or otherwise, nor to move any frame building, nor to move any building to a location at which the use for which such
building is designed or intended is prohibited by ordinance. (Village Code § 11-78; amd. 2004 Code)
Chapter 12
VACANT BUILDINGS
8-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, and the interpretation and enforcement thereof, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 310/416
meanings given herein, unless the context in which they are used shall indicate otherwise:
DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY: The director of public health and safety of the village of Forest Park or his or her designee.
OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the
state, county, or village as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of or a possessory interest in the property, including the guardian of the
estate of any such person, the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court; or a
mortgagee in possession or any person or entity maintaining, operating or collecting rent for any vacant building.
PERSON: Includes a corporation, a partnership, or other entity as well as an individual.
VACANT BUILDING: A building which is lacking habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises, or at which substantially
all lawful business or construction operations or residential occupancy has ceased, or which is substantially devoid of content. In determining whether a
building is vacant, it is relevant to consider, among other factors, the percentage of the overall square footage of the building or floor to the occupied
space, the condition and value of any items in the building and the presence of rental or for sale signs on the property; provided that a multi-family
residential property containing five (5) or more dwelling units shall be considered vacant when ninety percent (90%) or more of the dwelling units are
unoccupied; and further provided that a residential property shall not be deemed vacant if it has been used as a residence by a person entitled to
possession for a period of at least three (3) months within the previous nine (9) months. A vacant building shall not include unoccupied buildings which are
undergoing construction, renovation, or rehabilitation and which are in compliance with all applicable village ordinances, codes, and regulations, and for
which construction, renovation or rehabilitation is proceeding diligently to completion.
VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR: The village administrator of the village of Forest Park or his or her designee. (Ord. O-01-10, 1-11-2010)
8-12-2: VACANT BUILDING DETERMINATION:
A. Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this chapter, the village administrator shall evaluate all buildings in the village he or she believes to be
vacant on the effective date of this chapter and make a determination for each as to whether the building is a "vacant building" within the meaning of
this chapter. The determination shall be in writing and shall state the factual basis for the determination. For buildings the village administrator
determines to be "vacant buildings", s/he shall, within seven (7) days of making that determination, send notice of the written determination with the
factual findings to the last taxpayer of record listed on the most recent Cook County tax roll. Said notice of determination shall be sent certified mail,
return receipt requested. Failure of delivery shall not excuse a person from complying with this chapter. Any person making such service shall execute
an affidavit attesting to the facts of service. The village administrator shall maintain an affidavit of such mailing for each notice of determination sent.
B. The notice of determination shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of a building determined to be a vacant building, a copy of the
registration statement the owner is required to file pursuant to section 8-12-4 of this chapter and a notice of the owner's right to appeal the
determination. (Ord. O-01-10, 1-11-2010)
8-12-3: APPEAL OF DETERMINATION OF VACANT BUILDINGS:
A. An owner of a building determined by the village administrator to be a vacant building as provided for in this chapter may appeal that determination to
the mayor. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the village clerk within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing of the notice of
determination. The filing of an appeal stays the owner's obligation to register his or her building as required by section 8-12-4 of this chapter. The
appeal shall contain a complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the village administrator's determination, shall set forth specific facts in
support thereof, and shall include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The village mayor shall decide the appeal on the basis of
facts presented by the owner in his or her written appeal and the village administrator's written determination.
B. The burden is upon the owner to present sufficient evidence to persuade the village mayor that it is more likely than not that the subject building is not a
"vacant building" within the meaning of this chapter.
C. The village mayor shall send written notice of his or her decision to the owner within ten (10) days of his or her receipt of the appeal. The village mayor
may, but is not required to, seek additional information from the owner. The village mayor may, upon written notice thereof to the owner, take no more
than ten (10) additional days to decide the appeal if he or she determines that such additional time is required for consideration of the appeal.
D. An owner who wishes to challenge applicability of this chapter to his/her building without the village administrator's determination having been made
shall set forth specific facts to support nonapplicability in writing to the village administrator. In the event the village administrator determines that the
subject building is a "vacant building", the owner shall have the right to appeal the village administrator's determination to the village mayor as provided
for herein. (Ord. O-01-10, 1-11-2010)
8-12-4: OBLIGATION TO REGISTER VACANT BUILDINGS:
The owner of a building who knows, or from all the facts and circumstances should know, that his or her building is or has become a "vacant building"
within the meaning of this chapter after the effective date of this chapter, or the owner of a building which the village administrator determines at any time
to be a "vacant building", or the owner of a building whose appeal from the village administrator's determination has been denied by the village mayor shall
be required to file a registration statement for each such building with the village administrator on a form provided by the village administrator within thirty
(30) days after either the date of village administrator's notice of determination, or occurrence of the facts which would cause a reasonable person to
believe that the building was a "vacant building", or denial of the appeal, whichever is applicable. The registration shall be valid for a period of one year
from the date of registration. (Ord. O-01-10, 1-11-2010)
8-12-5: REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS:
The registration statement required by this chapter shall include the name, street address, and telephone number of a natural person twenty one (21)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 311/416
years of age or older, designated by the owner as the authorized agent for receiving notices of code violations and for receiving process in any court
proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding on behalf of such owner in connection with the enforcement of this code. Said person must maintain
an office in Cook County, Illinois, or must actually reside within Cook County, Illinois. A street address is required; a post office box is not an acceptable
address. An owner who is a natural person and who meets the requirements of this section as to location of residence or office may designate himself or
herself as agent. By designating an authorized agent pursuant to this section, the owner consents to receive any and all notices of code violations
concerning the registered building and all process in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding brought to enforce this code
concerning the registered building by service of the notice or process on the authorized agent. Any owner who fails to register a vacant building under the
provisions of this section shall further be deemed to consent to receive, by posting at the building, any and all notices of code violations and all process in
an administrative proceeding brought to enforce code provisions concerning the building. (Ord. O-01-10, 1-11-2010)
8-12-6: CHANGES IN REGISTRATION INFORMATION:
An owner shall notify the village administrator within twenty (20) days of any change in the registration information by filing an amended registration
statement on a form provided by the village administrator. A new registration is required for any change in ownership whatsoever. The registration
statement shall be deemed prima facie proof of the statements therein contained in any administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding
instituted by the village against the owner of the building. (Ord. O-01-10, 1-11-2010)
8-12-7: RENEWAL OF REGISTRATION:
An owner shall be required to annually renew on the anniversary date of the first filing of registration as long as the building remains vacant. (Ord. O-01-
10, 1-11-2010)
8-12-8: RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE OWNER:
An owner of any vacant building shall within thirty (30) days of the building becoming vacant enclose and secure the building and maintain the building in a
secure and closed condition in a manner which is acceptable to the director of public health and safety until the building is no longer a "vacant building" as
defined herein. (Ord. O-01-10, 1-11-2010)
8-12-9: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
A. Any person found to have violated any provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code for each
offense, in addition to any other legal or equitable remedies available to the village. Such other remedies include, but are not limited to, injunctive relief,
application to a court of competent jurisdiction for a receiver, demolition, or condemnation, contracting for the repair or purchase of the premises, or
foreclosure of any lien the village may have thereon.
B. A separate and distinct offense shall be committed each day on which such person or persons shall violate the provisions of this chapter.
C. Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the village from condemning a vacant building as provided by applicable law or taking other actions upon a
determination that the building is a public nuisance or poses an imminent danger to the occupants of the building, or the public health, safety and
welfare. (Ord. O-01-10, 1-11-2010)
Title 9
ZONING REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL ZONING PROVISIONS
9-1-1: SHORT TITLE:
This title shall be known and may be cited as the FOREST PARK ZONING ORDINANCE. (April 1969)
9-1-2: PURPOSE:
This title is adopted for the following purposes:
A. To promote and protect the public health, safety, morals, comfort, convenience and general welfare of the people;
B. To divide the village into zones or districts restricting and regulating therein the location, erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration and use of
buildings, structures and land for residence, business, manufacturing and other specified uses;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=422 312/416
C. To protect the character and stability of residential, business and manufacturing areas within the village and to promote the orderly and beneficial
development of such areas;
D. To provide adequate light, air, privacy and convenience of access to property;
E. To regulate the intensity of use of lot areas, and to determine the area of open spaces surrounding buildings necessary to provide adequate light and air
and to protect the public health;
F. To establish building lines and the location of buildings designed for residential, business, manufacturing or other uses within such areas;
G. To fix reasonable standards to which buildings or structures shall conform;
H. To prohibit uses, buildings or structures incompatible with the character of development or intended uses within specified zoning districts;
I. To prevent additions to, or alteration or remodeling of, existing buildings or structures in such a way as to avoid the restrictions and limitations imposed
hereunder;
J. To limit congestion in the public streets and protect the public health, safety, convenience and general welfare by providing the off street parking of
motor vehicles and the loading and unloading of commercial vehicles;
K. To protect against fire, explosion, noxious fumes and other hazards in the interest of public health, safety, comfort and general welfare;
L. To prevent the overcrowding of land and undue concentration of structures, so far as is possible and appropriate in each district, by regulating the use
and bulk of buildings in relation to the land surrounding them;
M. To conserve the taxable value of land and buildings throughout the village;
N. To provide for the gradual elimination of nonconforming uses of land, buildings and structures which are adversely affecting the character and value of
desirable development in each district;
O. To provide minimum standards of air and light within residences and to conserve the taxable values of neighboring residences by providing reasonable
standards for floor areas of residential structures;
P. To define and limit the powers and duties of the administrative officers and bodies as provided herein. (April 1969)
9-1-3: INTERPRETATION:
It is not intended by this title to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way impair or interfere with any existing provision of law or ordinance or any rules,
regulations or permits previously adopted or issued pursuant thereto, relating to the use of buildings or premises, now in force and effect in relation
thereto; except that all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this title shall be and the same are hereby repealed. Where this title imposes a
